MR. HAINES re-examined. Q.Is it the habit of your house to account at night? A. Yes, to see whether the shopmen's books agree with the cashier's, and with the checks they have given - if there were any errors there they would be rectified, but that would only refer to having a check too much or too little; I did not call on the prisoner to give any explanation of this - I told him what he was taken for, and he said I should find myself mistaken.
NOT GUILTY .

1387.
JOHN PERKINS
was indicted for
feloniously receiving, on the 27th of February , 1 sovereign, the money of
John Clements Pink
, well knowing it to have been stolen ; against the Statute, &c.
MR. BODKIN conducted the prosecution.

JOHN CLEMENTS PINK
. I kept the King's Arms, Green-bank, Wapping ; my son James is nearly twelve years old - I have been in the habit, for the last twelve months, of entrusting my bar to him in the morning before I was up - he had access to the till; he was so employed on the 27th of February last. I missed money at different times, particularly about three or four months ago, when I had a payment to make; I could not make my payments, as I formerly did, and I could not account for it, I received a letter on Trinity-Monday, and on my son's coming in I showed it him - he immediately made a communication to me respecting my loss, and he wrote down the whole, to the best of his knowledge, I believe; the prisoner was in custody at the time - I do not know that I had seen him before.

JAMES PINK
. I am the prosecutor's son; I had the care of his till and the bar before he got up. The prisoner first came to me about three months after last Easter twelve months; he said he knew all the transaction between me and Stapleton, and if I did not give him money, as well as I had Stapleton, he would tell my father that I had robbed him - the first time I saw Stapleton he came,and said he was in great distress: I lent him 1s.; he said he would pay me again, and told me not to tell my father of it; he came the next morning, and said if I did not let him have another 1s. he would tell my father what I had done; I gave him another 1s. - he came the following morning, and said if I did not give him half a crown he would tell my father; he continued to come for about three months; sometimes every morning in the week, and sometimes he would omit a day or two - the smallest sum he ever had was 1s.; the prisoner afterwards came, and had money in the same way; I remember giving him a sovereign, about the 27th of February; he said if I did not give it him he would tell my father I had robbed him; I got that sovereign from the cash-box, when I went with the key to get change - I gave the sovereign to the prisoner in Princes-street; I did not tell him where I got it - he had come in the early part of the morning to my father's house, and asked for it; I took it out of the cash-box, about nine o'clock - I met him about six in the evening, and gave it him, about three hundred yards from my father's; I was to meet him on the pier-head, but as I was going on an errand I met him in Princes-street; he asked if I had got it - I told our pot-boy, who was with me, to step aside, and I gave the prisoner the sovereign; the potboy was not near enough to see what passed - there was a boy named Lewis at the end of the street, right opposite to us; the prisoner always knew where I got the money from.
Prisoner. What money I had of him was to buy things for him; I did not have it myself. Witness. All I had of him was a plane, a hammer, and a small pocket-pistol; I gave him altogether about 25l.

GEORGE LEWIS
. I live with my uncle, who is a pilot, and am twelve years old. I saw the prisoner and
James Pink
in Princes-street; I saw Pink give him a sovereign; I was at the corner, and saw it in his hand - I live at No. 49, Berwick-street; this was about five months ago.

GEORGE ELLIS
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner on this charge on the 19th of June; he was then in the House of Correction - I told him what I took him for, but made use of no threat or promise to him; he stated to me that he had been very uneasy about it, and as soon as he was liberated from the House of Correction he intended to have gone to Mr. Pink's, and made disclosure of the whole matter; he then began to relate the circumstances to me - I cautioned him that what he said I should be obliged to state to the Magistrate - he said he had made up his mind to tell the truth, and he would tell me; he then said he had received in gold, from young Pink, upwards of 50l., and at various times he had received silver, which he supposed altogether might be 80l. or 90l. - he did not say exactly the time, but said it had been going on for some months, and on one occasion, he had received eight sovereigns.

JAMES PINK
. The largest sum I ever gave him was two sovereigns.

Prisoner. When I was brought from the House of Correction the officer asked me to have something to drink - I said half a pint of porter would do me good; they gave me ale, I believe, and I did not know what I said.

GEORGE ELLIS
. He said he was very weak, and I gave him half a pint of porter and a biscuit.

GUILTY . Aged 17. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1388.
HIERONIMUS BENJAMIN STENICKEN
was indicted for
feloniously receiving, on the 1st of April , 2 sixpences, and 6 pence, the monies of
John Clements Pink
, well knowing them to have been stolen ; against the Statute, &c.
MR. BODKIN conducted the prosecution.

JOHN CLEMENTS PINK
. I was in the habit of leaving the bar to my son in the morning - I have missed money; I have seen the prisoner at my house.

JAMES PINK
. I first saw the prisoner six or seven months ago - he came and said he would have money as well as Perkins and Stapleton, or else he would tell my father; he had money several times after that, and on Good Friday he had 1s. 6d. - he saw me take it from the till.
NOT GUILTY .

1389.
HIERONIMUS BENJAMIN STENICKEN
was again indicted for
feloniously receiving, on the 13th of April , 5 sovereigns, 2 half-sovereigns, 2 half-crowns, 20 shillings, 10 sixpences, 36 pence, and 43 halfpence, the monies of
John Clements Pink
, well knowing them to have been stolen ; against the Statute, &c.
MR. BODKIN conducted the prosecution.

JAMES PINK
. On the 13th of April I gave the prisoner some money, but he saw me take that from the till; I gave him a sovereign and a half-sovereign about four month ago, in Old Gravel-lane, which is about a quarter of a mile from my father's house - I gave it to him as I was going to school; he had come that morning, and said if I did not let him have 30s. he would tell my father - I took it from my father's cash-box; he has frequently shown me a paper directed to my father, as I was standing at the bar - he said it was to let my father know of the transaction if I did not give him money; I saw the name of Pink on it.

JAMES GONNER
. I was in the habit of going to Mr. Pink's, to supply them with milk, just before seven o'clock in the morning - I have seen the prisoner, Perkins, and three or four more in the tap-room; I thought what they were drinking they did not pay for.

THOMAS ALEXANDER ROBERTS
. I am a lighterman. I sold the prisoner a boat for 12l., and he paid me 8l. off it - I do not know where he got the money.

GEORGE ELLIS
. I took the prisoner. I said it was for inducing young Pink to rob his father - he said he knew nothing about him; I found this paper on him, and the duplicate of a musical snuff-box - I asked how he got this paper; he said he picked it up in Wapping, and he bought the snuff-box of Mr. Howard.
The paper being read was scarcely legible, but related to something about the prosecutor's son giving money away, and was directed to the prosecutor.
Prisoner's Defence. That letter I had from Deane the morning before I went away - I did not know what was in it; I cannot read or write.

GUILTY . Aged 19. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1390.
FREDERICK THOMAS
was indicted for
feloniously receiving, on the 27th of May , 1 shilling, the money of
John Clements Pink
, well knowing the same to have been stolen .

This case was of a similar nature to the last; the prisoner having seen the money taken from the till, was ordered to be detained on a charge of stealing, and on this indictment was
ACQUITTED .

1391.
JOHN WHITE
was indicted for
feloniously receiving, on the 23rd of May , 20 shillings, 10 sixpences, 36 penny-pieces, and 48 halfpence, the monies of
John Clements Pink
, well knowing the same to have been stolen ; against the Statute, &c.
The prisoner had in this case also seen the money taken from the till, he was detained to be indicted as a principal.
NOT GUILTY .

1392.
ROBERT STAPLETON
was indicted for
feloniously receiving, on the 28th of April , 40 shillings, 36 pence, and 48 halfpence, the monies of
John Clements Pink
, well knowing the same to have been stolen ; against the Statute, &c.
This was a case of precisely similar nature as the last.
NOT GUILTY .

1393.
JOHN HART
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of June , 2 pairs of shoes, value 5s., and 1 pair of boots, value 1s. , the goods of
Mary Ann Moore
.

MARY ANN MOORE
. I am single , and live in Newman-street, Oxford-street. I employed the prisoner as a carpenter about my house, and as a porter in my shop - I dealt in brokery , but I have now sold off my stock; I saw at Mr. Shaves' shop, on the 10th of June, some shoes, which were part of my stock - I had missed shoes, and never gave the prisoner authority to pawn or sell them.

JOHN SHAVE
. I live in Union-street, Middlesex-hospital, and am a harness maker. The prisoner lodged in my house - he left in my debt; he agreed to pay me 5s. a week; he left, as security with me, nineteen duplicates and two boxes - one of the duplicates was for shoes, which were at Mr. Baxter's, and I took them out; I also bought of him a pair of child's boots on the 6th of May.

GEORGE NORMAN
. I am a shopman to Mr. Baxter, a pawnbroker. The prisoner pawned two pairs of shoes on the 28th of April, and I gave him this duplicate.

JAMES McCORMICK
. I am a Police-constable. I took the prisoner on the 10th of June, at Mrs. Moore's. I have the shoes and boots.

MARY ANN MOORE
. These are my property.

COURT. Q. Are you married? A.There was a ceremony, but in consequence of my first husband being alive, it was put aside - Moore, my first husband, was transported for fourteen years; it was proved he was alive, and I never lived with Mr. Case (my second husband) afterwards - I have not heard of my first husband for four years; I believe he is alive, but am not certain - the fourteen years have been up about a year, but he has not returned; I bought these shoes four months ago.
Prisoner. Mr. Case came and took away several things, and she called me to turn him out.

MARY ANN MOORE
. He took a sideboard, but not the shoes - the shoes were up stairs.
The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating that he had bought the shoes in the street.
NOT GUILTY .

1394.
MARY HAWKINS
was indicted
for stealing, on the 6th of June , 3 shillings, and 3 sixpences , the monies of
Charles Hambleton
.

CHARLES HAMBLETON
. I live in Exeter-street, Chelsea
. The prisoner was in my service; I put three marked shillings and three marked sixpences into my breeches pocket, which I left hanging on the back of a chair at the foot of my bed, on the 6th of June, between eight and nine o'clock in the morning - I went up about two, and 1s. 6d. of the money was gone; I went up again in the evening, and it was then all gone - I had told the Policeconstable to be in the tap-room, and just as the prisoner was going home, about nine o'clock in the evening, I told her to stop in the parlour - the Police-constable then came in; I said I thought she had some money which she took from my breeches pocket up-stairs - she gave no answer; the officer said she must give up what she had or he must search her - she then gave up these two shillings and two sixpences, which are what I had marked; the other 1s. 6d. was gone; she said if she had had them she must have lost them.

Cross-examined by MR. BALL. Q. Had you a good character with her? A. Yes; I did not give her the breeches to brush - she had not the care of any clothes; she did not say, "In brushing your clothes, the money fell out, and I forgot to give it you."

RICHARD NEWLAND
. I am a Police-constable. I was called in - the prisoner denied taking the money, and the prosecutor wished me to search her, which I did; I took from her these two shillings and two sixpences - she took her pocket off, and I found them in it; I asked what she had done with the rest - she said if she had that she must have lost it; the prosecutor stated he had marked the money - the marks are on it now; she acknowledged taking it afterwards.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 18.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Confined Seven Days .

1395.
LOUIS MANUEL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of May , 1 watch, value 29s.; 1 chain, value 6d., and 2 seals, value 1s. , the goods of
John Baptist
.
The prosecutor and prisoner being Portuguese, the evidence was explained by an interpreter.

JOHN BAPTIST. I lodge in Cornwall-street
. The prisoner lodged in the same room; I had a watch in my chest- one Friday, about a month ago, the prisoner slept in my room, and had been there that day; I saw the watch at Mr. Phillips' shop - it had a chain and two seals to it; the prisoner is a countryman of mine.

WATKIN PHILLIPS
. I deal in clothes. I bought this watch of the prisoner; he came one Friday with it - I laid the watch in my window, and the prosecutor saw it and claimed it - the prisoner said he was going away and the watch was of no use to him; he asked 13s. for it - I offered him 9s.; he went away, returned, and took it.

WILLIAM CLAYTON
. I am a Police-constable. I took the prisoner.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 25.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Fined 1s. and Discharged.

1396. - MAYON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of May , 1 handkerchief, value 2d., and 1 crown-piece, the property of
John Thomas
, from his person .
The prisoner and prosecutor, being natives of India, had the evidence explained by an interpreter.

JOHN THOMAS
. I lost a handkerchief, which I had puton the prisoner's bed - I asked him for it; he said he did not know any thing about it - I afterwards saw it in his hand, and called an officer who took him; this is the handkerchief - there had been a crown-piece in the corner of it, but that is gone.

JOSEPH BARDEN
. I am a Police-constable. I took this handkerchief from the prisoner's hand.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I was in the yard, and found it against the wall - I put it into my bosom, and next day I took it out to use and the prosecutor claimed it.
NOT GUILTY .

1397.
JOHN REGAN
was indicted for
bigamy .
MESSRS. PHILLIPS and CLARKSON conducted the prosecution.

JAMES GROMWELL
. I was clerk to the Reverend Father O'Flynn, parish priest of Adair in the county of Limerick. The prisoner and
Mary Murphy
were married by him on the first Sunday after Easter, in the fifty-fifth year of the reign of King George the Third; they were married in the priest's parlour - there was a candle lighted, and I attended the ceremony; they were married with a silver ring, which was lent by Mrs. Fitzgibbons, who was a Carmelite, and they wear silver rings - I did not get any remuneration; they dined in the priest's kitchen, had bacon and cabbage, and some cyder or ale; I gave them the drink by Father O'Flynn's direction - I did not see Father O'Flynn receive any money for this marriage, and I never knew a marriage before without; I saw Mary Murphy on Wednesday last, alive in London - I waited on the prisoner the whole of the day of the wedding, and know him very well - his hair was cut short, which is not usual; he had been a soldier.

COURT. Q. Was it the usual marriage ceremony, according to the Catholic church? A. Yes; Father O'Flynn was a regular priest, and acting as such - I saw the prisoner in the same village some years after; I know he is the same man.
Prisoner. Q. Is not Father O'Flynn deranged? A. He was not at the time; he has been since.

JAMES PALMER
. I am assistant clerk of St. Martin's in the Field's. In January last an application was made to us, by a person describing herself as
Mary Regan
; in consequence of what she said, we got a warrant for the apprehension of the prisoner - the prisoner saw the same person at Bow-street; he then made an affidavit that she was his wife, that he was born in Limerick, in Ireland, and had obtained no other settlement; he was ordered, with his wife and children, to be passed to Ireland; this is the affidavit - it was read and explained to him, and I saw him sign it.

- SAWYER. I am parish clerk of St. Ann's, Soho. I remember the prisoner being married, but I cannot say in what month - I have the register here of the marriage of
John Regan
and
Jane Nicklin
, on the 8th of February last, but the banns were published in the name of Nicholin.

JANE NICKLIN
. I married the prisoner in February, at St. Ann's, Soho; I did not then know he had a wife.

Prisoner. Q. How long was I away before I returned to you, after I was taken on a charge of deserting my other wife and children? A. I did not know of his being taken on that charge; I never sowed any money up in the collar of his coat, to bring him back to England - I did not know of his being removed to Ireland.

COURT. Q. Had you been married before? A. Yes, I was a widow; here is the certificate of my first marriage - I had no reason to believe the prisoner had been married before; I keep a house in Naseby-court - I take in lodgers.
MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Was the prisoner sent to prison for his cruelty to you? A. Yes, about a fortnight after we were married; he was kept there ten days - he was a Policeman.
Prisoner's Defence. Her house is of the worst description - there is a room in it for***; I went to get a warrant against it, and she said I was spoiling the house.

GUILTY . Aged 35. -
Confined Twelve Months .

1398.
JAMES LOVELESS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of May , 1 fork, value 6d.; 4 knifes, value 3s., and 2 spoons, value 1s. , the goods of
Hannah Laing
.

JOHN KING
. I am in the service of Mrs.
Hannah Laing
; she keeps an hotel in Leicester-place
. The prisoner was in the habit of bringing porter to the house, and he used to fetch the pots away; some small knives, spoons, and a fork were missed.

THOMAS RICHMOND
. I am a Police-constable. I went with Mrs. Laing to the Bell public-house, in Leicester-street, where the prisoner lived as pot-boy; I searched a box in his sleeping-room, which was pointed out by his master, in his presence - he was desired to give the key, that it might be searched; he opened it - these articles and a pair of scissors were found in it.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I found these things wrapped in a paper in one of the cans - I did not know whose they were, and I put them on one side till they were asked for; I found them in my master's kitchen.
The prisoner received a good character.

GUILTY . Aged 22. -
Confined Six Months .

1399.
MARGARET MULDOON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of April , 2 handkerchiefs, value 4s. , the goods of
Jeremiah Dismon
, her master.

JEREMIAH DISMON
. I keep the King's Arms, in Slater-street, Bethnal-green
; the prisoner was my servant of all work. On the 15th of April I got up at eight o'clock in the morning; I missed her - she had been with me a month; I missed two handkerchiefs which had been in my private sitting-room the last thing over night - I went to Crown-court, Milton-street, and found the prisoner in a room with an old woman; I found this handkerchief on the bed - it is mine.

CHARLES KNAPP
. I live in Chiswell-street. I have a handkerchief, pawned by the prisoner.

JAMES HANLEY
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner, and produce the handkerchief.

MARY RIGGS
. The prisoner came to me when she left her place, and brought this handkerchief; I have known her some time - she had a good character.
GUILTY . Aged 22.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Confined Seven Days .

1400.
EDWARD MOLLOY
and
DENNIS SULLIVAN
were indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of June , 1 coat, value 2s., and 1 sixpence , the property of
Daniel Marney
.

DANIEL MARNEY
. I live servant with Mr.
George Poynton
, in Essex-street, Whitechapel, a silk manufacturer. On the 13th of June I was in Essex-street, with my master's truck; I had known the prisoner for some time- they assisted in pushing it; my coat was on the front of the trunk - I saw Sullivan put his hand on it, and draw it to the hind part; I missed it immediately, and the prisoners turned up Rose and Crown-court - I took the truck home; I saw Sullivan in the street afterwards, and asked him for my coat - he laughed at me; I saw Molloy at four o'clock, carrying my coat, truned inside out, down Whitechapel - it was a corderoy coat, with a fustian lining, and there was a sixpence in the pocket.

JAMES BRUNIGES
. I saw Marney with the trunk, and helped to push it; the prisoners came up, and I left it -I saw Sullivan shift the coat into Molloy's hands; they turned up Rose and Crown-court.

WILLIAM WHEATLEY
. I am a Police-constable. I took Sullivan in bed at his mother's house - I took Molloy in Essex-street.
Sullivan's Defence. I had not seen the prosecutor all the day, till I was going out of a public-house, and he said, "Sullivan, bring my coat back;" I said "What coat?" he said, "Never mind."
Molloy's Defence. I had not seen him at all till he came in his shirt-sleeves, and said, "Bring that coat back."

MOLLOY -
GUILTY . Aged 16. (See page 665.)

SULLIVAN -
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Confined Three Months .

1401.
THOMAS WILKS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of May , 1 watch, value 40s. , the goods of
Richard Ringer
.

RICHARD RINGER
. I live in Lower Dorchester-street, Connaught-square
. I lost a watch on the 9th of June, from a mantel-piece in my parlour, adjoining my shop - I had seen the prisoner there twice that day; I afterwards saw him in the Heart of Oak tavern - I asked him for the watch; he took it from his pocket, and endeavoured to pass it to another person or persons in his company - he had been employed by me as a carpenter, and had access to that room; I taxed him with it a day or two after I missed it, and asked if he had not taken it in a lark or joke - he denied it; I asked a man named Finch if he had it, and he said No, he had returned it to Wilks.

Cross-examined by MR. BALL. Q. What are you? -A. A green-grocer - I have known the prisoner five months; I did treat this as a lark - Finch is no friend of mine; I did not see any fun going on when I found it - I asked Finch, (whose name I did not know at that time,) to show me the watch he received from Wilks, and he said he had returned it to him; I then asked Wilks for it - he denied it, but he took it out, and was handing it to the other - I said if he did not give it up I would get an officer.

SOPHIA RINGER
. I am the prosecutor's wife. In the month of May the prisoner was at our house - my husband's watch hung on a nail over the mantel-piece; I missed it between ten and eleven o'clock at night - this is it - it is worth 40s.

DANIEL LORIGAN
. I am a Police-constable. I took the prisoner, and found on him a purse, three sovereigns, and five keys - I received this watch from the prosecutor.

GEORGE FINCH
. I was master of a stage, but have parted with it, and live with my uncle - this watch was placed in my hands, as security for 6l., by the prisoner - he said it was gold, and that he gave ten guineas for it.

GUILTY . Aged 28. -
Transported for Seven Years .
Fifth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin .

1402.
JOHN RAGAN
and
CATHERINE RAGAN
were indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of May , 1 watch, value 2l.; 1 key, value 2d.; 1 jacket, value 10s.; 4 pairs of trousers, value 6d.; 1 frock, value 6d.; 1 pillow, value 6d.; 1 shoe, value 1s.; 1 handkerchief, value 1s., and one 5l. Bank note , the property of
John Davis
.

JOHN DAVIS
. I am a mariner , and came home in the George the Fourth Indiaman. I came on shore on the 7th of May, and was paid off on the 13th, at the India-house; I was lodging at Mrs. Burk's in West-street, Poplar
, and on the 14th my chest was broken open, which stood in her back place - I lost a waistcoat and all the articles stated, also a 5l. note - I had received two, and given one to my landlord; I put the other into my chest - I locked my chest, and saw all the property safe on the Saturday night- I went to bed at half-past eight o'clock - when I got up in the morning my chest was broken open, and the mistress reported to me that the property was at the station-house; I found it there - I did not know the prisoners.

BRIDGET KELLY
. I live at this house - it is a lodging-house. I saw the two prisoners in the backhouse, on a long stool, close by the chest - I then saw
Catherine Ragan
going out with a bundle, and I told Mr. Burk of it.

MARGARET BURK
. My husband keeps this house. On the 14th of May, between nine and ten o'clock at night, Kelly told me there was a man and woman sitting in my back house, or shed, and in about five minutes I saw the woman go out with a bundle - I took the candle, went into the back house, and saw
John Ragan
sitting on the chest; I told the servant to fetch the Policemen - they came, and asked what was the matter; I said there was a chest broken open, which contained, to the best of my knowledge, a 5l. note, a watch, and some clothes - they asked if I had any suspicion; I told them I had, and they went away - I had seen the prisoners, but could not call them by name.

FRANCIS RASCALLAN
. On the 14th of May I was sent out on an errand about ten o'clock - I saw a great concourse of people running; I saw the two Police-constables running very fast - I followed them to where the prisoners lived; they told me to knock at the door, which I did, and
Catherine Ragan
opened it; we went in - one of the officers searched her, and took her to the watch-house; the other Police-constable and I staid in the house - he told me to feel in a tub of soap-suds, and I put my hand in, and found this watch.

CHARLES WYKES
. I am a Policeman. I took
Catherine Ragan
, searched her, and found this 5l. note in her pocket - she said
John Ragan
gave it to her.(Watch produced and sworn to.)

John Ragan
's Defence. This woman is innocent - I gave her the property, and told her to take it home.

Catherine Ragan
put in a written Defence, stating that the other prisoner had given her the property to carry home, and that on arriving at home he gave her the 5l. note.

J. RAGAN -
GUILTY . Aged 32.
Transported for Seven Years .

C. RAGAN -
GUILTY . Aged 30.
Confined Three Months .

1403.
GEORGE SOUTH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of June , 1 watch, value 15s., and 1 seal, value 5s. , the goods of
John Benham
.

JOHN BENHAM
. I live in Oldham-gardens, and am a pen-cutter . I was in a public-house on the 10th of June, between eleven and twelve o'clock at night, and lost my watch from my pocket; the prisoner was there with me - we were drinking together; we then went to the Vine, and there I lost my watch - I missed it next morning.

FRANCIS HENRY PARKER
. I am an assistant to a pawnbroker. I have a watch, pawned by the prisoner, on the 11th of June, in the name of
John Jones
.
JOHN BENHAM. This is my watch.

Prisoner. Q. How long have you known me? A. Six or eight months; I should not have been afraid to have left my watch in your care; I did not give it you to take care of - when I saw you on the Wednesday I said"You know what I want," and you said, "You shall have it on Saturday;" I waited till Saturday; you did not say you had pawned it - I was to meet you at the Thornhill's Arms; I should not have known you had the watch, had not two men come, and told - I waited till the Saturday, and as it did not come I began to think rather serious about it; I was the worse for liquor.

Prisoner's Defence. I met the prosecutor - we went, and drank together: we then went to the Vine, and drank a great deal more - he was very tipsy, I was rather better; I advised him to go home, but he would go to the Pickled Egg; I said he had better allow me to take care of his watch, and he said very well - I took it, and went my way; that was about two o'clock in the morning - I did not go home; I took a lodging, and the next morning I was obliged to pawn the watch to pay for the lodging - I went to the Vine the next morning to say where he might come to me, and that his watch was all right; he came on the Wednesday, and said "Do you know where my watch is?" I told him.
NOT GUILTY .

1404.
VINCENT SIMPSON
was indicted for
feloniously receiving, on the 26th of May , 1 printed book, value 2s., the goods of
Catherine Keith
, well knowing it to have been stolen .

CATHERINE KEITH
. I live in Drummond-crescent - I keep a small wareroom, and dispose of jewellery and other articles . I lost a book of Shakespears, some wearing-apparel, stones, rings, and other articles - a boy named Whall lived with me; I suspected him, and accused him; he took me to the prisoner's shop, in Crescent-street, Euston-street - he sells goods of all description, from a cobbler's awl to a diamond ring; I went as a stranger - I saw the prisoner; I asked him for some fancy jewellery - every article he showed me I said was mine, and they had been stolen by a lad named Whall; he said another lady had been there a few days before, and claimed them - I did not find the book then; I did not go again till May - the officer then found the book; it was handed to me - I said I would swear to it; I waited outside while the officer found it.

Prisoner. Q. How long is it since you called on me? A. I believe the first time was in March; Whall came to the house, for he was afraid to come in; he thought you would beat him - I said I had been to other shops, and found some paltry things; I saw a number of articles, which were mine - I gave my address, as you said other persons might come for them; I said the boy's friends were respectable, and if they would pay me I would pay you; I took away all I could recognize - I turned the boy away the same day; about a month after I dined with a lady; he found, from the servant, that I was out; he followed me, and said he would make an open confession - I did not take him into my service again; I know the book by the print being very small - I had it bound by Mr. Cross, and there are a few scorched leaves in it; my mother is very near-sighted, and was reading near the fire.

JOHN WHALL
. I was twelve years old on Sunday. I was errand-boy to this lady; I robbed her of jewellery and books - I sold them to the prisoner; I took him some bracelets - he paid me for them: I took him these two books, and he gave me 6d. for them; he did not know where I lived - he did not ask me, but his boy did, and I said at Battle-bridge; this is one of the books I took him - I went to him three or four times; he always paid me, and made no inquiries.
Prisoner. Q. How long is it since you were at my shop? A. I cannot tell; it is two or three months, I believe - you bought these books of me for 6d.

WILLIAM AGGS
. I am an officer. On the 26th of May I went with the prosecutrix to the prisoner's shop, and in a box outside the door, I found this book, marked 1s.; the prosecutrix said it was hers - I said to the prisoner,"I shall take this book as part of Mrs. Keith's property;" he said, "Oh, my God, how can you say it is yours? I bought it of a woman four days ago, and I can prove it;" I said, "Well, you must bring your proof before the Magistrate to-morrow morning, at eleven o'clock;" he said he could easily do that - I took the book, but as he seemed so positive I did not take him then; I found no other property of the prosecutrix's.
Prisoner. Q. Did I not do every thing in my power to show you every part of my premises? A. You opened the door, and said you had no property that you knew of.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I was an officer in his late Majesty's service, but having been unfortunate, I was forced to go into business to support a large family; I never purchased an article knowing it to be stolen - as soon as I found it was dangerous to buy goods of this description I never let boys come into my place, and for the last three months a boy has never been into my place; if a prosecution of this nature was to be allowed we should never be safe - it is one of the most cruel that can be instituted: here is a boy steals a book from his mistress and brings it to me - I give to the utmost value of it, then he goes and says, "I took it to such a shop, and they boughtit," and the prosecutor will excuse the thief to bring the receiver into disgrace, and perhaps deprive him of liberty; if it shall please you to acquit me, as I find the danger of following this business, I shall lay it aside - what I have experienced here is the as plus ultra of misery in body and mind; I happened to purchase this - you see what it has brought me to, through the ipse dixit of this boy.

GUILTY . Aged 52. -
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1405.
JANE SKUSE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of May , 1 watch, value 3l.; 1 watch-chain, value 6d., and 2 seals, value 5s. , the goods of
Henry Ridge
.

HENRY RIDGE
. I am a labourer - I lived in Upper Marylebone-street. My watch was hanging over my mantel-piece; I employed the prisoner as a char-woman on the 12th of May - I missed it before she went away, and spoke to her about it.
Cross-examined by MR. CHURCHILL. Q. Had you known her before? A. Yes, for two or three years; I believe she is married - I did not know she was in distress.

THOMAS WATER
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a watch, pawned by the prisoner on the 14th of May.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 33.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Confined Six Weeks .

1406.
MARY TRESHARDING
and
MARIA TURNER
were indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of May , 2 pairs of stockings, value 1s., 6d. , the goods of
Thomas Smith
, and
Sidney Smith
.

GABRIEL BURROWS
. I am in the employ of Messrs.
Thomas Smith
and Sidney Smith, pawnbrokers
, Pitfield-street, Hoxton
. On the 16th of May, about four o'clock, I heard that three girls had stolen something from the door; I went out and caught Turner - my master went in another direction and caught Tresharding; I saw him take her - a pair of stockings was found under her apron, and another pair of the Policeman's door - they were about three hundred yards from our shop.

RACHAEL BUSHBY
. I sit close to the prosecutor's shop, and sell fruit. I saw the two prisoner and another person go to the door - Tresharding snatched something from the door, and they all ran off together; I told what I had seen, and they were pursued - I am sure the prisoners are two of them.

THOMAS ANDREW CAMROUX
. I am a Police-constable. I took the prisoners, and received this property.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Turner's Defence. We were going down the street, and stopped to look at a gown, but we did not take the stockings - another girl looked at the gown, and she ran off; we saw her drop the stockings - Tresharding took them, ran to give them to her, and she and I were taken.

TRESHARDING -
GUILTY . Aged 16.

TURNER -
GUILTY . Aged 16.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Confined One Month .

1407.
JOHN TAYLOR
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of June , 1 fender, value 11s. , the goods of
John Manns
.

JOHN MANNS
. I live in Dean-street, and am an ironmonger . I was shifting my goods in the window on the 16th of June, and saw the prisoner take this fender off the rails, and go off with it - I followed and collared him; he dropped it - I had not lost sight of him.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I met some of my shipmates, who gave me some drink, and I might have done this for what I know - I had had no victuals that day.

GUILTY . Aged 46. -
Confined One Month .

1408.
HENRY THOMPSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of June , 1 cap, value 6s., the goods of
Robert Anderson
, from the person of
Robert Williamson Anderson
.

ROBERT WILLIAMSON ANDERSON
. I am the son of Robert Anderson; he keeps the Antelope, in Frith-street, Holywell-mount . On the evening of the 5th of June I was going home with my sister; the prisoner followed me for about three minutes, then took off my cap, and ran down Thrawl-street
- I pursued, and cried, Stop thief! I caught him at the end of a court and asked him for my cap; he said he had not got it - a girl came down the court, and she said, "Halloo! Jack, is that you?" I did not see the cap - I do not know whether he gave it to her or threw it over the pales; I am quite sure he took it.
Prisoner. Q. Did you lose sight of me? A. No.

EDWARD PARKER
. I was in the street. I saw the prisoner follow this lad two or three minutes - I kept my eyes upon him, and saw him take the cap off, put it under his arm, and run off; the young gentleman ran after him - he stopped at a court; I saw a girl come out and speak to the prisoner - she said, "Halloo! Jack, is that you?" he said Yes - the Policeman took him.

JAMES WALTON
. I am a Police-constable. I heard the alarm, and saw the prisoner running down the street towards me; when I got up the young gentleman had him by the skirt of his coat - the cap has not been found.
Prisoner's Defence. I was going home, and this young gentleman came and said I had his cap - I said, "You are mistaken, I have nothing but my own cap;" I have no friends to take care of me.

GUILTY . Aged 18. -
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1409.
ANN WEYMOUTH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th May , 1 blanket, value 8s. , the goods of
James Wise
.

JAMES WISE
. I live in Platt-terrace
. I let the prisoner and a person who appeared as her husband, a first floor back room - they stayed five weeks; I missed a blanket on the 17th of May - her husband had left the room; the prisoner came that night and slept, and went away in the morning; the husband when came, and said he wished I would see after it - I heard she was in the neighbourhood, and took her.

FRANCIS HENRY PARKER
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a blanket, pawned by the prisoner and another woman on the 13th of May - the other woman produced the blanket and wanted 4s. on it; I said I could not lend more than 3s. the prisoner said, "It is mine," and after some time she took the 3s.

HENRY SMITH
. I am an officer. On the 18th of May the prisoner was given in charge - I took her to the pawnbroker, and he identified her.(Property produced and sworn to)
Prisoner's Defence. I had not left the lodging; I was coming home when the prosecutor met me - I had borrowed 2s. or 3s., and pawned the blanket to pay it.

JAMES WISE
. Her husband had given up the key of the room.
NOT GUILTY .

1410.
JAMES WHITEHEAD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of May , 21 cigars, value 2s. , the goods of
Theophilus Potter
.

SUSANNAH POTTER
. I am the wife of Theophilus Potter - we keep a shop in Warwick-place, Kingsland-road
, and sell cigars. I was coming from the parlour into the shop on the 31st of May, and saw the prisoner put his hand into the box, take something out, and put it into his side pocket; I seized him by the collar, turned him round, and said, "What are you about?" I was calling my husband, and he got from my grasp - he ran out; some persons outside called the Policeman - I considered the articles not worth while saying any thing about, but the Policeman took him.

JOHN COLLINS
. I am a Police-constable I saw the prisoner come out of the shop, and run off; I caught him, and took him back - the cigars had been taken from him by the prosecutrix before he went out.

Prisoner's Defence. I was going to the back of Kingsland-road - two gentlemen came and said I had been stealing some cigars; the Policeman said I had thrown some into the field - he took to the shop, and the lady said I was not the boy.

SUSANNAH POTTER
. I did not - I am sure he is the boy.

GUILTY . Aged 15. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1411.
WILLIAM WILSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of May , 9 pieces of leather, value 2s. 4d. , the goods of
Joseph Bruce
.

JOSEPH BRUCE
. I live in Well-street, Oxford-street
, and am a leather-seller . On the 26th of May, between ten and eleven in the morning, the prisoner came to my shop; I saw my wife serving him; he had dealt at the shop - when he went to pay for what he bought, she said he had some that did not belong to him; I was going up to him, and he took nine pieces of leather out of his pocket- he threw them down in the window; I collared him immediately - he tried to get away, and I had some difficulty to detain him till the Police-officer came - this is the leather - it is my property; my wife had not served him with it.
Cross-examined by MR. STURGEON. Q. He had dealt with you before? A. Yes, for small quantities - he put a shilling on the counter for what he had bought that day.

ROBERT WHOOLLY
. I am a Police-constable. I took the prisoner to the office - in going along he offered me a sovereign; at least he pretended to do it; he held his hand down, and said, "There is not one coming, take it, and I will soon he out of the way;" when I got him to Marlborough-street he ran away, put I pursued, and took him - he acknowledged at the office that he had done it.
Prisoner's Defence. I went to purchase leather, as usual, and was accused of having some in my pocket - I had a handkerchief and a towel in my pocket.
The prisoner received an excellent character.
GUILTY . Aged 31.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Confined Six Weeks .

1412.
MICHAEL WALDEN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of June , 1 shirt, value 1s.; 1 handkerchief, value 3d., and 1 pair of stockings, value 1s. , the goods of
William Moore
.
The prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .

1413.
WILLIAM WILSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of June , 1 sovereign, the money of
Abraham Winks
, from his person .

ABRAHAM WINKS
. I am an engineer . On the 10th of June I met the prisoner in Bethnal-green-road - I was not drunk; I asked if he knew where there was a coffee-shop open - it was then about four o'clock; I had been to a party, and had a good way to go - I had been to bed, but did not much like my lodging; he directed me to the Camden Head, in Bethnal-green-road
- I got there about twenty minutes after four; he went with me, and we sat down together - he said he was out of employ, and had had no food; I asked him to go - we had a pot of porter, and I gave him 3d. to get some bread and cheese; he got some, and came back -I did not go to sleep; I was talking to some company on the other side the table - the prisoner put his head down on the table; I did not feel any thing, but I know I had a sovereign in the side pocket of this coat -I pulled it out in the house, and put it in again; I had occasion to show a person that I had such a thing - I am quite sure I put it safe back; the prisoner suddenly jumped up and went out, without saying any thing - I was surprised, and felt my pocket; it was cut and empty - I could not find him till five o'clock in the afternoon, when I had him taken in a beer-shop.

THOMAS ELDRIDGE
. I was at the Camden Head at seven o'clock that morning - I saw the prisoner in the taproom, sitting alongside the prosecutor; the prisoner said,"There is a man had known me from infancy - will you drink?" I said, "No, Bill, I will not;" I had known the prisoner; I did not see him take any sovereign, but I saw his head on the table - he went out, and I followed him; he crossed to go to Camden-street - I went to my breakfast; I went to the Camben Head again at eleven o'clock and the prosecutor was there then - he told me of this; I sent Glibbery, who took the prisoner.

SUMUEL MARTIN. I am a weaver. I went into the Camden Head about seven o'clock; the prosecutor and prisoner were there - the prisoner said the prosecutor had some money, and was spending it foolishly - he said he had a sovereign in his coat pocket; the prisoner went out, came in again, and sat down on the left-hand side of the prosecutor - I then went away.

JAMES GLIBBERY
. I am an officer. I received information, and took the prisoner - I have known him some years, and can give him a good character.
Prisoner's Defence. I did not take the money.

GUILTY . Aged 22. -
Confined One Month .
OLD COURT. WEDNESDAY, JULY 6.
Second Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

1414.
JOHN AXTILL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of June , 1 sovereign, and 9 shillings , the monies of
John Axtill
, the elder.

JOHN AXTILL
. I am a milkman , and live in Cromer-street. The prisoner is my son, and has been to sea - he was at home with me for about a fortnight; I missed a sovereign and nine shillings out of the till in my parlour, about eight o'clock on Sunday evening - he had been in the parlour, and immediately he went out I went to the till, suspecting him, and missed the money; he did not return - I found him at a public-house by the London-docks, at twelve o'clock at night, and found 3s. 9d. on him; he said he had robbed me; nobody else could have taken it - I had seen it in the till that afternoon.
Prisoner. My father drove me out of doors.
JOHN AXTILL. It is not true - he is constantly leaving home; I have five children at home.

GUILTY . Aged 21. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1415.
WILLIAM JONES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of May , 1 silver label, value 1s. 6d. , the goods of
John Newman
.

SECOND COUNT, stating it to belong to
William Wodd
and others.

JOHN NEWMAN. I keep a public-house in South-street, Chelsea. The prisoner was in my employ for about a week, as an odd man - he came to and fro; this label was in my care - it belonged to a society of four hundred members; I did not miss it till it was brought to me.

WILLIAM WODD
. I am a watch-maker, and steward of the society. On Friday evening, the 27th of May, the prisoner brought this label to me to sell - I detained it, and went to Mr. Newman's; I found the prisoner there, and gave him in charge.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner. I did not go to sell it - I went to ask him if it was silver - he said he could not tell that night, but if I would call in the morning he would tell me. Witness. I did that in order to detain it.

GUILTY . Aged 22. -
Confined Six Months .

1416.
JOHN VANCE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of April , 1 coat, value 14s. , the goods of
George Hanshaw
.

GEORGE HANSHAW
. I am a carman , and lodge at Limehouse
. On the 9th of April, when I went out in the morning, I left my coat hanging up - I sent nobody for it; the prisoner was also a carman - I never sent him for it; I have not seen it since - Jeffs was in the house.
Cross-examined by MR. CHURCHILL. Q. Did you ever state that you had seen it since? A. Yes, but when I came to look at the coat I found it was not mine.

JANE JEFFS. I am ten years old, and live with my parents. When the prosecutor went out, a man came, knocked at the door, and asked for Mr. Hanshaw's-coat - the prisoner is the man; I did not give it to him - he walked in, and took it himself; it was a white coat - he pointed, and asked me to pull a box from under the bed; I pulled it out, and it was locked - he tried it; it was a heavy trunk.

Cross-examined. Q. Had you seen him before? A. No - he was not long there; it was a wet day - he had a great coat on, and fustian trousers; I took particular notice of him - I have always said he was the man; I saw him again in about two months, at the Thames Police - I am sure he is the man.

GEORGE HANSHAW
. I did not know who took my coat - the prisoner had been with me a good deal before, but I did not see him afterwards.

Prisoner's Defence. He said he saw a gentleman in Whitechapel with his coat on - that person has never been brought forward; that little girl never saw me till I was at the office - I never knew where the prosecutor lived.

GUILTY . Aged 21. -
Transported for Seven Years .
There was another indictment against the prisoner.

1417.
JAMES BAINES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 22nd of June , 1 vice, value 7s., and 1 stock and bit, value 3s. , the goods of
Benjamin Corcoran
.

BENJAMIN CORCORAN
. I am a machine-maker , and live in Denmark-street, St. Giles'
. These tools were in my warehouse - the prisoner and his father rented a shop on the same premises about three years ago; I have heard nothing of them since.

THOMAS MADDEN. I am a Policeman. On the 22nd of June, about four o'clock in the morning, I saw the prisoner come out of the prosecutor's front door, with the vice in his hand - I let him go along, thinking he belonged to the shop, but he went into Rose-street, put it into the stable-yard to conceal it, and then came away; I saw Kelly find it in that place.
JOHN KELLY. I am a gun-maker, and occupy a shop over the prosecutor's. I found these tools in the stableyard.

BENJAMIN CORCORAN
. These tools are mine, and were safe on my premises the night before - the prisoner had no right there; he must have got in at the front door - nothing was broken; I fastened the back shop with some pieces of wood, which were removed, and the door open -I got up at five o'clock, as Kelly alarmed me; I found the prisoner in Rose-street - two latch-keys were found in his pocket; they would not open my door - I cannot tell how he got in; the centre-bit and other things were found on him.
Prisoner's Defence. I was not in Denmark-street that morning.

GUILTY . Aged 38. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1418.
HENRY BOWERN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of May , 1 waistcoat, value 3s., and 2 handkerchiefs, value 7s. , the goods of
John Scarlet
.

JOHN SCARLET. I live in New North-street, Red Lionsquare
- the prisoner's mother keeps the house; I occupy two rooms. I went out at nine o'clock in the morning, returned about four or five, and missed this property out of a drawer, which was not locked - the prisoner's father drives the Oxford coach.

ELIZA SMITH
. I live in Middle-row, Holborn, at Mr. Bell's, the pastry-cook - I have known the prisoner nine months, by his coming backwards and forwards. On the 19th of June he brought me a bundle, and asked me to take care of it: I put it into my bed-room - his father and a young man came and fetched it afterwards.

JOSEPH CHRISTOPHER HATTON
. I am an apprentice to Messrs. Owen and Williams. The prisoner told me he had left a bundle at Smith's, containing some linen of his own - I did not then know of this loss; I went with his father to Bell's, and brought it away to his mother's - this waistcoat was in it.

GEORGE PALMER. I am a Policeman. I apprehendedthe prisoner on the 31st of May - I received this waistcoat from Adams - the prisoner acknowledge that it was Mr. Scarlet's, and said he had lost the handkerchief.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 16. -
Confined Four Months .

1419.
ANN ANDREWS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of June , 1 half-crown, and 13 shillings, the monies of
William Carter
, from his person .

WILLIAM CARTER. I drive a cab . On the 30th of June I was in Gray's Inn-lane, between two and three o'clock in the morning; I had spent the evening with a friend, and drank a little, but knew what I was about - I was going home; the prisoner accosted me, and asked me to walk with her - I walked with her; I went out of my way - in a quarter of an hour I was about leaving her, and felt my money was gone from my breeches pocket- it was thirteen shillings and a half-crown; I am sure it was safe when I met her - I accused her of robbing me; she denied it, and said she had no money about her, that I must have made a mistake - I laid hold of her arm; a constable came up, and I gave her in charge - as she went to the station-house I saw my money drop from her pockets; I am sure she said she had no money about her- I had taken no liberties with her.

THOMAS DUNSFORD. I am a Policeman. I was on duty, and saw the prisoner and prosecutor - he charged her with robbing him of 15s. 6d.; I asked what she had done with the money - she said she had no money but 2d., but when we had got about a hundred yards towards the station she put her left-hand into the pocket-hole of her gown; I said, "Keep your hand from your pocket" - as I drew her hand out a half-crown and six shillings dropped on the ground; she then began to kick and be disorderly - I was obliged to hold her arms; I got my fellow-officer to pick the money up - she fell down in struggling, and seven shillings more dropped from her.

Prisoner's Defence. This man met me, and asked if I was going home - he put his hand across my shoulder; I had the money in my bosom - he said, "You have got money;" I said, "That is immaterial to you" - he asked where I lived; I said he could not see me home - he walked with me to the middle of Laystall-street, and gave me a shove; the Policeman came up, and he gave me in charge, but said he did not know what money he had lost- he dragged me along, and the money being in my bosom, the string of my gown broke and it fell; his pocket had a hole in it, so that he could not have money in it.

GUILTY . Aged 26. -
Transported for Life .

1420.
WILLIAM TIGHE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of June , two pewter pots, value 18d., the goods of
George Young
; 2 pewter pots, value 18d., the goods of
John Gurr
; and 1 pewter pot, value 6d , the goods of
John Bennett
.

CHARLES HAYWARD
. I am servant at a public-house, in George-street, Manchester-square. I was coming up an area in Manchester-square, and saw the prisoner with two pots - I went and asked what he was going to do with them; he said he was starving - I took him to Young's, and these other pots were found on him.

GEORGE YOUNG
. I keep a public-house , in Duke-street, Manchester-square. Two of these pots are mine; I know nothing of the prisoner.

GEORGE BANCHINI. I live with Mr.
John Gurr
, of the Albion tavern, Duke-street. Two of these pots are ours- I know nothing of the prisoner.

JOHN BENNETT
. I keep the Red Lion, in Gilbert-street , a quarter of a mile from Manchester-square. One of these pots is mine - I do not know the prisoner.

GUILTY . Aged 19. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1421.
HENRY BLOW
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of June , 1 shirt, value 2s.; 1 pair of trousers, value 7s.; 1 pair of stockings, value 1s.; 1 pair of shoes, value 2s.; 1 handkerchief, value 3s.; 100 cigars, value 3s., and 1 snuff-box, value 6d. , the goods of
Thomas Birkenshaw
.

CHARLES CRUMPTON
. I am a Thames Police-officer. On the 10th of June, at six o'clock in the morning, I saw the prisoner at the entrance gate of the West India-dock, with a cocoa nut in his hand - I asked what ship he came from; he said from the Ruth, which lay in the Exportdock - I said I did not believe he belonged to any ship; he then said he did not - I asked how he came into the ship; he said he got on board the previous evening, and stopped there all night - I asked what he had in his hat; he said Nothing - I pulled it off, and found about fifty cigars, and he had fifty more round him; I found a shirt and trousers on him, which he said he took from the ship.

THOMAS BIRKENSHAW. I am chief mate of the Ruth. The prisoner was quite a stranger - he might have been on board; the property produced was in my chest in the cabin, which was locked, but not the chest - he broke open the sky-light.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 22. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1422.
JOHN WATSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of June , 1 pair of shoes, value 4s.; 2 solderingirons, value 18d.; 1 hand-staff, value 1s.; 3 hammers, value 9d.; 1 nail-tool, value 1s.; 3 chisels, value 6d.; 1 pair of scissors, value 3d.; 3 punches, value 9d.; 1 mallet, value 6d., and 1 budget, value 18d. , the goods of
James McGuire
.

JAMES McGUIRE. I am a tinker . On the 27th of June I was at the Horse Shoe and Magpie, Saffron-hill
, and had this property in the passage, in a leather budget - I went in to light my pipe, came out in ten minutes, and it was gone; I have not got it since - I did not see the prisoner there; it was every thing I had - I told the landlady.

ANN CRICK
. My husband keeps this house. The prosecutor called for a pint of beer - he went into the taproom to light his pipe; while he was there the prisoner came to the bar, and called for three halfpenny worth of gin, which he drank and went towards where the budget was - he returned and went out, with the budget under his left arm; when the prosecutor complained, I told my husband what I had seen, and he was taken in five minutes, but the property has not been found - I had seen the prisoner several times, and am quite sure he is the man; I knew the budget - the prosecutor usually leaves it at our house after he has done work.

ROBERT TAYLOR
. I am a Policeman. I took the prisoner; he denied all knowledge of it.
Prisoner's Defence. A.Witness can prove I was in his company at the time he charged me with the robbery.
The witness did not appear.

GUILTY . Aged 40. -
Confined Six Months .

1423.
THOMAS WARREN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of May , 1 waistcoat, value 4s., and 1 pair of stockings, value 1s. , the goods of
John Aaron
.

JOHN WALLIS
. I am shopman to John Aaron, a pawnbroker , of Whitechapel-road
. This property hung rather inside the shop - I was serving a customer, and a person told me the prisoner had stolen them; I pursued him up Brick-lane - he threw them away; I still pursued, and secured him in Wentworth-street - I saw them in his possession.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY. Aged 16. -
Judgment Respited
.

1424.
EDWARD JERRENS
was indicted for
breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Isaac Ball
, on the 8th of June , and stealing, 1 snuff-box, value 1s. , his property.

ISAAC BALL. I live in Chapel-street, Westminster
, and am a tobacconist . On the 8th of June, about halfpast nine o'clock at night, I heard my window smash, and a snuff-box was taken; I ran out immediately - the prisoner was afterwards taken.

JOHN ANDERSON. I saw the prisoner at the bottom of Baker-street, about the length of a street from the prosecutor's house - there was no alarm; I bought this snuffbox of him in Baker-street for 1d. - I did not know him before.

JOSEPH WILKINS
. I am a Policeman. On Friday I was desired to look after the parties who had broken several panes of glass, and on Saturday I met the prisoner in Tothill-fields, and took him.(Property produced and sworn to.)
NOT GUILTY .

1425.
HARRIET HUGHES
was indicted for
feloniously and maliciously assaulting
Elizabeth Brown
, and with a certain sharp instrument striking and stabbing her, with intent to kill and murder her .
SECOND COUNT, stating her intent to be to disable, or do her some grievous bodily harm.

ELIZABETH BROWN. I lived at No. 3, Shire-lane
, and am an unfortunate girl. The prisoner is also an unfortunate girl, and lived in the opposite house; I heard she had been robbed of some wearing-apparel, but swear I know nothing of it - I was sitting at dinner about three o'clock, with my knife and fork in my hand; Mrs. Dudfield and her niece were with me - the prisoner came in; I did not speak to her, nor she to me, nor had I quarrelled with, her before - she first hit me in the eye, and knocked me backwards, then drew the knife which I was eating with, through my hand, and cut my little finger; she then stabbed me in three places in the eye with the knife - I have the marks now; she also stabbed me in one place at the back of my head, and two in the back - I got one cut in my arm; I screamed out, and endeavoured to get away - Maria Green came to my assistance; I believe she has been fee'd to keep away - she took the knife out of her hand, and I at last got from her; I went to Mr. Lowden's in Fleet-street, and was sent to St. Bartholomew's-hospital, on account of these cuts - I remained there for a month - I had had no quarrel with the prisoner; I never spoke to her, nor offered to strike her.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Nor offered to make the least resistance? A. No; I tried to get away - she did not say a single word to me; Mrs. Dudfield was bound over, but is not here - my father's name is John Brown; I have gone by the name of Hamilton, but my own name is Brown - I did not assist in dressing a person in the prisoner's clothes; I do not know
Sarah Bailey
.
THOMAS THORPE. I am a Policeman. I heard of this transaction; I went to the house about four or five o'clock, and this knife was given to me - the prosecutrix was gone to the surgeon.
Cross-examined. Q. Do you know the prosecutrix? A. Yes; I would not credit what she says - I would not believe her on her oath; her father goes by the name of Harrington, and that is his name.

COURT. Q. You say you would not believe her on her oath - is that from her general character as a prostitute , or for any particular reason? A. I have known her as a thief; she was taken up with her two sisters, who are to be tried to-day in the other Court - but there not being sufficient evidence against her, she was discharged.
NOT GUILTY .

1426.
ANN BRAZIL
was indicted for
breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
William Corking
, on the 12th of June , and stealing 1 whittle, value 2s. 6d.; 1 bonnet, value 9d.; 4 shillings, and 1 sixpence , the property of the said
William Corking
.

SUSAN CORKING. I am the wife of
William Corking
; we live in French-alley
. On the 12th of June, I went out for some herbs - I returned in about ten minutes, and saw the prisoner come out of the door, with my bonnet in her hand; I said, "You have got my bonnet," and laid hold of her, but having my baby, I could not hold her, and she went away; I saw her in the afternoon at the corner of Cow Heel-alley - she ran away; I fetched Hands, and found her in Fore-street-buildings - I am sure I had shut my door, but did not lock it; I left it on the latch - it was the street-door; she must have lifted the latch - I took the bonnet out of her hand; I lost a whittle at the same time.

EDWARD HANDS
. I am an officer and a green-grocer.
The prosecutrix came to my house in the morning, and I took the prisoner about four o'clock in the afternoon.
Prisoner's Defence. I did not take them.
GUILTY of stealing only . Aged 12.
Transported for Seven Years .

1427.
ANN BRAZIL
was again indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of June , 1 cloak, value 2s. , the goods of
William Newmarch
.

ANN NEWMARCH. I am the wife of
William Newmarch
; we live in Cow Heel-alley
. On the 9th of June, I heard my room door go - I ran down, and this cloak was gone; I could see nobody; and on Sunday I went out and locked my door - when I returned, I caught the prisoner behind my door, with my son's shoes in her hand; she ownedtaking my cloak, and said she burnt the duplicate on her mother's fire.

SAMUEL KEMP
. I am a pawnbroker, and live in Golden-lane. I have a cloak, which I believe was pawned by the prisoner.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 12.
Transported for Seven Years, to commence at the expiration of her former sentence .

1428.
JAMES TOWNSEND
was indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of May , 1 watch, value 4l. , the goods of
Henry Masscent
.
The prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .

1429.
THOMAS TOWNSEND
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of June , 1 pair of shoes, value 4s. , the goods of
Edmund Edwards
.

EDMUND EDWARDS. I am a shoe-maker , and live in Grove-place, Charles-street, City-road
. The prisoner lodged in my house; I missed shoes from time to time, and found two pairs at a pawnbroker's - they were taken out of a closet in the room I work in, and in which he lodged.

CHARLES MORLEY
. I am a pawnbroker. The prisoner pawned this pair of shoes on the 1st of June.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 19. -
Confined Six Weeks .

1430.
JULIA COMBES
was indicted for
feloniously assaulting
Sarah How
, on the 28th of June , putting her in fear, and taking from her person, and against her will, 1 half-sovereign, and 3 shillings , her monies.

SARAH HOW. My husband is a wine-cellar man. On the 28th of June, about eleven o'clock in the morning, I went out to market, and saw the prisoner in Whitechapel-market; the boys in the market were using her ill - I told them to go home, and asked where she lived; she said in Petticoat-lane, and that her husband was a drover - I took her into Petticoat-lane
, and a little way up two Jews came by and gave her nod; she directly struck me in the eye, tore my cap off, and took 9s. and a halfsovereign from my right hand, by force - my eye is bad now; a great crowd came round, and said if I dare to assist to take her, they would murder me - I watched where she went; I went to the station, then we came back, and found her in bed - I swear positively she is the woman; I had a violent blow, and for a few minutes lost my senses - yesterday a great number of Jews told me in the yard, that if I prosecuted her, I should suffer for it.
Prisoner. Q.Did you ever see me before? A. Not to my knowledge - I swear positively she is the woman.

SAMUEL GREEN
. I am an officer. The prosecutrix gave me an account of this - her eye was badly bruised and puffed out; she described the woman to me - I knew where to find her, and found her in bed about twelve o'clock that day, in a room in New-court, Wentworth-street - she had some of her things off; I found no money on her.
Prisoner. Please to call my witnesses.

WILLIAM -. I keep the King of Prussia, in Petticoat-lane. The prisoner and prosecutrix came into my house on the morning this happened, about eleven o'clock- they were both a little in liquor; they called for a quartern of gin, which I served them with - after that they had a pint of beer together; I did not hear a word mentioned about a robbery - the prisoner had a basket of eels, which she was taking home to clean, (I suppose, as she sold eels;) I saw they had both had liquor enough, and would not serve them more - they had not had quite enough when they came in; they were intoxicated - they seemed very good friends; after I told them to go away the prosecutrix endeavoured to take the eels from the prisoner, and in the scuffle the prosecutrix received the blow - I got between and separated them, and got my shirt torn; I put one out at one door and the other at the other - the prisoner's husband took her home, and the prosecutrix remained at my house for half an hour - the prisoner said the man was her husband; I have occasionally seen him pass my door - they fought in my house: there was no pretence for money being taken away - she received the blow in the eye in my house.
SARAH HOW. I never was in his house in my life, nor in any house with that woman - the Policeman can tell whether I was intoxicated.
Witness. It was an hour and a half after it was done that the Policeman took the prisoner - when she went outside my door I heard her say she had lost 3s. 6d.; she told the officer it was 13s. 6d.

LEWIS HARRIS
. I was standing at my door, opposite the King of Prussia. I saw the prosecutrix and the prisoner at the corner; a great crowd was standing round - the prisoner's husband came and took her home; I left the prosecutrix standing among the people - I had seen the witness put them out; they were both intoxicated - the prisoner could hardly stand on her legs.

SAMUEL GREEN
. When the prosecutrix came to me she was sober - she looked red in the face, but that might have been from the blows she received; she stated her story correctly.

SIMON JACOBS
. I sell strawberries. I was coming home about eleven o'clock, and saw the prisoner and prosecutrix going along, arm-in-arm, reeling in the pathway, and as I came back, in Wentworth-street, I saw the publican turning them out together - I stood to see the row, and in ten minutes saw the prisoner's husband come along; he carried her home in his arms, leaving the prosecutrix with eighty or a hundred people round her.
NOT GUILTY .

1431.
WILLIAM EAGAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of April , 1 watch, value 2l., and 1 key, value 6d. . the goods of
Thomas Owen
.

MARIA OWEN
. I am the wife of
Thomas Owen
, and live in Upper Dorset-street, Marylebone
. I had known the prisoner about a week; he was paying his addresses to
Maria Foster
, my niece - he stated himself to be servant to Lord Dundas; he came on the 18th of April, and considering he was paying his addresses to my niece, I kept out of the room, as I was ill - in about an hour and a half they went out to take a walk, and the instant they left I missed the watch from the mantel-piece, which I had seen there a minute before he came; I have not found it - my niece returned without him; nobody could have taken it but him or my niece.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q.You have a son? A. A little boy - he is here: he was in the room -I did not know the prisoner was a married man; he discontinued his visits.

MARIA FOSTER
. I had known the prisoner about a month before this; I became acquainted with him in the street - he paid his addresses to me as a single man, and a servant to Lord Dundas. On the 18th of April he came, and my aunt left the room - he asked me to take a walk to St. John's-wood; I quitted the room to get my bonnet and shawl, leaving him alone in the room - I know the watch was there; he wished me to wait at the end of Lisson-grove, about twenty minutes, till he returned - I waited above an hour, but he did not return; he never called afterwards.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you not leave a little boy in the room while you went for your bonnet? A. Yes: he is eight years old - he was at tea; the prisoner said he had to go to St. John's-wood for his master - I had seen him three times, but did not promise to marry him.

COURT. Q. What name did he go by? A.
James Brown
.

WILLIAM HOBBS
. I am a journeyman shoemaker. I had seen the prisoner in the house the first time he called; I heard of this loss, and saw him in Oxford-market - I asked how he did; he said, "Oh, how do you do? When did you see Mrs. Owen?" I said, "Not since the Sunday I saw you there;" we walked as far as far as Foley-place - he said he was going to call on a gentleman, and he should get some money, and if I would wait he would treat me; I said I could stand a glass if he would come in - he would not; I collared him, and asked where the watch was - he tore himself form me, and said, "Oh, come with me," and away he ran; I followed and caught hold of his coat - the pocket came off; he then said it was all right, that the pocket was full of duplicates, and he would give me the ticket and make it all right - I secured him.

Cross-examined. Q. When did you first mention about his saying he would give you the ticket? A. At the office - he never mentioned the watch: I do not live with my father - he did not turn me out of doors: he quarrelled with me for keeping idle company - I left his house; he did not say I should live at home - I dropped the skirt of the prisoner's coat; I did not examine to see if there were duplicates in it.

Prisoner's Defence. I know nothing whatever of what I am accused of - I declare I never said there were duplicates in my pocket, or that I would settle it; I told him I was known in the neighbourhood, and would go before a Magistrate with him, if he had any thing against me, but he pulled me about, and tore my coat - I ran because I should not be exposed; I went into my house, and told my wife, then came out, and went to the office - three parts of the evidence is false: when I met her in the street she asked if my name was Brown, and if I did not live with Lord Dundas - having lived with him at Lisbon, I said Yes; as to going to St. John's-wood, I was going for some work for my wife - I returned to the spot in about twenty minutes, and she was gone; being married, I thought it best to decline further visits; they thought I had a good situation, as I freely spent money with them - the first evening I went there Mrs. Owen said her husband lived on the Continent - people who live in the house can, prove no watch was ever seen on the mantel-piece - the first Sunday I went to tea there, this witness came out of Mrs. Owen's bed-room in his shirt-sleeves, and he was in: the bed-room on the first floor the same day; the evening the watch was taken there was a man in the bed-room, for there was a hat and coat there - this young woman took cups and saucers into the bed-room for two persons.

MRS. OWEN. My husband is butler in a nobleman's family; there was not a soul in my place - I was sitting in a chair and laying on the bed, being ill, but the watch was in the front room - there was no hat or coat in the room; I have lodgers, but they are respectable.
WILLIAM HOBBS. The prisoner escaped from me.

MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did he not go into a house and come out again? A. I followed him in close - he said he would go before a Magistrate, but he would not leave the house till a Policeman was fetched to take him.
NOT GUILTY .

1432.
ELENOR DALY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of May , 7 caps, value 20s.; 2 lace-collars, value 5s.; 4 handkerchiefs, value 5s., and 1 shirt, value 5s. , the goods of
Mary Murphy
.

MARY MURPHY. I lodge in George-alley, Field-lane
- the prisoner lodged in the next house. I had all these things safe on the 18th of May, on the first floor, and the door was locked - I missed them on the 20th; the prisoner's key will fit my door.

WILLIAM CLEMENTS
. I am a Policeman. On the 20th of May I apprehended the prisoner, and asked her about this property; she said she knew nothing about it, that she had never seen it - while I was searching her I saw her take something from her pocket, and put it between her stays; I there found these two caps and a collar.(Property produced and sworn to)

GUILTY . Aged 21. -
Confined Six Weeks .

1433.
GEORGE DEANE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of June , 1 coat, value 2s. , the goods of
John Thomas
.

JOHN THOMAS. I am a plasterer . On the 27th of June I was at work at an empty house in Ebury-street
; I came from dinner, left my coat in the parlour, and went on the roof of the house - during the afternoon the prisoner came and asked the foreman for a job; he could not give him one, and he was taken afterwards with the coat - the witness who found it is not here.

JOHN EDNEY. I am a Police-constable. I have the coat; I took the prisoner into custody, and asked if he had taken it - he acknowledged that he had; I did not threaten or make him any promise.(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoner pleaded poverty.

GUILTY . Aged 34. -
Confined Six Weeks .

1434.
GEORGE DUNCAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of June , 3 hats, value 3l. , the goods of
John Perring
.

JOHN PERRING. I am a hatter , and live in the Strand
. I have missed hats at various times for the last six months - the prisoner had been in my employ, and was discharged about two months since. On the 25th of June I missedsix hats from the front part of my shop; I had received information on the 23rd, and set the officers to watch.

ROBERT PATTENDEN
. I met a boy and the prisoner in company, coming up the Strand, and having received information from the shop-boy, I went back, and watched; the shop-boy, was opening the shop, and the prisoner walked to and fro - he went in, and came out again without any thing; he waited a bit, then went into the shop, and came out with three hats, walked towards Charing-cross with them, and was taken by the Police.

Prisoner. That witness met me on Friday night, and told me he was going to bring six hats out on the Saturday night; he agreed to go with me to fetch them out, and to pay me 4s. for my trouble. Was you not in my company on Friday night? Witness. Yes - you said you was going on Saturday morning, and I agreed to go with you.

JOHN WEST KING
. I am a Police-constable. I watched Mr. Perring's premises on the Saturday morning, and saw the prisoner come out of the shop with three hats - he was taken into custody by Hollings, but not in my presence; I am positive he came out of the shop with the hats.

JOHN HOLLINGS
. I am a Policeman. I was watching the premises on Friday and Saturday; I saw the prisoner come out of the shop with three hats under his arm - I followed him about one hundred yards, and apprehended him with them.

CHARLES SOUTHCOTT
. I was with the officers - I saw the prisoner go into the shop, and bring out three hats.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I was with the witness on Friday. night, and agreed with the shop-boy to buy six hats of him- he said six were too many to bring out himself, and agreed to give me 4s. to bring out three.

GUILTY . Aged 18. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1435.
EDWARD DEE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of June , 1 sack, value 1s., and 4 bushels of soot, value 3s. , the goods of
John Andrews
.

JOHN ANDREWS. I am a master chimney-sweeper , and keep my soot in a cellar, in Horace-street, Edware-road
; the prisoner was a sweep on his own account - he lodged at my house, and I bought soot of him, but he does not buy mine. I missed soot three or four times, and told McDonal to watch.

DAVID McDONAL
. I let the cellar to the prosecutor. On the 3rd of June, about half-past five o'clock in the morning, the prisoner came into the cellar with an empty sack, and went out with a full one - I stood in the street, but as he worked for Andrews I took no notice of his going in, and as he brought a full sack out I followed him - he took it into Crawford-street; there was nothing but the prosecutor's soot in the cellar.

Prisoner. He says it was half-past five o'clock; I can prove I was drinking with a man from a quarter to five till eleven. Witness. As near as I can guess it was halfpast five - I spoke to him; and about ten minutes before six o'clock he was setting on a public-house bench, in Crawford-street; I knew him very well before - it was Friday morning, the 3rd of June.

JOHN ANDREWS
. A sack of soot is worth 3s., and a sack 1s.; I have lost a sack.
Two witnesses attended to prove an alibi, but their evidence did not relate to the day on which the robbery was committed.

GUILTY . Aged 24. -
Confined Six Weeks .

1436.
JAMES CANTY
and
JOHN HARRINGTON
were indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of June , 1 basket, value 4d.; 1 bowl, value 3d.; 180 pennies, and 140 farthings , the property of
Colin Anderson
.

COLIN ANDERSON. I am a baker , and live in Duke-street, St. George's in the East
. On the 6th of June I had a basket near my shop window, containing a quantity of coppers - I cannot tell exactly how much; it held about 30s. worth, when full - it was about half full of halfpence, pence, and farthings - about ten at night I saw it safe; I turned my back into the adjoining room, and in less than five minutes it was gone - a paste board, which had been placed before a broken square of glass, was moved; it was a small cake-basket, without handles - I saw the prisoners in custody the following day, but have not found either basket or money.

WILLIAM SMITH
. I live with my parents. On Monday night, the 6th of June, I saw Canty looking into the prosecutor's window; he was alone, and watching at the corner, about six o'clock in the evening - at a quarter to ten I saw him running with the basket in his hand, close to the prosecutor's shop; I heard the money jink - he was about ten yards from the shop; it was a little oval cakebasket, without handles; I told Mr. Anderson - I did not see the other prisoner there.

JAMES BROOK
.
