The two prisoners came to the White Lion public-house, called for two pints of beer, and paid for them both with farthings; several persons drank with them - they had a Scotch cap with halfpence in it, and appeared to be dividing them; our house is nearly a quarter of a mile from the prosecutor's - I was shutting up soon after, and they were then sitting on the steps of the next house, and appeared to be dividing a great quantity of halfpence.

JAMES COHEN
. I saw the prisoners either on Monday or Tuesday night, sitting at my door, with two more young men; I heard them pulling coppers about - I asked where they got the halfpence; they said, "By Jack in the water"- I went to a public-house, and called for a pint of beer; Harrington came in, and asked me for a light; he gave me 3s. in coppers, to take care of - I returned it to him next day; I am a coal-whipper.

CHARLES HITCHINGS
. I am a Policeman. I apprehended Canty - a man named Eley was detained to give evidence, but he is in the House of Correction.
Canty's Defence. I got a good bit of money at the water side, and we used to share it between us.

CANTY -
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Transported for Seven Years .

HARRINGTON -
NOT GUILTY .

1437.
ROBERT STEWART
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of June , 1 cloak, value 2s., and 1 umbrella, value 2s. , the goods of
James Roberts Dickie
.

JAMES ROBERTS DICKIE. I live in Stanhope-street
. - On the 28th of June, about a quarter to ten o'clock in the morning, this umbrella and cloak were in my chaise, which stood at my door - I am a traveller ; I was absent four or five minutes, and when I came down to get into the chaisea man, who was repairing the road, said "Is not that your cloak, Sir?" I looked into the chaise, and it was gone - I saw the prisoner walking away very deliberately with my cloak and umbrella - I followed, and took him at the corner of the street with them, apparently intoxicated, but whether it was sham I do not know; I said, "My friend, I thank you for the trouble you have taken, but these are mine;" he turned round, and said, "Which is Holles-street?" I gave him in charge.(Property produced and sworn to.)

PHILIP ANDREWS
. I am a Policeman. I received him in charge.
Prisoner's Defence. I was intoxicated, and did not know what I was about.

GUILTY . Aged 26. -
Confined Three Months .

1438.
THOMAS BURNS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of June , 1 candlestick, value 18d. , the goods of
Joseph Brock
.
The prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .

1439.
THOMAS BURNS
was again indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of June , 2 books, value 2s. , the goods of
Thomas Cotter
.

JANE COTTER. I am the wife of
Thomas Cotter
- we live in Vere-street, Clare-market. On the 13th of June, Brock, the prosecutor in the former case, stopped the prisoner with these books, and I owned them.

STEPHEN TWOHIG
. I am an officer. Brock gave the prisoner in my charge, and said, in his presence, that he had offered to sell these books to him - the prisoner did not deny it.

Prisoner's Defence. I met two men in Clare-market, who had been to sea with me; they took me to a gin-shop, gave me something to drink, and in the market I bought these books of a man standing at the corner of Houghton-street - I went home for two hours, and on coming out again offered them for sale.

GUILTY . Aged 19. -
Confined Three Months .

1440.
MARY ANN CLARK
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of June , 1 shawl, value 1s. 6d. , the goods of
Richard Toomes
.

ELIZABETH TOOMES
. I am the wife of
Richard Toomes
- he is a journeyman baker , and serves the prisoner with bread, on his master's account. She came to our room about six o'clock, and asked my husband if he had left a quartern loaf in the morning; he said he had - I left the room a short time, and on returning missed my shawl, which was safe when I left; she was gone.

ELLEN DORIN
. On the 13th of June, at six o'clock in the evening, I met Mrs. Clark, and she had a shawl - she sent me to pawn it at Matthews'; as I was better known there, she thought I might get more on it - I pawned it for 1s.

LEONARD CLARE MATTHEWS
. I have a shawl, pawned by Dorin - the prisoner offered it in pawn at first; we would not taken it in, as she was intoxicated.(Property produced and sworn to.)

The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating that she had met the prosecutrix, who had sent her to pledge the shawl to procure some liquor; and had given her in charge to save herself from her husband's displeasure.

ELIZABETH TOOMES
. I never saw her till she came into the room - I had no gin with her; I saw her on Sunday morning - she offered me 10s. not to come here, and the Policeman 5s.; I lost the shawl on Monday, the 13th of June - I drank no gin that day with her, nor any liquor; I never saw her in my life till Sunday evening - my husband and her's were together then, and had a glass of beer, I believe, at the Crown, Golden-lane; I did not get drunk with her.
NOT GUILTY .
Before Mr. Recorder.

1441.
GEORGE RAIN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of June , 1 handkerchief, value 2s. 6d., the goods of
George Perkes
, from his person .

GEORGE PERKES. I am a warehouseman , and live in Lad-lane. On Sunday, the 26th of June, about five o'clock in the afternoon, I was walking down the Cityroad
, with my wife; a gentleman opposite gave me information that my pocket was picked - I felt, and missed my silk handkerchief, which was safe just before; I turned round, and saw three lads running, two close together, and one of the two dropped my handkerchief - I do not know which; I pursued the prisoner - he turned up Baldwin-street; I lost sight of him just while he turned the corner, and saw him again directly - he was stopped at the top of Baldwin-street, and I took him; I said, "You have picked my pocket;" he said, "Don't take me Sir, I have not had any thing to eat to-day;" I secured him, and gave him in charge - the handkerchief was afterwards delivered to me; it has my name in full on it.

GEORGE GLASSOP
. I am a comb-maker. On the 26th of June I was in the City-road, and saw Mr. Perkes there - I heard a cry of Stop thief! went into the middle of the road, twenty or thirty yards from Perkes, and saw the prisoner running away, and another in his company - I saw the prisoner drop the handkerchief, which I picked up; I continued the pursuit, and he was stopped by a City officer - I showed the handkerchief of Perkes, who claimed it.

ROBERT SMITH. I am an officer of Broad-street ward. I heard the cry of Stop thief! and joined in the pursuit - there appeared to be two boys running; the prosecutor was in pursuit - I came up at the very moment he stopped the prisoner, and took him in charge.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I was walking behind two boys, who threw the handkerchief down - I took it up; the gentleman ran after me, and I threw it down.

GUILTY . Aged 17. -
Transported for Life .
Second London Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

1442.
RICHARD PETER SMITH
was indicted for a
fraud .
The prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .

1443.
RHODA EASTBROOK
and
HENRY EDWARDS
were indicted for
a misdemeanor .
MR. ELLIS conducted the prosecution.

WILLIAM GRAY SKINNER
. I keep a chandler's shop, in Widegate-alley, Bishopsgate-street. On the 1st of June, between nine and ten o'clock in the evening, the femaleprisoner came and asked for half a quartern loaf - I was at the back part of the shop; my wife gave her the loaf, which came to 4d. - she offered a base shilling; my wife took it up, and said, "This is bad," and returned it to her - the prisoner put it into her mouth, and said it was bad, that she knew where she took it, and would go back, to see if they would change it; she went out, leaving the loaf behind - I followed her, and in Bishopsgate-street, she went up to the male prisoner, who was standing at the corner of Widegate-street, looking up the street, the way the woman was coming down; they joined - I was three or four yards off, and could not hear their conversation; I saw the hand of one go to the other - something appeared to pass from the woman to the woman; they then turned towards Bishopsgate church - I followed, and in the pursuit they stopped and conversed two or three times in the space of a hundred yards; they stopped again at the end of Rose-alley, and just at that time Sapwell came by - we followed them up Rose-alley, to the Rose public-house - they stopped at the door; Sapwell directly caught hold of Edwards' hand - he drew a shilling from it, and said, "This is a bad shilling, we will take them into the house, and search them further;" I had taken the woman - we took them into a room at the Rose; Sapwell took Edwards to a table to search him - a good shilling and some coppers were found on him; Sapwell then said to the woman, "Come, let me search you;" she said she would not be searched by him, but he caught hold of her, drew her to the table, and just at the place where she stood, I saw something white - it might be two or three feet from where Edwards was searched; I got another light, stooped down, and picked up a piece of cloth; it felt heavy, and was just twisted round, not fastened - I handed it to the officer, and saw it opened; it was ten base shillings, which Sapwell took charge of.

Eastbrook. Q.They were as near the young man as me? A. No; I think they were three feet from where he had been - he did not pass her; Sapwell took him to the right - if any thing had passed from her to the man, in the house, I think I must have observed it.
Edwards. Q. Did you not swear before the Alderman that it was the shilling which Eastbrook had offered your wife? A. No; I said I could not tell.
MR. ELLIS. Q.Where were you? A. At the back of the shop; I could not see what she tendered, but heard what passed.

THOMAS SAPWELL. I am a constable. I was on duty; Skinner came to me between nine and ten o'clock, and I watched the prisoners into Rose-alley - at the door of the Rose I ran up, seeing them close together, and took a counterfeit shilling from Edwards' hand; I marked it - this is it; I took them into the parlour, and on Edwards found a good shilling and 2d. or 3d. - I put it on the table, and he made a scramble for it, saying, "Don't take my money;" Eastbrook was standing just behind me - Skinner said, "Here is something down here," and picked it up - it contained ten bad shillings; I do not think there were three yards space between us all - we were pretty close together; on the way to the Compter Eastbrook said, "The shilling found in the man's hand, was the shilling which he gave to me."

MR. JOHN FIELD. I am an inspector of counterfeit coin. This shilling is counterfeit, and cast from Britannia metal; the other ten are also counterfeit, and the whole eleven are cast in the same mould.
Eastbrook delivered in a written defence, stating, that the male prisoner had given her the shilling to purchase him a loaf, and at the public-house had contrived to throw the 10s. down near her.

EASTBROOK -
GUILTY .

EDWARDS -
GUILTY .
Confined Six Months .

1444.
ELIZABETH BOYLE
and
JOHN SMITH
were indicted for
a misdemeanor .

PASCHO FAIRCHILD
. I am a watchman of St. Andrew's. On the 8th of June, about half-past nine o'clock at night, I saw the prisoners together in Shoe-lane; the man had a child in his arms - they were both so intoxicated as not to be able to take care of it; I asked the man to deliver it to me, and I would take him to the watch-house, to protect him and the child, which he objected to, at first, but at last gave the child into my arms; a number of people collected - a woman took the child from me, to take care of it; the man resisted - I took him by the collar, and he dropped a half-crown and a shilling, which I produce; he was very near the
Robin Hood
- the female prisoner was about half-a-dozen paces from him; they were apart when he dropped the money - I am sure it dropped from him; he put his foot on the half-crown, but could not reach the shilling - I did not know it was bad, and wished to put it into my pocket to take care of for him, but he resisted my taking it up; I got assistance - Rentmore took charge of the woman; I saw some coin taken from the woman, but did not count it.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. How long have you been a watchman? A.Between four and five years - there might be sixty or a hundred persons, or two hundred about - I cannot say, as I was engaged; I cannot say whether it was a fine night or not - it was not raining when he dropped the money; if it did, I do not recollect it; the lamps were lighted - I expect to be paid for attending here, but do not know how much: I have only been a witness once before - I do not know what that was about; it was concerning base coin.

MR. ELLIS. Q.How far was the man from the crowd, when he dropped the money? A. The crowd had not collected till after he dropped it; there is a lamp by Messrs. Pontifex's building - I could see perfectly well.
JURY. Q.Did you see the money in the man's hand before he dropped it? A. No - I took him by the collar, and it dropped from his hand.

EDWARD RENTMORE. I am a watchman, of St. Andrew's. I took the female prisoner to the watch-house, and found and old stocking in her bosom, inside her gown, containing a quantity of bad coin, amounting to 7l. 10s. 6d. - I turned it out, and said it was all bad; she directly said, "I know it is all bad, and I got it all bad."
Cross-examined. Q. She was quite sober? A. No, she was drunk; there were about fifty persons present when I took her - she claimed the child at the watch-house,

WILLIAM HENRY KING
. I am ward-beadle, of St. Andrew's. The prisoner were brought to the watch-house - I observed Boyle's breast very bulky, and told Rentmore to search her; she resisted very much - he drew from her bosom this stocking, containing thirteen crowns, seven half-crowns, and sixty-eight shillings.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you find any thing else on her? A. No; I found about 7l. 6s. in good money on the man, but no bad money.

MR. FIELD. The whole of the money found on Boyle is counterfeit; the shilling and half-crown produced, are also counterfeits - they are all of the same metal; the halfcrown appears to be from the same mould as the others - the shillings are three different impressions.

Cross-examined. Q. I believe these two metals are different? A. They are precisely alike, but one has undergone a preparation to fit it better for circulation, to imitate money which is worn and greasy.

BOYLE -
GUILTY .

SMITH -
GUILTY .
Confined Twelve Months .

1445.
RICHARD BISHOP
and
JOHN LANE
were indicted for
a misdemeanor .
NOT GUILTY .
NEW COURT. WEDNESDAY, JULY 6.
Fifth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1446.
JAMES GROVES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of June , 1 copper pan, value 2s. , the goods of
George Watkins
; and that he had been before convicted of felony; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 44 -
Transported for Seven Years .

1447.
MORRIS MAGNUS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3rd of May , 1 handkerchief, value 1s.; 2 gowns, value 2l.; 1 waistcoat, value 1l.; 1 pair of trousers, value 30s.; 2 shawls, value 30s.; 20 sovereigns, 7 shillings, three 10l., and three 5l. Bank notes , the property of
Isaac Bradnack
; against the Statute.

JOHN THOMAS KINGSTON
. On the 3rd of May, at half-past three o'clock, I was in Wentworth-street; I saw the prisoner come out of George-yard, carrying a blue bundle - he looked aslant two or three times, then turned to the left and walked gradually on; three or four of his companions came to him and asked how he got on - he went to No. 55, Wentworth-street, where he was taken into custody - the end of Wentworth-street goes into Osborne-street; I saw a horse and chaise - there was a lady in it; in about ten minutes I saw Mr.
Isaac Bradnack
talking to the lady sitting in the chaise - he then went to Lambeth-street; he did not go to the house I saw the prisoner go into, but to the office; he complained of the loss of a blue bundle, and I went with Healy to the house in Wentworth-street, that I had seen the prisoner go into - Healy entered the house, and came out with the prisoner; that was about three quarters of an hour after I saw the prisoner go in with the bundle.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did you search the house in Wentworth-street? A. No; I did not go in- I had not known the prisoner before; I am sure I am not mistaken in his person.

ISAAC BRADNACK. On Tuesday, the 3rd of May, I was sitting in a chaise at the corner of Wentworth-street, close by Osborne-street
, about half-past three o'clock - a man came up to me, and asked me some indistinct question; I had not any suspicion of him - I stooped down and said,"What do you say?" he then left the chaise - I turned to the left, and missed a bundle in a blue handkerchief: I saw a man running away with it - I did not see any other man running; I have no doubt it was the prisoner - I called,"Stop thief! stop that villian!" he had run behind the gig, and up Wentworth-street - the bundle contained a new waistcoat, a pair of pantaloons, two silk dresses, two shawls, three 10l. notes, three 5l. notes, and fifteen sovereigns wrapped up in a piece of brown paper; and in another paper there were five sovereigns - I have not seen any of it since.

Cross-examined. Q. This money would have been more safe in your pocket? A. Yes; the man ran with his back towards me, but he turned his face two or three times - I did not say I could not swear to the prisoner; I said it was a very serious thing to swear to a man, but I had no doubt upon my mind - I only meant that there was a possibility of a doubt.

DAVID HEALY
. On the 3rd of May I went with Kingston to No. 55, Wentworth-street - I went into the house, and inquired below who was up stairs; they said a woman who lay in, and that was all - this was about four o'clock in the afternoon; I looked through the crack of a door, and saw two persons lying in bed - I went in, turned down the bed, and found the prisoner in bed with a female - he had all his clothes and his shoes on, and so had the female; they had both been under the clothes - I brought the prisoner down stairs, and asked Kingston to look at him - the prisoner said he was in bed in consequence of his shirt being washed; he had no shirt on - I had got from Kingston a description of the man I was in search of, and the prisoner's appearance corresponded with that; I took the prisoner up to Whitechapel - I had another with me, and as we were going up the passage of the office Mr. Braduack pointed to the prisoner, and said, "That is the man;" I said, "You must be very particular, it is a very serious thing;" he walked up and down the passage two or three times, looked at the prisoner again, and said, "I am confident that is the man;" he persisted in asserting that he was the man.

Cross-examined. Q. I dare say the gentleman described him as a man without a shirt? A. No, Sir; the prosecutor said that it was a serious thing to swear to a man, and so did I - the prisoner went with us to Whitechapel, in custody; I cannot say whether it had struck four o'clock - it was a short time after the prosecutor alleged he had lost his bundle - I searched the house, but found nothing belonging to the prosecutor; the woman who was in bed was Elizabeth Hall, I believe - she was taken and discharged.
Witnesses for the Defence.

ELIZABETH HALL
. I keep the house in which the prisoner was taken - I was not in bed with him; that was
Elizabeth Christmas
; the prisoner had not been out - he had been at home all day; Christmas had washed his shirt and it was drying in the yard - I had been up to him three times in the course of the day, to make him get up; I did not know he had not a change of linen, and he did not like to tell me.

COURT. Q.Had nobody been in your house that day? A. The lodgers had gone out; but between twelve and four o'clock no one had come in or gone out - I was at home all day; my husband is a cabinet-maker, but he is ill.

GEORGE BRANCH
. I keep a shop for my mother, at the corner of George-yard, in Wentworth-street. I was standing at the door, and saw the robbery committed - the gig was about forty yards from our door; I saw the person who took the bundle - he passed me, and I looked at him very hard; the prisoner was not the man - I have seen the prisoner about, and knew his person, but I had never spoken to him; if I saw the man who took it I should know him - I knew it was a robbery; the prosecutor called Stop thief!
JURY. Q.Do not you think it is a long forty yards from your shop to the corner? A. I think it is about that.

COURT. Q. Why did not you take any steps to take the man? A. It is a dangerous place, I might have been knocked down - I saw no one about; my life would not have been safe - if there had been any Policemen about I would have tried to have stopped him, but it would have been madness without; I think it was between two and three o'clock - there were two or three men round the gig; I knew them by sight - the first thing I saw was the man who took the bundle made some remark to the gentleman in the gig, as it stood at the Two Brewers - the streetkeeper was going by, and he ran past me; he watched the street-keeper past, and then went and took the bundle - he passed me, and ran down George-yard.

JURY. Q. Was the gig in Brick-lane or Wentworth-street? A. The horse's head was towards Brick-lane, and the chaise in Wentworth-street - he took the bundle from behind the chaise, and ran; Hall's husband is a carpenter.

EMMA BATEMAN
. My husband is a porter. I saw the robbery committed as I was passing through Wentworth-street - the gig was in the road, and I was on the pathway - there was one gentleman in the gig, and another had hold of the horse; there was an attempt made at the robbery first, and the man was foiled in it, as the beadle was coming down the street - the prisoner is not the man; I should know the man if I saw him again - I cannot say whether the man who made the first attempt took the bundle: I had not seen that person - I know the prisoner; if he had been the man I should have known him directly - I was about six yards from the man who took it; he ran up George-street - I do not think the headle observed the robbery.

COURT. Q. Did he not come out of George-street again? A. I did not see him - he walked gently when he took it; the gentleman called Stop that man! or Stop thief! I do not know which; I did not observe the man look round - I did not see any one go into No. 55, Wentworth-street; I do not know which is 55 - the man who took the bundle had got as far as the City of Norwich public-house when the gentleman missed it, and called out; I lodge in Montague-street.
Prisoner. When Healy came to my room he brought another man with him, and asked if I was the man - he said No, and they went away.

DAVID HEALY
. A person named Hughes went with me, and Kingston waited at the door - Hughes did not know the man at all; I went and asked Kingston to describe him, and he did - while I was talking to him the prisoner came down, and he said that was the man.

GUILTY . Aged 22. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1448.
MARY WILLIAMS
and
ELIZA LATTAN
were indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of June , 1 halfcrown, 3 shillings, and 2 sixpences, the monies of
William Anchor
, from his person .

WILLIAM ANCHOR. On the 6th of June I was in Oxford-street
, about half-past twelve o'clock at night - I saw the two prisoners there; Williams came up behind me, put her arms round my waist, and said, "Come along with me and go home;" I said, "I don't want to go home with you;" she then slipped her hand into my right-hand pocket, and took out 6s. 6d. in silver - I tried to take it from her hand, and saw her give it over to Lattan; sixpence, I think, fell on the ground - Lattan was about three yards off when she took it from me; the Policeman then came up, and asked what was the matter - I told him I had been robbed of 6s. 6d.; Lattan had not done any thing - she came up at the time I was scuffling with Williams and trying to get the money from her; I know my money had been safe about twelve, or five minutes before twelve o'clock, when I was coming out of a public-house - nothing had been done to endanger it in the meantime.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Your money had been taken before Lattan came up? A. Yes, she saw the other one scuffling with me; the money that was in Lattan's hand had not been counted before I stated what I had lost - I was sober; I had been out with a cub - I am a groom.

Williams. I met him and three more gentlemen's servants - he came up to me, and I said "Let me alone;" he took hold of me in a very rude way - I fell down, he fell upon me, and the servants laughed at us; Lattan then came up, and said "Is there no one to take this young woman's part?" I called out Police! and the Policeman came up; the prosecutor then said he had been robbed - Lattan said, "I don't think you are robbed;" he said,"There is something chinks;" and she said, "I dare say it is what is in my handkerchief;" the officer took us to the watch-house, and asked him what he had lost - he said he could not say; Lattan said there was a half-crown, three shillings, and two sixpences in her handkerchief. Witness. There were three gentlemen's servants just behind me; I did not take hold of Williams, she took hold of me - I was down on one knee when I was scuffling to take the money from her.

JOHN MARTIN
. I am a Police-constable. I saw the two prisoners and the prosecutor; he said he had been robbed - I asked of what; he said he had had his pocket picked of 6s. 6d. - he had hold of Williams at the time; another constable came up, and I took Lattan - I found 6s. tied in the corner of her handkerchief.

Cross-examined. Q. I believe she claimed it as her own? A. Yes; the prosecutor at first said he had been robbed of all he had got; I asked him what pieces of money they were, and he said he did not know, except one half crown; I found one half-crown, two shillings, and three sixpences- I looked at the money in the street, but I did not tell him what there was; he might be two yards from me - he could not see it; Lattan all the time claimed it - Anchor did not say whether he had shillings or sixpences; he was standing when I came up to him, but he had the appearance of having been down; he said he fell in struggling to get the money from her hand - I did not observe any dirt on him; I knew Williams had been down by her hands being dirty- Lattan was asked what money she had, and she said 6s. 6d. in her handkerchief: that was after the prosecutor had said what he had lost - the inspector asked what coins they were, but he is not here; she could not tell him, but she said 6s. 6d. - there were four, five, or six persons present; Lattan had time, no doubt, to tie up the money in her handkerchief; it was full ten minutes before I went up - she must have had time to have seen what was in it.

Williams. Q. Did not she say, "You will find a halfcrown piece, three shillings, and two sixpences in it," when she gave you the handkerchief? A. Yes: but there was a half-crown, two shillings, and three sixpences.
COURT. Q. Did she ask you that question? A. She did not specify the money exactly, not to my knowledge- I cannot swear it.
Williams' Defence. This young woman desired him to go to a house to ask what was in the handkerchief; she said she had it from a friend in that house.

JOHN MARTIN
. Yes she did, but I did not go.

Lattan's Defence. I had the money from a gentleman before; I then heard the cries of a female, saw Williams laying down, and the prosecutor on her - I said, "Is there no one to take the female's part?" the Policeman then came up, and the prosecutor said he had been robbed, but he did not know of what - he then said he heard something fall; I said, "Very likely you heard this;" I gave up the handkerchief, and told what money I had in it; I begged of him to go to a house which I had been to.
NOT GUILTY .

1449.
JAMES TUNBRIDGE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of June , 3 pairs of ear-rings, value 20s.; 2 watch-keys, value 3s., and 36 penny-pieces , the property of
Richard George Spice
.

RICHARD GEORGE SPICE. I live in Drury-lane, opposite Long-acre
, and am a ham-dealer . On Sunday, the 5th of June, I went out in the afternoon, leaving the prisoner in charge, with a son of mine seven years old; I left the door which goes from the shop to the adjoining room closed, and fastened with a padlock - there was a chest of drawers in the adjoining room, which were locked; I left about a quarter before five o'clock, and returned a quarter before ten - the prisoner was then gone; the staple of the door between the shop and room was broken in two - the drawers had been forced open, and I missed some ear-rings from a cash-box in my drawer; I know there were three pairs, and I have understood from my wife there were four, also two watch-keys, and some copper in a paper.

JOSEPH HIGGINS. I am a Police-constable. I received the prisoner into custody on the 10th of June - I did not say any thing to induce him to confess, but he told me he had been in the habit of meeting a sailor named Reynolds, at different times, and he had put him up to rob his master, that he had slept with the sailor that night in St. Giles, and he had carried off his waistcoat, with the ear-rings in the pocket of it - I think he said he had spent the copper; I believe he said there were 2s. worth, and a shirtcollar, and that he had sold in Petticoat-lane.
Prisoner. Q. Did you not say you could get me out of the scrape if I told you? A. No, I swear I did not -I asked what you had to say, and you told me that.
Prisoner's Defence. I know nothing of it.

MR. SPICE. I left him in the house, and he had the key of the parlour to get into the passage - there was a long skewer in the shop, and I believe he broke the middle door, to get the skewer to break the drawers.

GUILTY . Aged 16. -
Confined One Year .

1450.
GEORGE WHITING
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of June , 1 van, value 20l. , the goods of
Benjamin Randall
.
MR. PHILLIPS conducted the prosecution.

BENJAMIN RANDALL. I am a baker and corn-chandler , and live in Chandos-street. On the 4th of June I lost a van, and on the 8th of June, in consequence of information, I went to John-street, Bethnal-green, where I found it taken to pieces - I knew every bit of it; I saw the prisoner there, and asked him whether the carriages, wheels, shafts, and van, which were laying about, belonged to him - he said Yes, the whole of them; I said,"I am very much mistaken if this don't belong to me;" he never opened his lips again - my name had been on the front and the off-side of the van, painted in yellow letters on a red ground; I had seen it safe at ten o'clock on the Saturday night, and on the Wednesday I saw it in John-street - I had received information on the Sunday; the van was worth 20l.
Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q.Where did you see the van on Saturday night? A. At my door, in Chandos-street - I took Christie with me to the Magistrate, but not to the watch-house.
COURT. Q. How did you find the van? A. It had been taken to pieces, and the body was on another carriage - I think it was better as I had it; it was in good order for work.

THOMAS HOOK
. I live in John-street, Bethnal-green, and am a labourer. On Sunday, the 5th of June, the prisoner came, and hired a stand in my yard, at 2s. a week, and on the Tuesday he brought a van, drawn by a large brown horse - the body of the van was yellow, and he took off the lower part of it; the next day he painted the body slate colour - there was no name on it when he brought it to me; the day following some person came, and took the prisoner away with it.

JOHN ADAMS
. I am a Police-constable. I took the prisoner - he said the van was his; I asked how he came by it, and he said he had purchased it of a man in Worship-street, on or about twelve o'clock on the Saturday night; I asked if he knew the man - he said he did not, he was a stranger; I asked if he had any receipt for the money he had paid - he told me he had not; he said afterwards that the man's name he thought was Breath or Brett, and that he had given 10l. for it.

JOHN HODGE
. I am carman to the prosecutor. On the 4th of June, about ten o'clock at night, I took his van,to the wharf under the Adelphi - I put it by the stabledoor, where it was always put, and I left it there about five minutes before eleven; I should think that place is a mile and a half from Worship-street - I went the next morning, about six, and missed it; I went to the stand in John-street, on the 8th, and saw it again - I knew it by some marks on it; the body was not then the same colour it had been - it had been fit for use, and did not require any change at all; my master asked the prisoner whose it was, and he said it was his.

COURT. Q. Had your master his name on the van? A. Yes, on the red head-board, and the letters were shaded with black - the board was there; the van had been taken off the wheels, and the wheels and springs put to another body.

Cross-examined. Q. There was nothing done to it that prevented your knowing it again? A. No - I had no watch when I was at the stable; I had four horses to attend to - I had been to Sydenham, and did not get home till then; I heard the clock strike eleven when I got up to the Strand.

THOMAS BENJAMIN CHRISTIE
. I am a sack-maker, and live at No. 1, Adelphi-under-the-Terrace. On Saturday night, the 4th of June, I went to the pump for some water, about a quarter or twenty minutes before twelve o'clock; I saw the prisoner there, and a man in a smock-frock, leading a horse in the shafts of Mr. Randall's van - they appeared to be in company, and were talking together; the horse was a high brown horse - I had seen the prisoner before three or four times, but never at the Adelphi- he passed close by me that night, and I am certain he is the man; I informed the prosecutor next morning of what I had seen.

Cross-examined. Q.What are you? A. A coal sackmaker - I live with my father; I knew the prisoner before, but never spoke to him - I should not think I saw him above five minutes that night - this did not strike me as a suspicious circumstance; I should not know the other man, who was on the off side of the horse - I did not know at the time that it was Mr. Randall's van, but I heard the next morning that his van was lost; there was nobody with me - some of the people in the neighbourhood were up; it would be a dark place if there were no lamps, but there were lamps, and I stood right under one of them; I swear I had seen the prisoner before two or three times, but I cannot tell any one place, or when, I had seen him - I see a great many people about the street; I never said I could not swear to a person in such a dark place, and that it would be difficult enough to do it in daylight.
COURT. Q. Did you know where Mr. Randall kept his van? A. Yes, close to the stable door, not twenty yards from where I saw the prisoner.
Prisoner's Defence. I bought it within a hundred yards of Worship-street office on that Saturday night.

THOMAS JACKSON
. I am a porter, and live at No. 5, King's Head-court, Shoreditch - I know the prisoner. On Saturday night, the 4th of June, I went to the Ship, at the corner of King's Head-court, at half-past nine o'clock, as near as I can tell; I saw the prisoner there, with Gibbs - I left at eleven, leaving Gibbs with him.
MR. CHURCHILL. Q. How long have you known the prisoner? A.Six years; he lodged with me about eighteen months - a man might walk from there to the Adelphi in three quarters of an hour; he is a carman.
COURT. Q. How far is Shoreditch from the Adelphi? A. I should think two miles and a half, or nearly three.

JAMES GIBBS
. I am a carman, and live in the Canalroad, Hoxton. I have known the prisoner three years - he is a carman, and lives in Worship-street. On Saturday night, the 4th of June, I saw him at the Ship - Jackson came in while we were there, and left about eleven o'clock; the prisoner and I remained about a quarter of an hour, or more - I was dealing with him for a horse.
COURT. Q. What time did you go to the Ship? A. About nine o'clock; Jackson came in soon after.

JOHN DOWSETT
. I live at No. 42, Curtain-road, and am a corn-chandler - I have known the prisoner some months. On Saturday night, the 4th of June, I remember his coming to my shop for a truss of hay, about twenty minutes past eleven o'clock - he ordered it to be sent to his yard, at the Green Dragon, Worship-street; I objected to fetching it down that night, as I did not like to go up with a candle - he stopped till about twenty minutes or a quarter to twelve, as he remained to hear a woman singing; I can positively swear he was in my shop about that time - I live full two miles from the Adelphi.
COURT. Q. What induced you to notice the time he stopped? A.Because I had just then given my man orders to shut up the shop; I am certain I am correct within five minutes.
MR. CHURCHILL. Q. What enables you to know when he came in? A. I know he was there full half an hour; I have a clock in the adjoining room, but it was too fast; I knew the time.

JAMES MULLETT
. I was examined on the part of this prosecutor, but was not before the Grand Jury; I am a carman, and live at No. 2, King's-road, Hoxton. I know the prisoner very well - I was with him on Saturday night, the 4th of June; I met him near twelve o'clock, about half way up Worship-street, and just before we got to the Baker and Basket, I saw two men with a horse and van - one was talking to the other about buying the van, but he went away just as we came up, and the prisoner asked the man what he wanted for it - I think he said 13l. or 14l.; the man who went away had a short smockfrock and trousers - the other had a smock-frock and white stockings; the man said he wanted to sell the van, and he had just parted with that man, as they could not deal - that he did not dare to take it home, fearing to have it seized for rent on the Monday morning; the prisoner ultimately agreed to purchase it for 10l.

MR. CHURCHILL. Q. What did you hear the man say? A. He said he had a van to sell; I had never seen him before - they were both strangers; there was no name on the head of the van - I did not go to the off-side of it; I left them there dealing, within one hundred yards of the prisoner's yard - I told the prisoner, if I was him, I would not pay all the money till day-light; I saw no money paid - I left them walking towards his yard; there was a brown thick-looking horse in the van.
COURT. Q. How came you to fall in with the prisoner? A. I was going by - I thought he had come out of his own yard.

JAMES WISE
. I am a carman, and live at No. 1, Han'splace, Hoxton. On Saturday night, the 4th of June, I came out of Brick-lane into Old-street, which is threequarters of a mile from Worship-street; it was after eleven o'clock, and might be half-past - I saw two men with a van; they asked if I would buy a van - I said, No, that I had only a sovereign; they asked 13l. for it - I walked round it, and said it was not worth half the money; they said their landlord would seize it for rent on Monday, and sell it for what it would fetch.

MR. PHILLIPS. Q. They were strangers to you? A. Yes; I was talking to Goddard and three or four men when they came up - I have known the prisoner five or six years; he has a stable in Worship-street, and lives at the corner of Finsbury-market - I was at Worship-street, and told young Armstrong what I had seen; he sent me into the office - I would not give more than 7l. or 8l. for the van; it was a light colour, the axletree and carriage was dark; the body was a lightish colour - not yellow nor white; it might have been yellow once, but was worn - it was a lightish yellow; I have seen a van here, but it is new done over now - I did not see the prisoner that night.

COURT. Q. Is Brick-lane in the way from the Adelphi to Worship-street? A. I do not think it is the shortest way; it is out of the road - one of the men had a short frock, and long brown trousers; the other had white stockings, and high shoes - he was a stout man; there was a name on the cart, but I cannot read.

ROBERT GODDARD
. I am a carman, and live in Europaplace, John's-row, St. Luke's. I was with Wise on Saturday night, the 4th of June, and saw two men with a van; they offered it for sale to Wise - I cannot exactly tell the time; it was ten o'clock, or between ten and eleven - I cannot be certain whether it was ten, eleven, or twelve; they said they expected an execution, and were forced to sell it to pay the rent.

MR. PHILLIPS. Q. How do you know it was the 4th of June? A.Because I took home bills for my work; I am not certain it was not eleven o'clock - I did not see the prisoner that night; I have known him about five or six years - there was a short punchey horse in the van, short and thick - I am sure it was not a white horse; I cannot say whether it was black - they asked him if he knew who wanted a van; he said he did not - that he had only a sovereign, if that would buy it, he had no objection; the man said he would not take less than 12l. or 14l. - I cannot read properly; I did not notice the colour of the van - it might have been black for what I know; it was not very close to me - I did not see Wise examine it much, for I was talking to Mr. Bedell, a builder, who I work for; I give receipts for money.

Q. If you cannot read, how do you know the date by your bills? The man who keeps my book tells me the dates - his name is Taylor; I can tell figures - I delivered a bill to Mr. Bedell that day; I did not observe any figures on the van - I heard nothing of this till Thursday, (a month ago to-morrow,) when the gate-keeper at the gas-works said Whiting was taken up for buying a van; I said there was a van offered for sale on Saturday night - he said that was the time he bought it; I do not know that I have ever spoken to the prisoner - I was never in his house.

COURT. Q.How far do you live from Old-street? A.About three hundred yards - I cannot say at what time I got home; I stopped and drank with Bedell and Wise, and then Wise went home - we were not many minutes at the public-house; I had been to Burke, in Cooper's-court, for some money.

PHILIP ISAACS
. I live at No, 18, Crown-street, Soho, and keep a horse and cart; I heard Christie say he did not think it was any body who worked about the premises, or he should have known him again.

MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did you go to Christie? A. No; I went to my stable about six o'clock in the morning, and saw him - I never told his father he should have 4l., 5l., or 6l., if he kept his son out of the way, nor any thing of the kind - I move furniture with my cart.
COURT. Q.How far is your stable from where the van is kept? A. About the length of this Court - I do not know the prisoner.

Q. How came you to go to Christie's father? A. Because some word was uttered under the place that was false - the prisoner's wife sent to me; I went up with them, and they told me what the business was.
- CHRISTIE, SEN. I am Christie's step-father. I would not believe Isaacs on his oath; what he has stated is all false - I know his character.

GUILTY . Aged 35. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1451.
WILLIAM SMITH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of June , 1 coat, value 5s. , the goods of
James Godfrey
.

JAMES GODFREY. I lodge in High-street, St. Giles'
; I am a journeyman baker - there are three beds in my room; the prisoner had part of one. On the morning of the 1st of June I got up and went down, locking the door; the prisoner was then in the room - soon afterwards I heard him trying to get out; I went and opened the door - he passed me quick, and went out; I went into the room and missed my coat - I gave an alarm; the landlord brought him back, and he had my coat on under his own.

CHARLES CRITCHLEY
. I am the landlord. I heard the alarm, followed the prisoner, and took him in New Compton-street - I brought him back; he had Godfrey's coat on under his own.

WILLIAM KENNEDY
. I am an officer. The prisoner took this coat off in my presence.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 19.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Confined Three Months .

1452.
JAMES SUTTON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 22nd of June , 1 gown, value 13s. , the goods of
Caroline Bills
.

CAROLINE BILLS. I am bar-maid at the Lord Nelson, Whitechapel-road
. I left my gown in my bed-room when I went out on the 22nd of June - I missed it.

BENJAMIN CORDELL
. I am a Police-constable. I heard the alarm between five and six o'clock, and took the prisoner at the corner of Court-street, Whitechapel - this gown fell from him.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. It did not drop from me - I had been at a stall, buying 1d. worth of nuts, and the officer took them from me; another man seized me first, and Istruck him, knowing myself to be innocent - my coat was buttoned.

GUILTY . Aged 56. -
Confined Three Months .

1453.
JEREMIAH SULLIVAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of September , 1 wooden partition and door-frame, value 2l. 10s.; 200 bricks, value 5s.; 1 piece of leaden pipe and cock, value 10s., and 1 dust-bin, value 10s., the goods of
William Robins
, and fixed to a building of his ; against the Statute, &c.

WILLIAM ROBINS
. The prisoner rented a house of me in Harley-street - he paid me three quarters rent, but when I went again he was gone, and the house shut up; I went to him for the key, and he would not give it without I would give him a receipt, which I at last did - he had had the house on an agreement, which is not stamped.
NOT GUILTY .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1454.
WILLIAM SELLWOOD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of May , 1 bag, value 6d.; 1 sovereign, 1 half-sovereign, and 7 shillings, the property of
Edward Bishop
, from his person .

EDWARD BISHOP
. I live in Noble-street, St. Luke's. On the 21st of May, about six o'clock in the evening, I was in Old-street
; I saw the prisoner, whom I have known many years - I called him to have part of a pot of ale; there was a fight; we went into the crowd, and while there I noticed him very close to me - I then walked up as far as the Pitt's Head; I there missed my money - I came back, and found the prisoner; I accused him of having my money- he said he knew nothing about it; I got an officer, and then he said, sooner than be given in charge he would give me the bag and money back again - I had a sovereign and a half in this outside waistcoat pocket, and seven shillings in a bag in my under waistcoat; I have not seen any of it since, for directly the officer came to take the prisoner, he got away, and was not taken till the Monday morning.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. I believe you were all drunk together? A. No, I was not drunk - I had had part of a pot of ale.

THOMAS BRADFORD
. I live in Long's-buildings, and am a headborough. On the 21st of May I received information, went to a public-house in Golden-lane, and found the prosecutor and prisoner sitting on a seat together - the prosecutor charged him with this robbery, and the prisoner denied it; I asked if he would give charge of him - he said he would rather have his money; I hesitated some time, and the prisoner said, "If you or Bishop will go with me, you shall have your money back again" - I did not countenance that, as there were some of his companions about there: I had heard mention of a bag and seven shillings in silver - the prosecutor said he had lost upwards of 30s.; I took the prisoner - he gave me a thrust away, and ran off.
Cross-examined. Q. You found no bag nor money? A.No.

FREDERICK MILES
. I am a Police-constable. I took the prisoner - I said I wanted him for stealing a canvas bag and seven shillings from Bishop, in Old-street, on the 21st of May - he said there were but six shillings in the bag, and that it was hanging out of Bishop's pocket when he took it; he said the same to the inspector, at the station-house - he said before the Magistrate, "I don't deny it."
Prisoner's Defence. He has falsesworn - I said nothing about the bag at all.

GUILTY . Aged 21. -
Confined Two Months .

1455.
PETER REYNOLDS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of May , 1 coat, value 6s., and 1 cap, value 2s. , the goods of
Edward Richardson
.

GEORGE RICHARDSON
. I am the son of
Edward Richardson
, and am eleven years old; my father is a jeweller , and lives in Coram-street. On the 14th of May I was in Oxford-street, and saw the prisoner; I had seen him before in our street - he asked me where I had seen him last; I said at Russell-square, at the pump - he said he had been to the East Indies since that, and the mate of a ship had given him two poll parrots and two other birds - if I would go with him he would give me one of the parrots; I had some jewellery in my possession, which I took to Holles-street - he waited till I came out; he then spoke to me again, and we went to St. Martin's church steps; he then said I must give him my cap to put the parrot in, and my coat to wrap it in - I asked him if my waistcoat would not do, and he said No, it would fly out at the armholes; I took off my coat and cap, and gave them to him; he ran off - he out-ran me, and got away.
Prisoner. Q. Which way did the person go after he had received your clothes? A. Towards the Strand.

CHARLES MAYHEW
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner - he denied the charge.

EDWARD RICHARDSON
. I am father of this lad - he returned without his coat and cap, and told me what had happened; I know the prisoner, by seeing him about the neighbourhood for a long time, and I had him taken.
Prisoner's Defence. I am quite innocent; if the father and son knew they had seen me within three months, how was it likely I could have been to the East Indies?

GUILTY . Aged 19 -
Confined One Year .

1456.
WILLIAM REEVES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 22nd of June , 1 hat, value 20s. , the goods of
John Perring
.

ROBERT PATTENDEN
. I live in Tibberton-street, Newington-causeway, and deal in fruit. At a quarter to seven o'clock in the morning of the 22nd of June, I saw the prisoner in the Strand
, near Mr. Perring's - he walked to and fro, then went into the shop, and took two hats off the floor, in front of the door, walked towards Charingcross with them, and went away; I saw him and the shopboy in conversation in the Strand next day, before the shop was open, at a quarter to seven o'clock - I am certain of his person.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. You thought he had stolen the hat? A. Yes - I was going to endeavour to stop him, but he went off; I was placed there to watch - I was four or five rods from him: I waited to see another person go in, who was walking to and fro - I had not turned my head before he was out of my sight; he had the hats under his arm - I sell fruit in the Boroughmarket; I saw the prisoner for several minutes before he took the hats, and am certain of him.

JOHN HOLLINS
. I am a Policeman. I took the prisoner in Broad-wall, Surrey - Pattenden had described him tome, and pointed him out to me; I searched his lodging, which he directed me to in Broad-wall - I found a hat in a box on the second floor, and part of a lining on the first floor; a young man named Duncan has been convicted of robbing the prosecutor in the other Court to-day.

JOHN PERRING
. This hat is mine, and has a privatemark on it - so has this lining, which belongs to another hat, both in my own writing; they had not been sold, as I enter every number in the stock-book.
Cross-examined. Q. Can you tell, except from your book, that you had not sold it? A. I am sure I had not; my shopmen enter what they sell.

COURT. Q. Was the prisoner ever in your employ? A. He was with me only one day, as errand-boy, four or five months ago - he was engaged for a longer period, but left at night, and did not return; ever since that I have lost hats; Duncan was also a shop-boy of mine for four or five months.
Prisoner. The hat does not belong to me, but to my brother, and I understand he bought it of Duncan, as a damaged hat, for 8s. 6d.
HENRY REEVES. I am the prisoner's brother. I bought this hat of Duncan - there was no lining in the bottom; I got it lined myself.

COURT. Q. Where is it damaged? A. He showed me beaver was off at the side - I met him in the street, and bought it; the part of the lining that was in it was a little soiled - there was no mark on it.

GUILTY . Aged 18. -
Confined Four Months .

1457.
REUBEN ROY
and
SARAH BRADS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of June , 1 coat, value 1l.; 2 handkerchiefs, value 4s.; 1 stock, value 6d.; 1 halfcrown, and 1 shilling, the property of
James McDermot
, from his person .

JAMES McDERMOT
. I live in Cow Heel-alley, and am a tailor . On a Monday in June I was at the Cock, in Golden-lane - I saw Roy there; I treated him to porter and gin, and he said he would take me to his place to have breakfast - there was another man with him; we then went to No. 4, Chequer-alley
, kept by Mr. Rowley; we went to the back part of the house, and the other man said I ought to send for some beer - I said I had no money; Roy said I had - he put his hand to my pocket, and said he would have the price of half a gallon; he took out a shilling and a half-crown - I did not agree to it at the time, but it came in, and I drank some - Brads was there; the men then said my coat was soiled, and they would brush it; Brads went, and brought a scrubbing-brush - I said I would not allow my coat to be cleaned with that - they said they would have it cleaned, and they would take it off, which they did; I then turned to light my pipe, and the men were gone off with the coat - Brads said it was gone to the pawnbroker's; I saw Roy at the Pitt's Head, in Old-street, two days afterwards - I had him taken, and after he had had three hearings at Worship-street, the daughter of the woman he lives with brought the coat to my lodging.
Roy. Q. Did you not come to me the next day? A. No; I went to your lodging, but you was not there - there was a stock and two handkerchiefs in the coat pocket.

EDMUND HARDWICK
. I am a Police-constable. I took the prisoners.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Roy's Defence. I never saw him; when I went home at night I understood that he and two more drunken men had been there; he called the next day, and asked if I knew whether Butt had been there - the duplicate of it was found two days afterwards in my landlady's house, and she sent it to him - he came to me a few days after, and wanted 10s. to make it up.

JAMES McDERMOT
. They came to me, and asked if I would settle it; I said if they gave me 10s., and paid for my time I would; but I was told I should be tried myself if I did.
NOT GUILTY .

1458.
MARY PAGE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of June , 1 crown, 1 half-crown, 20 shillings, and 8 sixpences, the monies of
Philip Hitchman
, from his person .

PHILIP HITCHMAN
. I am a labourer , and live at Wantage, Berks. I was coming to town, and met the prisoner at Old Brentford - I had 33s. in my pocket; I went to two public-houses with her, and had two pints of cyder and one pint of beer - the second was the Running Horse, - my money was in a brown cloth bag in my pocket; I took it out there, and put it into my left-hand breeches pocket - I then went down a lane there, and while something was happening, I found her hand in my pocket; she then went off, and joined three men - I followed her to the Running Horse again, and accused her of taking my money, which I missed; she said she had not had it- a Policeman came, and took her; I had not given her any thing - my purse was safe in the lane, and I missed it directly she left.

Cross-examined by MR. CHURCHILL. Q.What did you drink at the first house? A. A little gin, and a quartern of peppermint; I was about an hour and a half with her drinking - I had made no bargain with her; I felt her drawing my purse out - I did not tell her I had no money, nor that she might search me.

JOHNSON ORR
. I am a Policeman. I was on duty, and heard something about this - the prosecutor was sober, but much distressed; I saw the prisoner walking down the lane, and heard her tell a man she was accused of taking the money - I went by them, and saw them go to the Running Horse; the prosecutor came up, and went in - he came out, and took me in; I took the prisoner, and found one new shilling on her only - this was about ten minutes after I had seen her.
Cross-examined. Q. There was time to escape then? A. Not after I took her - she came to the door and said she would send for a Policeman to search her.

Prisoner's Defence. I never left him till I returned to the public house - as I came back I met several young men, and told them the charge he made; he said if I would give him 6d. or 1s., he would say no more about it.

GUILTY . Aged 24. -
Confined Six Months .

1459.
ANN PARKS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of June , 1 shawl, value 8s. , the goods of
Ellen Neale
.

ELLEN NEALE. I am a widow , and lodge in Red Lion-court, Saffron-hill
. The prisoner lodged with me - I left her in care of my room on the 25th of June; in aboutthree quarters of an hour, and while I was outside I saw her go out - I went back, and missed my shawl; I saw her the same day, and asked her for it - she denied it, and I gave charge of her; she is willing to work, but is in distress.
WILLIAM HILL. I am shopman to Mr. Beacham, a pawnbroker, at Holborn-bars. I have a shawl, pawned on the 25th of June, and I believe, by the prisoner.

JOHN ROBINSON
. I am a Policeman. I took the prisoner, and found this duplicate of the shawl in her shoe.
WILLIAM HILL. This is the duplicate I gave for it.(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoner pleaded distress.

GUILTY . Aged 32. -
Confined Seven Days .

1460.
WILLIAM PHILIPS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of June , 1 handkerchief, value 2s., the goods of
William Lloyd
, from his person .

JOHN PENNY
. I am a gun-polisher, and live in Leicester-street, Regent-street. On the 25th of June, about three o'clock in the afternoon, I was in New Bridge-street
- I saw the prisoner put his hand into the prosecutor's left-hand coat pocket, and take out a silk handkerchief, which he put into his own right-hand trousers pocket; I turned round, saw the officer take him, and take the handkerchief from his pocket.

THOMAS FARRANT
. I am a Policeman. I took the prisoner, and took the handkerchief from his pocket - I saw him take it.

WILLIAM LLOYD
. This is my handkerchief.
Prisoner. I leave myself to the mercy of the Court.

GUILTY . Aged 18. -
Confined Three Months .

1461.
JAMES NIGHTINGALE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of May , 1 gown, value 8s.; 1 petticoat, value 1s.; 2 shifts, value 2s., and 1 apron, value 6d., the goods of
Varden Wood Harrop
, from the person of
George Harrop
.

GEORGE HARROP
. I received a bundle from my mother on the 21st of May, to take to Fetter-lane; the prisoner overtook me in Oxford-street, and asked me to take a note to Bedford-square for him - I said I was going down Oxford-street; he said it was only just round the corner, in Tottenham-court-road, and he would give me 2d. to take it - that it was to fetch a bundle to wash for his mother, whose name was Sheppard; he asked if I knew any body about where I could leave my bundle with, or, if I did not mind, he would hold it for me; we went into Bedford-square together - I gave him the bundle, and he gave me the note; I went down the area, and asked for Mrs. Thompson, who the note was directed for; there was no such person - I came up, and he was gone with the bundle; I saw him in Tottenham-court-road on the Tuesday following - I followed him to Oxford-street, and had him taken.

MARY HARROP. I am the wife of
Varden Wood Harrop
- we live at Chelsea. I gave my son the bundle, containing these articles.

THOMAS PETO
. I am a pawnbroker. On the 21st of May, about half-past two o'clock, the prisoner pawned all these articles with me.(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoner pleaded distress, and received an excellent character.

GEORGE HARROP
. It was only a piece of paper that he gave me - it was not directed; he told me it was for Mrs. Thompson - he took it from his pocket.
GUILTY . Aged 17.

Strongly recommended to Mercy. -
Confined 14 Days .

1462.
ANN McCARTHY
,
ELLEN DAVIS
, and
MARY ANN HAYS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of June , 16 yards of printed cotton, value 5s. , the goods of
John Brown
.

ELIZABETH KING
. I am the wife of
Samuel King
, a tailor, in New Gravel-lane. On the 24th of June I was at the corner of Twine-court
, and saw Davis take a piece of cotton off a hook at Mr. Brown's shop - she dropped it directly, took it up again, put it under her petticoat, and came up the court with it; the other two prisoners had crossed the way to her before she took it, and stood before her while she took it down - they were rather between her and the shop, but close together; she put her arm over their shoulders - I had not seen them in conversation; she went up the court - they crossed directly, and went towards New Gravel-lane together; they had all three been standing about before - when she dropped the cotton, McCarthy said, "D - n your eyes, it is all right, run off;" they were altogether - I went and informed Mr. Brown: I saw them in custody next morning in the watch-house - there were seven or eight persons altogether, and when I went in, before I could say any thing, McCarthy said, "We are done;" I then told the officer what had occurred, and McCarthy replied that she would break my nose if she could catch me - as they were going into the Police van, Hays said she hoped I would not say more against her than I had.

JAMES MORGAN
. I am a Policeman. On the 24th of June, about one o'clock in the morning, I went to a house in Twine-court, kept by Hays - I have seen her there repeatedly; I saw a light there - I knocked at the door, and they put the light out - I knocked repeatedly; they said,"Who is there?" I said, "Tom;" they said, "What Tom?" I said, "Oh, you know me very well, open the door;" I then said I was one of the Police, but they would not open it - I said if they did not I should use force, and in about ten minutes it was opened; I did not find either of the prisoners there - I took King to the station, and before she spoke I heard McCarthy say, "We are done;" I heard Hays say something about taking King's life.

ARTHUR DEBENHAM
. I am an apprentice to John Brown, a linen-draper, at Shadwell, at the corner of Twine-court. King gave me information - I went out, and missed sixteen yards of print off the book of the blind.
Davis' Defence. I was never in the prisoners' company.

McCARTHY -
GUILTY . Aged 19.

DAVIS
GUILTY , Aged 19.

HAYS -
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Transported for Seven Years .

1463.
SARAH MYERS
was indicted for
stealing, onthe 24th of June , 2 pillows, value 5s., and 1 sheet, value 3s. , the goods of
James Cropper
.

JAMES CROPPER
. I live in Great Peter-street, Westminster
, and am a coal-dealer . The prisoner hired a furnished room in my house on the 20th; she was alone, but a man afterwards came as her husband - I knew him before; on the 24th I set a boy to watch, and from information I went to the Angel, Broadway, with an officer, and found the prisoner there - I found a pillow at Mrs. Ravener's shop.

WILLIAM CROPPER
. I watched the prisoner, and saw her go to Ravener's, a pawnbroker, in the Almonry, with a pillow in a blue cloth; she came out without it.

JAMES CLARKE
. I am a Policeman. I searched the prisoner, and found the duplicate of the pillow on her - Ravener gave it up.

THOMAS COX
. I live with Mr. Ravener. The prisoner pawned the pillow; I gave it up.
Prisoner. My husband left me; distress and want led me to it.
GUILTY . Aged 23.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Confined Ten Days .

1464.
THOMAS MUMFORD
and
JOHN HEMSON
were indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of May , 1 handkerchief, value 2s. 6d., the goods of
Matthew Day
, from her person .

WILLIAM ARNEY
. I am a Policeman. On the 28th of May, at eleven o'clock at night, I was in Piccadilly, near the Haymarket
, and saw the prisoners in company; I had followed them from Regent-street - there was a considerable crowd, on account of the illumination; I saw Mumford put his hand into Mr. Day's pocket, and keep it there a considerable time - a coach then came up, which forced the people to go close; he then took his hand out with this handkerchief - I took hold of him; Hemson did nothing but stand by - he must have seen this done.
MATTHEW DAY. This is my handkerchief; when my attention was called to it, I missed it.
Mumford received a good character.

MUMFORD -
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Confined Three Months .

HEMSON -
NOT GUILTY .
OLD COURT. THURSDAY, JULY 7.
First Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin .

1465.
HENRY SALMON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of June , 1 watch, value 2l. , the goods of
James Brookman
.

WILLIAM SMITH
. I am servant to James Brookman, an upholsterer , at Islington
. On the 17th of June the prisoner came from Mr. Owen, a polisher, and was at work in our front shop for about two hours; this watch hung under the mantel-piece in that shop - it was missed about half an hour after he left; he had been alone in the shop.

WILLIAM SHEEHY
. I am a Policeman. I was on duty in Liquorpond-street on the 25th of June - the prisoner came and said, "Policeman, I am waiting for you;" I said, "What for?" he said, "I want to give myself up to you;" I said, "What for?" he said, "I have taken a watch and hat from Mr. Owen, of Liquorpond-street;" I took him to the watch-house - he said he had pawned the watch at Fleming's, Fleet-market.

WILLIAM CLARK
. I am shopman to Mr. Fleming. I have a watch, pawned on the 17th of June, in the name of
Henry Bennett
- I do not know who by.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 19. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1466.
THOMAS McNAMARA
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of May , 1 cash-box, value 12s. , the goods of
James Boyd
, the elder, and
James Boyd
, the younger, his masters.

ALEXANDER BOYD
. I am journeyman to
James Boyd
and James Boyd, Jun., who are furnishing-ironmongers
, and live in Wellbeck-street
. The prisoner had been nearly two years in their employ, as a labourer - we did not miss this box till a pawnbroker brought it to us; it was kept in the shop.

WILLIAM GOFTON
. I am a pawnbroker, and live in Gilbert-street, Grosvenor-square. On the evening of the 21st of May the prisoner came to pawn this box; I asked how he became possessed of it - he said he was the manufacturer; he seemed confused - I saw a paper sticking out of his pocket, which I took out, and found a shop-mark on it; I took him into custody; he then said he hoped I would not give him in charge, and acknowledged stealing it from his masters.

GUILTY . Aged 18. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1467.
ROBERT CLARK
and
THOMAS WOODRUFT
were indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of May , 24 yards of printed cotton, value 10s. , the goods of
James Veitch
.

JOHN THOMAS
. I am a Police-constable. On the 16th of May, about a quarter-past twelve o'clock, I saw the prisoners in company in Ratcliff-highway - I watched, and saw them near the shop of Mr. Brown, a linen-draper; Clark stood on the pavement, with his face towards me -Woodruft had his back towards me, and his face to the shop, handling some prints in front of the window; they took nothing - they then went to two other linen-drapers, and handled prints at both of them; I at last followed them to Mr. Veitch's - a coach stood there, and I did not see them take any thing; they walked to and fro till two o'clock, and every time they came from the shop they had each an apron tied up round their middle, and as they came back their aprons were down - I at last saw Hennessey with Clark; I ran up to his assistance, and saw the property in his hands - Woodruft ran away; I know he is the same man - I had watched him for an hour and a quarter.

MICHAEL HENNESSEY
. I am an officer. I was on duty, and saw the prisoners in company; I understood Thomas had been watching them - I observed Clark's apron up and bulky; they were together then - I seized him with this property in his apron: he struggled, and dropped it -Thomas came to my aid.

JAMES PORTCH
. I am an officer. I was on duty in Cannon-street; my brother officer collared Clark, and pointed out Woodruft to me - I ran and took him.
Woodruft. Q. Had you seen me before? A. Not till you was pointed out, by the gates of St. George's church.

JONAH JONES
. I am shopman to
James Veitch
, a linendraper . This print is my master's, and measures twentyfour yards.
Clark's Defence. I was looking for work - I saw this print on the ground, and the Policeman stopped me.
Woodruft's Defence. I was in company with nobody, and had never seen Clark.

CLARK -
GUILTY . Aged 22.

WOODRUFT -
GUILTY . Aged 26.
Transported for Seven Years .

1468.
THOMAS EDMONDS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 22nd of June , 1 silver spoon, value 5s. , the goods of
Elizabeth Sewell
.

ELIZABETH SEWELL. I keep a pawnbroker's-shop , in Gray's Inn-lane
- I knew the prisoner as a customer. On the morning of the 22nd of June he came and bought plates and other things, which came to 10d.; about ten minutes after he was gone I missed a spoon - he drives a cab about.

RICHARD BAYLIS
. I am a Policeman. I took the prisoner at his lodgings, in Canterbury-square, on the 22nd of June, and found the spoon there.

GUILTY . Aged 26. -
Confined Six Weeks .

1469.
THOMAS SIMPTON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of June , 2 handkerchiefs, value 6s.; 1 shirt, value 3s., and 1 pair of stockings, value 18d. , the goods of
Thomas Marsh
.

THOMAS MARSH
. I live in Edward-street, Hampstead road
. The prisoner is a labourer , and lodged in our house for about a month - I missed these things from the bedroom, and spoke to him; he denied taking them - I insisted on it that he had them - I found a pair of my stockings on his feet, and the duplicates of my sheet and handkerchiefs were found on him - I never allowed him to pawn them.

JAMES HOPPER
. I am a pawnbroker, and live in Grafton-street. I have a handkerchief, pawned on the 2nd of May.

EDWARD HALL
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a handkerchief, pawned by the prisoner.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I was in Seymour-street, and a young man asked me to pawn them for him - when I came out of the shop he was gone.

GUILTY . Aged 18.
Whipped and Discharged.

1470.
ANN SILVER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of May , 3 half-crowns, 2 shillings, 3 pennies, and 1 farthing, the monies of
John Casement
, from his person .

JOHN CASEMENT
. I work at a nursery at Kensington. On Saturday night, the 29th of May, I went out to see a friend, and met the prisoner in York-street, Westminster
; she put her arms round me, and said, "Will you take me with you?" I said No - she put her arm round me, and in an instant I felt her hand in my pocket, where I had three half-crowns, two shillings, and 3d., and took it out; I had been drinking, but had my senses - I accused her of taking my money: she denied it - I gave her in charge directly, as a Policeman came by; he asked her what money she had about her, and I am sure she said she had none - he found my money on her.

RICHARD NEWLAND
. I am a Policeman. The prosecutor charged the prisoner with robbing him - she said, so help her God, she had not a farthing about her, and I might search her; she pulled her pocket inside out - I then observed her hands clenched; I opened her left hand, and found three half-crowns, and in her right hand 2s. 3 1/2 d.

GUILTY . Aged 25. -
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1471.
SUSAN FENTON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of May , 3 pairs of stockings, value 2s.; 2 books, value 3s.; 1 apron, value 6d.; 1 pocket, value 4d., and 1 handkerchief, value 2d. , the goods of
Maria Waxham
.

MARIA WAXHAM
. I am a servant out of place, and was lodging in White Horse-alley
.; I left there the beginning of March, and left my box there, locked - I went to Islington, for the benefit of the air; the prisoner did not lodge there then - I came home the beginning of May, and on unlocking my box I found the bottom of it broken out- I suspected the prisoner, who was then lodging there, and spoke to her about it; she denied it - I found a pocket handkerchief and an apron under her bed; she had been lodging about three weeks in the room my box was in - I showed her the things; she said she knew nothing of them but that one day, when she wanted a clean pocket, she took mine - she was out of a situation.

JOHN BALL
. I am a pawnbroker, of Smithfield-bars. I have three pairs of stockings, pawned by the prisoner, in the name of
Mary Ransom
.

JAMES TERRY
. I am an officer. I apprehended the prisoner, and have a petticoat, apron, and handkerchief, given to me by the prosecutrix; the prisoner said she took the pocket when she wanted a clean one, but how the other things got there she did not know - at the next examination she said the books were at a pawnbroker's on Snowhill.

WILLIAM TRANAH
. I live with Mr. Reeves, of Snowhill. I have two books, pawned in the name of
Ann Harrison
, Cow-lane - I do not know who by.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner. The officer said if I would confess, I should not be prosecuted.

JAMES TERRY
. It is false.

GUILTY . Aged 19. -
Confined Six Weeks .

1472.
SARAH ROSE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of June , 3 yards of flannel, value 2s.; 1 handkerchief, value 6d.; 5 yards of lace. value 10s.; 1 pair of gloves, value 1s.; 6 pieces of net, value 3s., and 2 towels, value 1s. , the goods of
James Wilson
, her master.

ANN HOPPER
. I live with my brother-in-law,
James Wilson
; the prisoner was about a month in his service; we had no other servant . I missed some articles of my own- my brother called in an officer, who searched her box, and found these articles in it; it was not locked - we did not tell her we were going to search before the officer came.

DANIEL McGILLIN
. I am an officer. I was called in; Mr. Wilson told me to search the prisoner's box, which was up stairs, unlocked - I found all this property in it; Miss Hopper claimed them - the prisoner said they were her own, and not her master's.

JOSEPH BARDEN
. On Saturday, the 11th, while the prisoner was in the watch-house, she told me she bought part of the property at a linen-drapers at Shadwell, and took me to the shop - the person denied having had such things.(Property produced and sworn to)

Prisoner to ANN HOPPER. Q.Did you not miss a great many things before I came to the house? A. No; the towels were there when you came - the towels were found in her basket; she has made them into aprons.

GUILTY . Aged 21. -
Transported for Seven Years .
There was another indictment against the prisoner.

1473.
THOMAS ROACH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of May , 1 jacket, value 5s., and 1 pair of stockings, value 1s. , the goods of
Henry Hart
.

HENRY SOUTHAM
. I am a shopman to
Henry Hart
, who keeps a clothes-shop . On the 14th of May the prisoner and a man, who called himself his father, came to the shop - I had seen the prisoner on board ship before; they asked Hart to trust them with a pair of shoes and stockings- he took down the father's address, and during that time the prisoner went away with the stockings and shoes; I then missed a jacket and another pair of stockings, which were not sold - the prisoner came back; I said, "You have stolen a jacket;" he said he had not - I afterwards found the prisoner at the station-house.

EDWARD STERN
. I am a shopman to Mr. Hart. I stood at the door, and after he had served the prisoner I saw him - go out with the jacket under his arm, but did not know it was stolen - he returned in ten minutes; I said,"Why did you not bring the jacket back which I saw under your arm?" he denied it - I said, "Who did you give the shoes and stockings to?" he said, to his brother; I found his brother with the jacket.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY. Aged 19. -
Judgment Respited
.
Before Mr. Recorder.

1474.
MARY DIXON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of June , 1 shawl, value 3s. , the goods of
Thomas Nichols
.

JOSEPH HUETSON
. I am in the employ of Thomas Nichols, a pawnbroker , in Gray's-Inn lane
. A person passing alarmed me, and I missed this shawl from the door, which I had seen safe a quarter of an hour before, pinned strongly up - I went out and found the prisoner with it folded in her apron, about twenty yards off; she said she was sorry for it.
BENJAMIN PHILLIPS. I am a Policeman. I saw Huetson stop the prisoner and take the shawl from her apron - she said distress had caused her to do it.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY Aged 48.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Confined Two days .

1475.
JOSEPH PERKINS
was indicted for
stealing on the 18th of May , 1 coat, value 2l.; 1 bag, value 1s., and 1 handkerchief, value 2d. , the goods of
George Whitworth
; and that he had been previously convicted of felony.

GEORGE WHITWORTH
. I work at a stable in Clarencegardens, Regent's-park
; I lodge on the second floor there. I have worked with the prisoner once or twice, at groundwork - he knew where I lived; I was out of employ, and went to Epsom Races on Monday, leaving my coat and things at my lodging, in care of my wife - I returned on the Friday night, and they were gone; I never sent the prisoner for them.

ANN ELIZABETH WHITWORTH
. I am the prosecutor's wife. He went to Epsom; the prisoner came on the Wednesday morning and told me he came from my husband, who had sent him for his coat, as he had come to town for some horses, that he had to go further, and would call again in the afternoon - he came in the afternoon, and asked me if the coat was ready; I fetched it down, and gave it to him in a bag - the handkerchief was in the pocket.

ROBERT DIXON
. I am a Policeman. On the 18th of May the prosecutor gave the prisoner into my charge, for stealing a coat, handkerchief, and bag - he said he knew nothing about it, and in about two hours he said he had sold the coat for 6s., and it was gone far enough away; he said next morning that he had pawned it at the corner of East-street, Manchester-square - I found it there.

JAMES MOODY
. I am a servant to
James Ross
, a pawnbroker. I took this coat in pawn from the prisoner, for 8s., on the 18th or 19th of May; and on the 21st he brought a man to buy it - a few hours after a second and third came to look at it - I have had it ever since; the handkerchief was pawned with it.
JURY. Q.Did you ever see him before? A. Never; he said he had been to the races, and wanted some money to take him back.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner. If I had not been in liquor I should not have done it.
THOMAS FERGUSSON. I know the prisoner. I saw him tried here in October, 1827 - he was found guilty.

RICHARD HARTLY WALL
. I am an officer. I have got a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, from Mr. Clarke's office. - (read.)

GUILTY . Aged 35. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1476.
EDWARD FITZGERALD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 22nd of May , 1 blanket, value 3s., and 1 sheet, value 2s. , the goods of
James Power
.

MARGARET POWER
. I am the wife of
James Power
.
