The prisoner lodged in our first floor back-room, with his two children; he came as a widower , and worked as a plasterer - he was there about nineteen months, and owed me nearly 7l.; he was out of work a long time - on the 22nd of May I asked him for some rent, as he was in work; he said I could have none that day - I said I thought my things were not all right, and while I was examining, he went out; his children followed - I missed a blanket and sheet; I never allowed him to pawn them.

JOSEPH HUETSON
. I am a pawnbroker. On the 9th of May the prisoner pawned this sheet for 1s.; I knew him before - the blanket was pawned at our other shop, but we cannot find it; we believe it has been redeemed.

DANIEL HUMPHREYS
. I am a Policeman. I took the prisoner; he said he had burnt the duplicates of the blanket and sheet - I found ten duplicates on him; one of them related to the sheet.
The prisoner pleaded poverty.
GUILTY. Aged 45.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Judgment-Respited
.

1477.
RICHARD PRINGLE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of May , 1 hat, value 5s. , the goods of
Robert Bushell
.

ROBERT BUSHELL. I am a hatter , and live in Shoreditch
. I lost this hat on the 26th of May, while I was out; it was on a peg outside the door.

SARAH BULL
. I live in Mile-end-road; my husband is a seaman. I was in Shoreditch between five and six o'clock in the evening, on the 26th of May, and saw the prisoner there - I saw a hand take a hat off the prosecutor's nail, and immediately after saw it in the prisoner's hand - I ran after him, overtook him in Old-street-road, and took it off his head; a Policeman came and took him.

RICHARD HUNT
. I am a Police-officer. I came up, and saw Bull take the hat off the prisoner's head - Bell took him in charge; he gave no account of it.

LEWIS BELL
. I am a Policeman. I took the prisoner to the shop, where the hat was claimed - there was a cap and black handkerchief in it.

ELIZABETH BUSHELL
. I am the prosecutor's wife. The prisoner was brought in with the hat.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 24. -
Confined Two Months .

1478.
WILLIAM PEARSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of June , 1 musical snuff-box, value 3l. , the goods of
Susannah Morgan
.

THOMAS FURNESS
. I live in Taylor's-row, St. John-street-road
. The prisoner came to my lodging on the 6th of June, between nine and ten o'clock in the morning- I had known him some time; he stopped till about a quarter-past one, and at half-past I missed a musical snuffbox, which I had to repair for Susannah Morgan; it was in my second-floor back-room, which is a workshop - he was in that room most of the time; it was at the end of the work-bench - I saw it safe about twelve o'clock, and nobody called after that; I had him taken at his lodging in Windmill-street, Haymarket.
Prisoner. Q. Did not you suspect another person? A. No.

PETER DIXON
. I am shopman to Mr. Howes, a pawnbroker. This musical-box was pawned on the 6th of June, between one and two o'clock, by the prisoner, for 2l.; I am quite certain of his person - it was claimed next morning.

WILLIAM BENNETT
. I am a Policeman. I took him into custody.
The prisoner put in a written defence, stating that distress had driven him to take the box, and that he had given the prosecutor 10s. towards his loss, which he afterwards returned him.

THOMAS FURNESS
. I knew him to be poor, but considered him honest; he offered me 10s. to compromise it which I refused.

GUILTY . Aged 24. -
Confined Three Months .
Second London Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

1479.
WILLIAM HAYLEY
was indicted for
a fraud .
MESSRS. ADOLPHUS and BODKIN conducted the prosecution.

JOHN CHANNON
. I was secretary to the Potosi La Paz, and Peruvian Mining Association, which was established in London. I have not belonged to it this four years - the object of the Association was to work mines in Peru; the capital was divided into shares, which were bought and sold in the money-market - this paper (looking at it) is a genuine share; there were printed receipts for the scrip, but this is the instrument on which divedends would be payable.

Cross-examined by MR. ALLEY. Q.You have neither Charter nor Act of Parliament to authorize your proceedings? A. No; the Association may consist of one thousand persons or two thousand for what I know; the office is in Great Winchester-street - the Association is governed by twelve directors, self-elected, and the money was paid to the bankers on account of the directors; the amount collected was 60,000l., as near as I can recollect - I do not think it was 100,000l.; I should say between 70,000l. and 80,000l. - the sums were subscribed in 1825; no dividend has been paid - there is no money remaining at the bankers', that I am aware of; there are deeds - I do not know where they are, as I am not now connected with the Association; I believe the shares are still circulating on the Stock Exchange - the mines are at Potosi, I understand; there was no deed of Association.

MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. Was it ever given out that there was a Charter or Act of Parliament establishing the Company? A. Never; great expence was incurred in sending out vessels - the money was entirely spent in the necessary expences of the Company; share-holders would certainly not be benefitted by fictitious shares in the market.

SAMUEL HILL
. I am a member of the Stock Exchange- I believe the defendant is also a member; I have known him transacting business there for five or six years - I knew him transact business in the shares of public companies; I have bought and sold shares in the Potosi La Paz and Peruvian Mining Association - they were the subject of bargain and sale in the market in May last. On the 7th of May I received from the defendant fourteen parchment instruments, constituting fifty shares in that Association - four represented ten shares, and ten one each; I gave 10s. per share for them, and paid him a cheque drawn on Sir
James Lubbock
and Co. by
James Flynn
, for 1l. 10s., and four sovereigns and another cheque of Jones, Loyd, and Co., my own bankers, for 19l. 10s.; here is is one of the parchment instruments I received - it is No. 3126; here is a figure of 10 on it, which I think is my own writing - it forms no part of the instrument; I have also written on it, "Hayley, for Costello."

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Are you the prosecutor of this indictment? A. It is not carried on at my expence - I do not know at whose expence it is done; I have heard that it is at the expence of Mr. Measam: time bargains have been done with these shares, but not on the Stock Exchange now - they were some time back; that is buying and selling a given number of shares to be taken at a stipulated future day - I am not aware of more being agreed for than can be delivered, because many bargains are almost immediately closed again, and the differences are paid; this may be called partly gambling.

Q. On the day you agreed with Mr. Hayley for these shares, were you not obliged to wait some time till he could get them from other persons? A. I waited some time for him to produce them, but not long enough to constitute a time bargain - I should think any thing beyond a day would be a time bargain, but if they are delivered the day the bargain is made, I think it is a ready money transaction - time bargains are sales made foran account day; I agreed with a Mr. Costello for the shares - he referred me to Hayley, who was to produce a portion of them; they were delivered about four o'clock on the day I agreed for them - I swear that positively; it was a regular money transaction; I stated this at the Mansion-house - what I said was taken down; my deposition was read over to me, but all I said was not taken down.

MR. ADOLPHUS. Q.Has Mr. Measam any fabricated shares in his possession? A. I have not seen any - this transaction was not a time bargain; the money was paid the same day; when I received the shares I received them as bona fide shares - I produced the cheque on Messrs. Jones and Loyd, which I paid him.

MR. EMANUEL LOUSADA. I am a merchant, and one of the directors of the Potosi La Paz and Peruvian Mining Association. (Looking at the document) my name, which is signed here, is not my handwriting; it has been put there without my knowledge or permission - the shares are signed by three directors, and countersigned by the secretary; no other can be genuine - J. B. Lousada is my first cousin and brother-in-law; I know his hand-writing perfectly well - this is not his signature; he was a director at the time

JOHN CHANNON
. Mr. C. A. Thesselton was a director - I know his hand-writing, and do not believe this to be his signature; the name, "John Channon," is not my signature.

JOHN WEBSDALE PEEL
. I am a letter-press and copperplate printer, and live in the New-cut, Lambeth. I have known the defendant about two years; when I first knew him he gave the name of Smith. In March last, when I came home one day, I found him at my house - my young man had taken an order from him, and entered it in the name of Spicer and Co. - the prisoner then ordered me to engrave a plate like a copy which he had got - (looking at a share) it was as near like this as the engraver could do it; he said the former plate was lost, that Mr. Ellis, the engraver, had offended the gentlemen, and there would be a great many other things to be done - I was to engrave this as quick as I could; it had the name of Ellis, as the engraver, and was dated 1827 - I said it was copper-plate; he said Yes, but the plate was lost, and I was to do another; I got one engraved - a proof was thrown off, which I showed to him on paper at my house; he ordered one hundred to be engraved on parchment - I gave the plate, the whole hundred engravings, and the original they were copied from, all over to the defendant - I was paid 7l. for my trouble; I gave a receipt for the money, in the name of Spicer and Co., and delivered it to the defendant, as my young man entered the work to be done in that name - he made not the least objection to the receipt being in that name - (looking at nineteen impressions) I have no doubt these are all impressed from the same plate.

Cross-examined by MR. ALLEY. Q. Have you been a speculator in these shares at all? A. No; I never saw Mr. Measam till about May, nor did my wife, to my knowledge - I was taken into custody about these plates; it was then I saw Mr. Measam - I was in custody four or five days till I could find the defendant; I was not in prison, but in a lock-up house at night, and went out with the officer in the day-time to find him - I was never in prison in my life; I was at the office about disposing of indecent prints, and paid the 20l. penalty for it - one of my apprentices was a witness against me; I have not been in trouble about any thing else - I go to Ascot races; you may have seen me there - I kept a "une deux cinq table;" I never said Mr. Measam employed me to engrave these shares -Barker, who superintends my business when I am out, was present when the defendant came; I did not say, at Unionhall, that nobody was present - he had spoken to Barber, but when I came in and took the business Barber left, and was at a little distance in the office when I took the order.

Q. In the same room? No, the office is divided - there are two rooms, the press and composing-rooms; he left me with Mr. Hayley - he might have heard our conversation if he had paid attention to it; I do not know whether he did; he might have heard part of it - my wife was at home - she works in the business, and saw the defendant; I believe she was in the kitchen - she was about the premises; I cannot say whether she was in the office or not, but she saw him - she was backwards and forwards; he was dressed in a very dark olive or black surtout coat, and wore glasses - I do not know any thing about Mr. Measam.

MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. I think I prosecuted you about the papers? A. Yes; I never saw Measam till he took me into custody in May; I never did any work for him - all the while I was in custody I was about with the officer, by direction of the Magistrate, looking for the defendant, and my wife went about at different periods; the defendant pointed out Ellis' name to me on the engraving.
JURY. Q. Are you certain the defendant is the man? A. Certainly - he did not tell me where he lived.
COURT. Q. When did you first know the defendant by the name of Hayley? A. The day he was taken he gave that name - Mr. Measam called him Hayley when he took him; I never knew him by that name before.

CHARLES FREDERICK BARBER. I am journeyman to Mr. Peel. I first saw the defendant in March last - he came to the office to have a plate engraved for the Potosi Association; Mr. Peel was not at home when he came in- he showed me a copy on parchment, similar to this(looking at one); I declined giving him an estimate of the price till Mr. Peel came in, as I did not know the price of engraving - I asked if he would leave his name; he gave me Spicer and Co.; our office is in the back premises below, and as I was shewing him up stairs, I met master - the conversation between them was not exactly in my hearing, for the office where we work has a deal of bustle in it; I did not bear what passed - I saw him leave in about ten minutes; as far as I can recollect, he wore a frock coat, and wore glasses - I saw him again four or five days after, when he came to our house to see a proof of the plate; I was not present when it was shown to him, nor did he say any thing to me about it - I know the engraving had been done then; I saw him again on the Saturday in the same week, when he came to fetch them away - I think it was the same day as he saw the proof; he took away the impressions, which were on parchment, the plate, and the copy it was engraved from - I did not see him pay any thing, and did not see him again till he was apprehended; I am quite sure he is the person.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q.Can you give us the day of the week that he first came? A. No - I know it was Saturday that he saw the proof, as there was a chimney on fire opposite; I cannot say which house - I have no other reason - it was about four or five o'clock; I have lived with Peel about nine months - I did not notice the colour of the defendant's glasses; he had a dark coat, inclining to brown - I know his features, but did not examine him all over; I cannot say what cravat he wore - there were two more men at work in the office, about four yards from master, but you cannot hear while the press is going what persons in the counting-house are talking of, unless you chose to be inquisitive and listen; I cannot say how long these men had been in master's employ, nor recollect their names - they merely came to work a job off; there is a small partition to the counting-house, but still they might see the defendant - he did not pass them to go out; I did not ask the defendant where he lived, but it was asked, because I was desired to put down Stangate - I have the book here: I asked Mr. Peel if he had left his address - he said Stangate; master said he had told him where he lived - if he has said he did not ask him, he must have said an untruth to me, or to the gentleman who asked him, if he did: Mrs. Peel was going backwards and forwards in the office - I cannot say how near she was to him; she passed him, I believe - as far as I can recollect this was in the morning; it might be ten o'clock, or it might be three - the order was given and executed in March, but I cannot tell the day of the month.

MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. Were the two men in the office at press or composing? A.They were at press that day; it makes a great noise, and engages their attention - the counting-house is separated by a partition: the men were not in our constant employ - I saw the defendant at Unionhall, and had a doubt of him till I heard him speak, on account of his not having spectacles, but had not the least doubt then, and have none now.

SOPHIA PEEL
. I am the wife of Mr. Peel. I saw the defendant at our house in March last, several times in in that month, and I had seen him about two years ago - he then left us the name of Smith; we then lived further up, in the same street - he came to have some printing done; I did not see him again till last March, and recognized him as the person I had seen - he came to know if my husband could engrave a plate for him, and brought a proof with him; Mr. Peel not being at home, he asked Barber if Mr. Peel could engrave a plate like that copy; he told him Yes - I saw the copy he produced; it was like this and printed on parchment - Mr. Peel met him as he was going out, in the passage; I afterwards saw him when he came to see a proof of the plate - I told him it was not ready then, and he was to come on Saturday; I know that he came on Saturday, and waited a quarter of an hour till Mr. Peel came in - I sent our lad for the proof; I took the proof from the lad who brought it, and Mr. Peel came in - I gave it to him, and he showed it to the defendant; I saw him when he came the same night and took them away - I put them up in the kitchen, and just as Mr. Peel came to the door the defendant came in and had them; my husband was taken to Union-hall on this charge, and detained six days - while he was detained I went out, by direction of the Magistrate, with Pople, the officer, to find the defendant; I went to the 'Change, and several places - I at last stationed myself on Londonbridge, and while there the defendant passed; I pointed him out to Pople, and said I was confident in my mind he was the man, but I would not swear to him till I saw him full in the face - I went up, and spoke to him; directly he saw me he put his handkerchief up to his face - I asked if his name was Thompson, or Thomas - I hardly know which, I was in such a state of agitation; it was the first name that came to my mind - he told me that was not his name; I said my name was Peel, and asked if he did not know me - he said No, he did not, he had no knowledge of me whatever; I said I was confident he did know me, for Mr. Peel had done some work for him - he said No, he did not know me, but when he first saw me he thought me very much like a servant that lived with him; I left him, and went to speak to Pople - I told him I had not had a sufficient view of his countenance, but we would watch him, see where he went to, and Mr. Peel should come and see him; we followed him up Gracechurch-street - he went up and down several courts, and when he got to the corner of Bishopsgate-street he looked round to see if I was following him; he had looked round several times before, and not wishing him to see me I went into a shop; when I came out both him and Pople were gone- I saw him before the Magistrate the same afternoon; I am confident he is the person, for I answered the door every time to him.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. You answered the door the first time, and all? A. Yes - I think it was three times; it was not to me he spoke about the engraving - he asked me if Mr. Peel was at home; I asked him down to Barber - I cannot tell the date on which he first came; I rather think it was the beginning of March, and I think between three and four o'clock - we had dined; Barber dines with us - I think we had dined, but I do not recollect such a trifling circumstance; as near as I can recollect we had dined - I am confident he did not come so early as one o'clock; the apprentice was in the office, and so was I part of the time - I cannot say how long I staid; there was nobody else in the lower office -Barber was at work; I do not remember whether the presses were going - I paid no attention to the conversation between my husband and the defendant; I was in the office in which the presses were - my husband and Hayley were in a small place, a sort of counting-house; it is not a regular counting-house, but only some boards placed across - it is one room; I do not think any body else was at work in the office.

Q. How came you to call the defendant Thomas? A. I had asked the officer what I should do to see his face, but he kept his handkerchief up over his nose and mouth all the time - I do not think any body was at work at the presses when he was there, but I am in and out so many times I do not take notice; sometimes we are busy. and take extra men - my husband was once taken to Unionhall through a person informing against him; his apprentice's indentures were cancelled - I was never taken up; - yes, I was, at Union-hall.

MR. BODKIN. Q. Do you mean that an officer took you into custody, or were you desired by any writing to go to Union-hall? A. I never was taken up by an officerany where; a man had come into the house after this trouble of Mr. Peel's, and insulted me - he struck me, and I slapped his face, because he used improper language to me; that was the subject I went there about - I was never in custody; one of our presses makes a great noise when it is at work.

COURT. Q. You speak of the office and counting-house - they are parted off by a board? A. Yes, as high as my shoulder - a piece is cut out, so that you can see who comes into the office; the defendant and Peel were in the counting-house, and I even with them, but not in the counting-house - it is too small to hold three; I cannot say whether Barber was in the counting-house any part of the time.

RICHARD POPLE
. I am an officer of Union-hall. In May last Peel was in my custody, with liberty to go out with me to look for a person supposed to have uttered a forged instrument - Mrs. Peel also accompanied me at times; Peel had described the person to me - I was on London-bridge with Mrs. Peel, when the defendant came in sight; Mrs. Peel was standing some distance from me; she ran to me, and said, "There, I think, is the man; there he goes;" I accompanied her, and followed him to about the centre of the bridge, about a hundred yards, and then she spoke to him - I did not hear what she said; he had a handkerchief holding up to his mouth, and when she spoke to him he kept it a little way off, but still kept it before his face; after she had done talking to him I followed him with her - she requested me not to lose sight of him; he went up Fish-street-hill, through White Hart-court, and several other little courts, in and out, till he came to the Cross Keys coach-yard, and into Gracechurch-street; I had him in sight the whole time - he did not call at any place, but kept looking back; he went quite out of the way - it was a bye way to get round; he looked back several times, and I suspected he saw Mrs. Peel - after he got across Cornhill into Bishopsgate-street he got a little way down, then crossed over the way - Mrs. Peel passed me, and got into a gateway; I saw the defendant go into a hosier's or draper's shop, and come out again at the same door in an instant - I saw no more of Mrs. Peel; I followed the prisoner into the Stock Exchange - the turnings he took were quite out of his way; having nobody to assist me, I went for Peel, brought him over with me, went into a court at the back of the Stock Exchange, and there Peel identified the defendant as the man - he was in the court among other persons, not alone; he said he was the man the moment that he saw him, without any doubt whatever- I took him into custody, and told him I wanted him for forgery - he said he did not understand or know any thing about it; I got into a coach with Peel, him, and two gentlemen.
Cross-examined. Q. How long had Peel been in your custody? A. Four or five days.
MR. ADOLPHUS. Q.Had he been employed in that time looking for the defendant? A.Day and night.

THOMAS CHARLES MEESAM
. I am an agent, and deal occasionally in Mine shares; I have done a great deal in the Potosi shares. I know the defendant; he has dealt very extensively in such shares - I have got into my possession seventeen forged shares, which are here, and more than that; friends whom I have bought for have a great many more - I never saw Peel till he was in Pople's custody; I never ordered him to engrave a plate for me.

Cross-examined by MR. ALLEY. Q. You are the prosecutor of this indictment? A.Certainly; I have never been a member of the Stock Exchange, but have a clerkship in the house, and am privileged to be a member if I like; nothing has been produced from the mines - the money received by the directors has not been accounted for; I consider the shares worth something till that is done- I am not a proprietor; I am not connected with the Puno Mining Association.

Q. Is not your name on this? (handing him a paper.) A. Yes, I can account for that; Puno is in South America- my name is put here by desire of the jobbers; the dealers wished me to sign them, that they might know a good from a bad one.
MR. ALLET addressed the Court on behalf of the defendant, and called

JOHN BERNARD JACOBS
. I am a jobber, and dealer in foreign shares; I live in Bevis-marks. I have known the defendant two or three years - he sold me forty Potosi shares, shortly before the 7th of May; they were to be delivered to me on the 7th of May, and on the 7th of May he bought seventy of me; I have the memorandum, which I took out of the jobbing book; I had to deliver him thirty to balance - I did not deliver them, but told him to take twenty of Mr. Knight, and ten of Mr. Old; he paid Mr. Old for them, I believe; and I had to pay the difference, which was very considerable.

MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. Has the prisoner always been a dealer in mining and speculating shares? A. Yes, very largely - I dare say he has dealt to the amount of thousands of pounds; I have dealt with him for some hundreds - mine was a time bargain; I did not deliver shares to him, but referred him to gentlemen in the market - I believe he had them; I paid him the difference in money - I do not consider it gambling.
COURT. Q. Can you tell the number of any one share that passed from you to Hayley? A. No; many hundred shares pass through our hands in a day - I cannot take the numbers.

GEORGE KNIGHT
. I am a watch-maker, and live at No. 64, Goswell-street. On the 7th of May, by direction of Jacobs, I delivered to the defendant two Potosi shares, each being for ten shares; I cannot say in what year they were dated.

Q. Look at this share? A. We never endorse them - my name is on this; it is not my writing - persons sometimes write on the back the name of the person they buy of; I cannot say whether I sold him this share - I sold him several tens; on the 7th of May some notice was taken about some shares being understood to be had, and I think Hayley applied to me about it; but I know nothing of any bad shares - I gave them as I took them; I said I passed them on in the way I took them, and would not take any back - I never suspected him.
MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. Is "Knight for Jacobs" on this his hand-writing? A. I do not know his writing - we keep books, but never let each other see them.

WILLIAM OLD
. I am a stock-jobber, and live in New North-road. I have known Hayley about three years- (referring to a book) on the 7th of May, I believe, I delivered him ten Potosi shares, for a person named Jacobs; I cannot say how many tickets they were in.

MR. BODKIN. Q.Will you show me the entry? A.You must look at Friday, the 29th of April - the entry is," D. P. Jacobs, 10-15 for next week," which was the 7th of May; they were sold for the following Saturday - D. P. means double Potosi - 10-15s., ten shares at 15s.; there is no other entry to show it was for the 7th of May- next week means the last day of the next week.
COURT. Q. Can you tell us the number of any shares sold to Jacobs? A. No; sometimes ten or fifteen hundred pass through our hands in a week.
RICHARD GRAYDEN. I am a brick-maker, and live at Lambeth. The witness Peel is my brother-in-law; I would not believe him on his oath.
MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. Did he marry your sister, or you his? A. I married his - I do not live with her; I allow her a maintenance; I married her in 1818 - I live with no woman now; a woman lives with me.

COURT. Q.How long have you been on bad terms? A. I have not spoken to him for nearly two years; I do not know where my wife lives - I pay the parish 3s. 6d. a week for her, and I have my six children at home to maintain; I think I heard Peel examined in a Court of Justice on the 30th of June, 1830 - I did not contradict what he swore.

ISAAC LATIMER
. I was apprenticed to Peel - I would not believe him on his oath.
MR. ADOLPHUS. Q.Have you heard him examined in Courts of Justice? A. I have once, at Union-ball, about obscene prints; and once at the Court of Requests, where he recovered a debt.
HENRY SEWELL. I was apprenticed to Peel - I would not believe him on his oath.

MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. Did you serve out your time with him? A. I left him by the Magistrate's order; my indentures were not cancelled - I heard him examined on his oath about an assault, which he charged me with committing on his wife; I was fined 10s.
JURY to J. W. PEEL. Q.Did you engrave the plate? A. No, Mr. Club; the name of Ellis was put on it according to the copy; I took the order, and gave it to Club to engrave.

GUILTY . -
Transported for Seven Years .
NEW COURT. THURSDAY, JULY 7.
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1480.
WILLIAM BAXTER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of June , 2 planes, value 8s.; 2 saws, value 5s.; 9 chisels, value 4s.; 1 square, value 1s.; 1 mallet, value 1s.; 3 brad-awls, value 1s.; 2 guages, value 20d.; 1 rule, value 1s. 6d.; 1 oil-stone, value 3s.; 2 gimblets, value 6d.; 1 bevel, value 9d., and 1 basket, value 5s., the goods of
William Constable
Banks; 2 planes, value 4s.; 1 saw, value 3s.; 5 chisels, value 2s.; 2 gauges, value 1s.; 1 axe, value 1s. 6d.; 1 screw-driver, value 8d.; 1 spoke-shave, value 1s.; 1 oil-stone, value 2s.; 2 gimblets, value 2d.; 1 brad-awl, value 1d., and 1 basket, value 1s. , the goods of
John Hill
; to which he pleaded

GUILTY .
Confined Three Months .

1481.
MARY COLLER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of May , 3 sovereigns, the moneis of
John William Cupit
, from his person ; to which she pleaded

GUILTY .
Transported for Seven Years .

1482.
JOHN MEAKIN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of June , 2 shirts, value 12s. , the goods of
William Terrier
.

WILLIAM TERRIER. I lodge at Boston-place
. The prisoner lodged in the same room; I missed two shirts on the 23rd of June.

GEORGE ADNUM
. I am shopman to a pawnbroker in Upper Park-place; I have a shirt pawned by the prisoner on the 18th of June, in the name of John Williams - he came again on the 21st, and had a fresh advance on it.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. It is my first offence, and I hope you will be merciful.

GUILTY . Aged 29. -
Confined One Month .

1483.
WILLIAM KNIGHT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of June , 2 shillings, and 4 sixpences , the monies of
Eliza Wilkins
.

ELIZA WILKINS. I keep a shop in Arthur-street, Chelsea
. The prisoner came there with another man on the 27th of June - they had some beer, and then asked for some tobacco - the other man asked for a light; I went up stairs, and while there I heard footsteps - I came down; the prisoner and his companion were then gone - I looked in the bar, and missed, I think, about 4s., but I am positive of 2s. - I had seen it when I gave them a sixpence and 4d. change just before.
Prisoner. Q.Can you swear you saw me take the money? A. No - I saw you coming from the bar as I came down.

CHARLES HUGHES
. I am an officer. In consequence of an alarm from a man named Gamble, I stopped the prisoner five or six hundred yards from the prosecutrix's house - he turned and said, "I will give up to you, but I know that man is not an officer;" I was going to search him - he threw down 18d., and said, "This is my 18d., if she can swear to it, but I am d-d if she can;" he said he came out for a stroll, and begged me to return him 6d. for drink.
Prisoner's Defence. I was not in the bar at all; the other man left before this woman came down - I am innocent.

GUILTY . Aged 23. -
Confined Three Months .

1484.
JOHN JAMES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of June , 67 yards of silk, value 10l. , the goods of
James Tavener
and another.

HARRIET YARNOLD. I am shopwoman to Messrs.
James Tavener
and Ely Kimpton, of Oxford-street
. On the 4th of June the prisoner brought a piece of black silk to the shop, and said Mr. Foster would be obliged by our giving him a pattern to match it as near as we could; I gave him one - he returned in about ten minutes, and said Mr. Foster would be obliged to us to let him have the piece; I gave it him - it was twelve yards and a quarter; he brought that back, and said Mr. Foster wanted thirtyyards at least; Mr. Tavener then gave him a piece of sixty-seven yards, worth about 10l. - he left the other, and went away.
Cross-examined by MR. STURGEON. Q.Had you known him before? A. No - I am sure he is the man.

JAMES TAVENER
. I let the prisoner have the silk, and in consequence of suspicion, I watched him into Mr. Foster's - I then returned, and sent Burton to Mr. Foster's.

JOHN BURTON. I am in the prosecutors' employ. I went to Foster's, and as I went in I met the prisoner coming out - I followed him to Rathbone-place; he then began running, and went on to Greek-street - I overtook him there, and asked if he had not brought a piece of silk from Mr. Wild's, in Rathbone-place; he said Yes, and he was going to take it to a customer - I went with him; he called in Gower-street, in Bedford-square, and Tavistocksquare - I then said he should not go further till he told me where the customer lived; he said at No. 36, Guildford-street - he went there; the person he inquired for was not at home - he came back to Wild's, in Rathbone-place, and they said they knew nothing of him; he then said a person in a surtout coat, who stood at their door, gave it to him.
Cross-examined. Q. Did he attempt to run away? A. No.

ROBERT MILLARD. On the 4th of June the prisoner came into Mr. Foster's with a piece of silk, and said he should want two pieces to match it for Mr. Wild; I gave him a pattern - he went out; Burton came in: I told him what had passed - the prisoner was not in Mr. Foster's service, and was not sent from our shop for the silk.
Cross-examined. Q. How many persons have you? A. One more shopman.

ROBERT KNOWLES. I am a Police-constable. On the 4th of June I was fetched to Mr. Wild's - Burton charged the prisoner with taking the roll of silk from Mr. Tavener- he said a young man at Wild's door sent him to Tavener's for it.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 26. -
Confined Three Months .

1485.
MARTHA JONES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of June , 1 purse, value 6d.; 9 sovereigns, and 8 shillings, the monies of
Thomas Clark
, from his person .

THOMAS CLARK. I am a waterman , and live at New Brentford. On the night of the 1st of March I was at the White Swan, Shadwell
; the prisoner was there when I went in - I walked with her from there to Shadwell-dock stairs
; she did not do any thing to me that night, that I am aware of, but I was intoxicated - I missed my money in the morning, between four and five o'clock - she saw me take a half-sovereign out of my purse, which I changed to treat her and another; I put the silver into my purse with the gold, and put it into my pocket again; I cannot say what I paid.

Prisoner. Several more men and women were in his company. Witness. Yes, but she was the only one with me after I left the Swan; she wanted me to go home with her - I said I would not, I should be safe in my own barge.

CHARLES EDGE. I am a Police-constable. On the 2nd of June I went with the prosecutor in search of the prisoner - we found her in a house in Gravel-lane; he asked what she had done with his money - she said she had not got it, and knew nothing about it; I said she must get up, and as soon as she sat up in bed I turned the bolster up, and saw a pocket; she said directly, "Don't touch my pocket - I know how much I took;" I found in the pocket four sovereigns, one half-sovereign, two half-crowns, three shillings, three pence, and ten halfpence; while she was getting up another person came into the room, and gave me a sovereign and a half, saying that the prisoner had put it into a cupboard up-stairs - she heard that, but made no answer; I asked her, in New Gravel-lane, what she had done with the purse and key - she said she had not seen them; I said, "Do you mean to say the money was loose in his pocket?" she said Yes, it was, and that she did not know how much she had taken, as she was intoxicated.
Prisoner. He asked what I did with the other three sovereigns - I said I did not think I had more, or I should have put it as safe as that.

GUILTY . Aged 23. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1486.
WILLIAM JOHNSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 22nd of May , 3lbs. of veal, value 2s. 6d. , the goods of
George Frederick Richard Lloyd
.

GEORGE FREDERICK RICHARD LLOYD
. I live in Featherstone-street, City-road
, and am an upholsterer . I was going out on the 22nd of May, about twelve o'clock, and saw the prisoner coming out of the passage leading to my shop- I asked who he had been to; he said the cabinet-maker - I pulled his apron down, and this veal dropped from it; I said he had taken it from my kitchen - he said he had done it for want.
MILES STANLEY. I received him in charge.
The prisoner pleaded distress.

GUILTY . Aged 70. -
Confined Ten Days .

1487.
WILLIAM HONEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of June , 3 hats, value 3l. , the goods of
John Perring
, his master.
JOHN PERRING. The prisoner was my shop-boy - he was never allowed to sell hats; George Duncan was also in my employ - I marked a sovereign, a half-sovereign, a half-crown, a shilling, and a sixpence.
Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. I believe the prisoner had a good character? A. Yes.

JOHN WEST KING
. I am a Policeman. On the 25th of June, a little after seven o'clock, I went into a public-house opposite the prosecutor's, and saw Duncan come from the shop, with three hats under his arm - he was apprehended by Hollings; I then saw the prisoner walking about the front of the shop, and saw Pattenden go into the shop and bring out three hats, in consequence of which I apprehended Honey - I had not seen him give Pattenden the hats, but they were in the shop together.

ROBERT PATTENDEN
. On the morning of the 25th of June, I was at the prosecutor's shop; I received three hats, from the prisoner, for which I gave him 14s.; I was taken, and gave them up to King.

Cross-examined. Q.Have you any other name? A. No - I am a native of Maidstone; I never assumed any other name - I never went by the name of Randall; I am nineteen years old - some have called me Randall, as my mother was married to one Randall, but the marriagedid not stand good; I have gone by that name sometimes- I lived with a Mr. Terry, in the Borough-market, and left him eighteen months ago; I have dealt in the market myself, and had a stand there - I have known the prisoner eight or nine years; I first saw him in London, about four months ago, and on the 21st of June he told me he was in the prosecutor's service - I did not go to see him on the 16th, 17th, or 18th of June; I never told him it would be easy to get me a hat or two - I never talked about hats till he mentioned it to me on the 21st of June; I gave information to Mr. Perring on the 23rd. On the 21st I was going to see the King go to the House of Lords; Honey showed me the house, and said he was in a regular gang of thieves, and had been so for a long time - I thought it my duty to let Mr. Perring know; I never bargained for four hats for 14s. - I was offered as many as I would take, at a crown a piece; I gave him 14s. for the three - he said that would do; I have received no money for this job - I received 16s. in marked money from Mr. Perring, and gave 14s. of them to the prisoner; I cannot tell how much I have received for myself.
COURT. Q.When did you first propose to the prisoner to buy hats of him? A. On the 24th - I had told Mr. Perring of it on the 23rd; I was acting under the officer's direction.

CHARLES SOUTHCOTT
. I am a Policeman. I went to the prosecutor's shop with King, and apprehended Honey, I searched him, and found on him this half-crown, this shilling, sixpence, and half-sovereign.
MR. PERRING. This is the money I marked.
The prisoner received a good character.

GUILTY . Aged 17. -
Confined Six Weeks .

1487.
JEREMIAH JOHN GREENING
was indicted for
embezzlement .
The prisoner being in the character of an agent to the prosecutor, and not a servant, the evidence was not proceeded in.
NOT GUILTY .

1488.
JOHN GEORGE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of May , 1 watch, value 3l.; 1 shawl, value 2l., and 3 seals, value 1l., the goods of
Thomas William Bull
, from his person .

THOMAS WILLIAM BULL
. I live in Margaret-place, New-road, and am a box-maker . On the 25th of May I was returning from White Conduit-gardens, and was very much in liquor; after I passed the Orange Tree, Tottenham-court-road
, I missed my watch and appendages - the prisoner was then with me, and I accused him of taking them; a Policeman came up - I have since seen my watchcase in the Policeman's hands.

Prisoner. Q. Do not you recollect being knocked down by three men? A. No, I fell down, and my hat fell off my head; that was before I got to the Orange Tree - you did not pick my watch-case up; I saw you take it out of your pocket.

JOHN RODERICK. I am a Policeman. On the morning of the 25th, I saw the prisoner and the prosecutor walking arm-in-arm, near the Orange Tree, New-road - the prosecutor was intoxicated, and the prisoner was leading him; I went round my beat, and saw them again down a gateway, about forty yards from Tottenham-courtroad, and heard the prosecutor say to him, "It is of no use your talking, you have got my watch;" I went and asked if he was robbed - he said Yes, of his watch and money; I called him aside, and asked if he knew the prisoner -I then called the prisoner, and asked if he knew the person he was with; he said Yes, he was a particular acquaintance of his - that they had been drinking and playing at skittles at a public-house in Somers'-town; I asked if he knew he had lost his watch - he said, "Then he must have dropped it, and you had better search in the water under your feet;" I said I should search him for it, and as I put my hand into his coat-pocket my hand met his coming out - I said, "What have you here?" he said,"The case of a watch I picked up;" I found this case in his hand.
Prisoner. Q. Did I not say he had lost his watch directly you came down? A. You did not.
T. W. BULL. This is my watch-case; the prisoner was a total stranger to me.

WILLIAM STEWART
. I am a Policeman. I saw the prisoner and prosecutor together in the New-road; I saw the prosecutor down, and assisted in taking him up - he had dropped his hat and handkerchief; I noticed at that time that he had a chain and seals hanging out of his pocket - a gentleman's servant attempted to brush the dirt off his coat; the prisoner gave him a push, and said,"Let the man's pockets alone;" he said he did not mean to hurt the man's pocket; the prisoner said, "I will take care you shall not."
Prisoner. He was knocked down by three men.
Witness. No, he fell down.

Prisoner's Defence. When I first met the prosecutor he asked if we could get any thing to drink - I said I would go and see - he was knocked down by three men; I took him up, and he then dropped this case - I picked it up; I said he was a friend of mine, because we had been drinking.

GUILTY . Aged 26. -
Confined One Year .

1489.
HARRY BRADBEAR
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of June , 1 handkerchief, value 2s., the goods of
Thomas Eden
, from his person .

THOMAS EDEN. I am a surgeon , and live in Bucklersbury. On the 6th of June I was at Hoxton
, about seven o'clock - there was a crowd; I felt something move my pocket, turned round suddenly, and saw the prisoner standing close to me - I told him I thought he had my pocket handkerchief; I searched him, and found it under his coat - this is it.
WILLIAM JACOBS. I am a Police-constable. I took the prisoner.
The prisoner received an excellent character.

GUILTY . Aged 16. -
Whipped and Discharged.

1490.
JAMES FULLER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of April , 3 sheets, value 15s., and 1 counterpane, value 5s. , the goods of
John Grossett
.

JANE HAMMERSLEY
. I am servant to John Grossett, of the Rose and Crown, Little Pulteney-street
. The prisoner occupied part of a bed for four or five nights; I went up to make the beds, as usual, found the door looked, and the prisoner gone - I had been up before, to get the candlestick from the adjoining room, and he gave me the candlestick out of his room; I saw him afterwards.at the corner of Berwick-street - I said, "You are a pretty sort of a man, to treat me so," as I had been but a short time in the place; he said, "You had better let me go"- I gave him in charge.
Prisoner. Q.Was there not another man in the room? A.Another man slept in the room, but he went out at six o'clock in the morning.
SAMUEL LINDLEY. I am an officer. I took the prisoner, but found no property.

Prisoner's Defence. There are three rooms on a floor- a man was in bed; I left him there, and went down -I spoke to the landlord, and it was impossible I could take such a bundle out as that must have been.
NOT GUILTY .

1491.
WILLIAM ELLIS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of May , 1 guitar, value 2l. , the goods of
John Branch
.

ROBERT LAWSON
. I lodge at the Vernon's Arms, Pentonville, and am a labourer. On the 18th of May I was passing Mr. Branch's stall, and saw the prisoner with a guitar under his arm - a ticket was pinned to it, marked 2l. 2s.; Mr. Branch spoke to me soon after - I am sure the prisoner was carrying it.

MARY ANN WOOD
. I live in York-place, Pentonville. On the 18th of May I saw the prosecutor's stall, and two boys standing near it; one of them was dressed like the prisoner, but I cannot swear to his person - that boy went to the stall, took the guitar from a hook, and gave it to the other boy, who took off his white apron, wrapped it up, and carried it across the road.

JOHN BRANCH. I keep a book-stall in front of my house in Pleasant-row, Pentonville
. On the 18th of May I had a guitar hanging there, with a ticket on it; the prisoner was taken, and he denied knowing any thing of it.
JOSEPH CADRY. I took the prisoner.
ROBERT LAWSON. I am quite certain the prisoner is the person - he was on the other side of the way, and had it in his hand; when he saw me looking at it he covered it up.

GUILTY . Aged 22. -
Confined One Month .

1492.
MARY EAST
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of May , 1 half-sovereign, 1 crown, and 3 shillings, the monies of
Richard Samuel Brooks
, from his person .

RICHARD SAMUEL BROOKS
. I am a compositor , and live in Platt-terrace, Somers'-town. On the morning of the 29th of May, between two and three o'clock, I met the prisoner in Holborn, and went with her to a house in West-street
- I was in the room about half an hour; she put her hand into my left side waistcoat pocket, and took out my money - I had a half-sovereign, a 5s. piece, and three shillings, which were all safe when I went into the house; I charged her with it, she denied it, and put on her bonnet to leave the room - I followed, called the Police, and she was taken.
Prisoner. You know you gave me the money; and often asked me to live with you. Witness. I never saw her before.

PETER MCINTYRE
. I am a Policeman. I heard an alarm, and took the prisoner in West-street - I searched her at the station, and two shillings dropped from her hair- I searched further, and a 5s. piece dropped, and on the top of her hair I found a half-sovereign and a shilling; the prosecutor told me what I should find.

GUILTY . Aged 20. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1493.
JOSEPH DONELLY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of May , 1 hat, value 5s.; 1 shirt, value 3s.; 1 pair of boots, value 5s.; 1 pair of trousers, value 2s., and 1 waistcoat, value 1s. 6d. , the goods of
Luke Grey
.
LUKE GREY. On the 17th of May I lost these articles; the prisoner lodged in my house - I never lent them to him.

WILLIAM BOOTHMAN
. I am a constable. I apprehended the prisoner - I found this waistcoat on his person, and in the room the duplicate of these trousers, which the pawnbroker delivered to me - the prosecutor claimed them.
The prisoner pleaded distress.

GUILTY . Aged 21. -
Confined Three Months .
Fifth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1494.
CATHERINE CALLAGHAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of May , 3 caps, value 7s.; 1 cloak, value 1l.; 1 pair of ear-rings, value 16s.; 1 shawl, value 2s.; 2 knives and forks, value 2s.; 1 pair of sheets, value 3s.; 1 flat-iron, value 1s., and 1 pair of stockings, value 1s. , the goods of
Mary Everett
.

MARY EVERETT. I am a widow . In May last I lived in Grove-street, Commercial-road
- the prisoner lodged with me, and left me on the 20th of March, without notice- I missed these things; I had lent her the shawl, but not the cloak - this cap was found on her head when she was taken.
Prisoner. She gave me the two old caps. Witness. A. No, not the net caps - I gave her an old muslin one.

LOUISA MANNING
. About six weeks after the 20th of March I met the prisoner in Whitechapel - she had the prosecutrix's plaid cloak on; I invited her into a house.

JOHN DELBRIDGE. I am a shopman to Mr. Cording, a pawnbroker. I have a shawl, pawned on the 21st of March - I know the prisoner, as a customer, but I do not recollect that she pawned this.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner. I never was in his shop - Everett gave me this cap and a pair of strings with it.

MARY EVERETT
. No, I did not.

RICHARD JONES
. I am a Police-constable. I took the prisoner, and found this cap on her head.

GUILTY . Aged 32. -
Confined Four Months .

1495.
ELIZABETH COLLETT
was indicted for
stealing on the 15th of May , 2 half-crowns, 1 shilling, 1 sixpence, and 1 penny halfpenny, the monies of
Joseph Ekers
, from his person .

JOSEPH EKERS
. I live in New Church-court, Strand, and am a tailor . On the morning of the 15th of May I was on my way home, near Russell-street, between two and three o'clock; the prisoner came and asked me to give her something to drink - I said there was no house open, I could not do it; I walked with her some short way, as I was going home - I was not going any where with her; she walked by my side, saying she knew a house that was open - when I got to the corner of White Horse-yard
I perceived her hand in my pocket; I took hold of her shoulder - I heard something fall, and picked up a half-crown and three halfpence from the ground; the Policeman came up, and I gave that money to him - I had had two half-crowns, one shilling, a sixpence, and, I think, 4d. or 5d. in copper, in my pocket - I missed the whole of it; I had had my hand in my pocket, and know it was safe.

THOMAS WALTER
. I am a Police-constable. I came up to the prosecutor at the corner of White Horse-yard; he said he had lost all the money out of his pocket - I took the prisoner, and searched her at the station-house; I found a half-crown and 4 1/2d. on her - the prosecutor gave me this half-crown, but no halfpence.

Prisoner's Defence. This man wished me to go up a court - I refused; he attempted to force me - I resisted; he then said he had been robbed, and I was taken - the money taken from me was my own; he took half a crown from his own pocket, and put it into the Policeman's hand.

GUILTY . Aged 34. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1496.
JOHN CLARKE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of June , 70 lbs. of iron, value 6s. , the goods of
Thomas Murray
.

CHARLES CRUTCHLEY
. I live in High-street, St. Giles'
, and am a baker. On the 17th of June I was sitting in my shop, with the door open, about two o'clock in the morning; I saw the prisoner come out of Mr. Murray's passage, next door to me, with a flat bar and a bolt on his shoulder - I followed, and gave him in charge.

Prisoner. Q.Did you see me go in? A. No; I asked where you was going - you said to No. 21, High-street, and I followed you; when you got to Lawrence-lane you wanted to go down; I got before you, and called the officer.

THOMAS MURRAY
. I found my side door open when I was called up, and missed articles of this description; I have bolts here to match them - I could not identify it at first, as I had not the fellow.

Prisoner's Defence. He said he could not swear to it, and I was liberated - I met a man going up Holborn; he asked where I was going - I said I had no money to pay for a lodging; he said if I would carry these bars he would give me a pint of beer - this gentleman asked where I was going; I was so confused I did not know what I said.

GUILTY . Aged 58. -
Confined Three Months .

1497.
JANE CLEMENTS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of June , 43 knives, value 7l.; 2 saucepans, value 10s., and 1 candlestick, value 5s. , the goods of
John Bennington
and another.

CHARLES ROBERTSON. I am servant to Mr.
John Bennington
and Son, furnishing ironmongers . I went to a nobleman's house in Curzon-street, and received these articles to be repaired - I went to a public-house, and got tipsy; I put down my basket at the step of a door - I felt myself getting sick and ill; I laid down, and was taken by the constable - I did not see the prisoner.
NOT GUILTY .

1498.
ELIZABETH BLACKMORE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of June , 1 bed, value 3l.; 1 sheet, value 2s., and 1 piece of calico, value 1s. , the goods of
Valentine Rathbone
.

REBECCA RATHBONE
. I am the wife of Valentine Rathbone; we live in John-street, St. George's
. The prisoner lived next door to me - I lost the duplicates of these articles; I went to the pawnbroker's, and found they were taken out.

WILLIAM BUTLER
. I am a Police-constable. I went to the prisoner's house; I asked if she had got a bed out of pawn that morning - she said Yes; I asked her how she came to do it when she knew it did not belong to her; she said she was not aware of the consequences - I found this sheet and calico on the drawers, and on the table I found a bag; the bed was in the yard, tied up in a bit of carpet.
Cross-examined by MR. STURGEON. Q. Did she in any way attempt to conceal them? A. No, she said she found the duplicates.
MRS. RATHBONE. This is my bag - here is my marriage certificate in it, and thirteen duplicates.

EDWARD EDMOND CHILD
. I am a shopman to Mr. Reynold's, a pawnbroker, in High-street, Shadwell. The prisoner came to his shop on the 9th of June; she produced a duplicate of a bed, and said she wished to take it out - I got a man to take it home for her; Mrs. Rathbone, who had pawned it, came afterwards to stop it, and I produced the man who took it to the prisoner's.

MRS. RATHBONE. These were all pawned in my name before I was married, and the marriage certificate has the same on it; I had only lived next door to her for three weeks - I suppose I dropped the bag in the street the night before these were taken out; here is only one duplicate of my ring, which is in my present name.
NOT GUILTY .

1499.
THOMAS BROWN
was indicted for
feloniously receiving, on the 25th of May , 2 pairs of breeches, value 5s.; 2 pairs of trousers, value 5s.; 1 pair of drawers, value 1s.; 1 coat, value 3s.; 2 waistcoats, value 1s.; 2 shawls, value 2s.; 1 gown, value 1s.; 4 petticoats, value 1s., and 2 frocks, value 1s., the goods of
Hugh Cox
, which had lately before been stolen, he well knowing the same to have been stolen ; against the Statute.

BRYNE COX
. I am eleven years of age. On the 25th of May I lost a 6d.; I stood crying at my mother's door - the prisoner came up, and asked what was the matter; I said I had lost 6d., which my mother gave me to get some potatoes - he said, "Never mind - bring me 4lbs. of rags, and I will give you 2d. for them;" he came into my father's passage, and I gave him my own coat and two waistcoats - he said that was not enough; I then brought my father's two pairs of breeches and two pairs of trousers; he gave me 2d. for them - I then brought him down one pair of drawers, two frocks and a gown, and he gave me 2d. more; I then brought him two petticoats and another frock, and he gave me 1 1/2d. for them - he asked me if I should have any more to-morrow; I said No - I am sure the prisoner is the man.

HUGH COX. The things were worth 1l. to me, at least - my wife went after the prisoner, and found him; I went to him, and asked if he was not ashamed to induce my boy to sell him all this property for 5 1/2d. - he said, "I am not ashamed - I sold one pair of the trousers to a man for 1s. 3d., and the rest were torn up in rags."

HERBERT PRIDDON
, I am a Police-constable. Theprisoner said, in my hearing, that he sold one pair of breeches, for 1s. 3d.
Prisoner's Defence. They were nothing but rags - there was only one pair of breeches.
NOT GUILTY .
Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

1500.
PETER BROWN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of June , 5 shirts, value 15s.; 5 collars, value 2s.; 5 neckcloths, value 2s.; 3 pairs of trousers, value 17s.; 4 pairs of stockings, value 4s.; 4 waistcoats, value 7s.; 1 hat, value 6s.; 1 pair of drawers, value 1s.; 1 coat, value 2l.; 1 pair of slippers, value 3d.; 1 book, value 1s.; 1 inkstand, value 5s.; 1 pair of shaving-glass frames, value 2s., and 1 box, value 5s. , the goods of
Robert Lewis
.

ROBERT LEWIS. I am a cabinet-maker , and lodge in Shoreditch. I was removing on the 20th of June from Little Pulteney-street
- the prisoner was recommended to me to carry my box; I delivered it to him to carry to Shoreditch
- I was to pay him 1s. 6d.; I went there the same evening, and he had not been - I gave him 2d., and left 1s. 4d. in Mr. Carr's hand to pay him - the box contained all the articles stated; I gave him a written direction - I never saw him till I offered a reward for his apprehension; there were papers in it I would not have taken any money for.

JAMES HARRISON
. I am an officer. On Tuesday I was at the watch-house; I was called by Carr to take the prisoner, saying he had absconded with a box of clothes - I took him in Bride-lane; he told me he went into a liquor-shop, left the box at the door, and it had been taken away.

GUILTY . Aged 18. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1501.
HENRY BURCHETT
and
WILLIAM HARNSWORTH
were indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of May , 1 copper, value 30s., the goods of
Samuel Thompson
, then being fixed to a certain building ; against the Statute, &c.

SUSAN THOMPSON. I am the wife of Samuel Thompson; we live in Little Pulteney-street, Golden-square
. On the 16th of May my copper was safe and fixed in my kitchen; I missed it about three o'clock in the afternoon - I went to Thomas Cunningham, who lives two doors off from me - he said he had seen two men with one; I went with him into a water-closet, and saw these two men beating out my copper; I know it was mine - I saw it fitted to the place again; I had seen it safe just before, and full of boiling water.
Harnsworth. Q. Did you see two men beating it up? A.Burchett had it between his knees,; you struck at Cunningham, and made your escape.

THOMAS CUNNINGHAM. I live two doors from the prosecutor's. I have seen Burchett about the neighbourhood frequently; I detected the prisoners in the watercloset of the Rose and Crown public-house, endeavouring to beat up the copper - Harnsworth struck at me, and escaped that time, but he was taken on the Tuesday week following; I am quite sure of his person - it is a most notorious house.
SAMUEL LINDLEY. I am an officer. I took the prisoner.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Burchett's Defence. I have nothing to say, but this man is entirely innocent. Harnsworth's Defence. I went on Whit-Tuesday to get a pint of beer, and I was taken.

BURCHETT -
GUILTY . Aged 27.

HARNSWORTH -
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Transported for Seven Years .

1502.
JANE ALLUM
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of February , 2 breast-pins, value 5s.; 1 cloak, value 15s.; 1 cap, value 7s.; 1 pair of pattens, value 1s.; 1 shawl, value 2s.; 2 handkerchiefs, value 1s.; 3 pairs of trousers, value 9s.; 2 aprons, value 1s.; 1 sovereign, and 4 half-crowns , the property of
Mark Allen
; and that she had been previously convicted of felony.

MARK ALLEN
. I am a sailor , and live with my wife and family at Poplar
. I have known the prisoner about five months - she lived at a lodging-house, and got ill-used; we took her in out of kindness - my wife and I went out on the 16th of February; the prisoner walked with us a little way, - I gave her the key to go back to our house, and to finish some stay-stitching that was in the house; she was to stay till we returned from Greenwich - I came home at five o'clock in the evening, and expected to find her at home, but she had locked the house up, and left the key next door; we went in, and missed the property stated from the drawers - she had knocked the top of the drawers up, got the top drawer out, got the others open, and taken these things; the money had been in the middle drawer - I heard of her, and had her taken on the 4th of June; I have not got any of my property.

ANN ALLEN
. I am the prosecutor's wife. What he has stated is true, but he forgot to mention that we missed a sovereign out of this box, and four half-crowns out of this other - they were both in one drawer.

JOSEPH BEALE
. I am a Police-constable. The prisoner was given to me - I found nothing on her.

WILLIAM JONES
. I took the prisoner on the former occasion; I know she is the person who was tried - I have the certificate of her conviction - (read.)

MARY WANNELL
. The prisoner left the key of the prosecutor's door with me - she had on a cloak, a pair of pattens, and a bundle under her arm.

Prisoner's Defence. I am totally innocent; I was there seven months - her husband said they should go to lodge at Greenwich; I said I should most likely go before they came back, and I would leave the key next door.

GUILTY . Aged 30. -
Transported for Life .

1503.
JACOB BARNETT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of June , 1 bed, value 1l.; 1 sheet, value 1s.; 1 blanket, value 1s., and 1 bolster, value 5s , the goods of
William Basset
.
The prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .

1504.
GARRETT DOWLING
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of June , 2 planes, value 3s.; 1 box and top, value 6s.; 1 bed-wrench, value 1s.; 1 chisel, value 1s., and 1 screw-driver, value 6d. , the goods of
Beal Beecroft
.

JAMES COBBETT
. I am a Police-constable. On the 30th of June I met the prisoner in Bainbridge-street, St. Giles' - he had one plane under his arm, another in his hand, and the other things were in his pocket; he said they were his own property - I asked if they had anymark on them; he said, No - I asked if the maker's name was on them; he said Yes, but he did not know what it was - I said he must go to the station; he sent me to a man who he said would state that he worked with him; I went there - the man said he knew an old man of that name, but not a young man.

BEAL BEECROFT
. I am a turner . These are my tools, and were safe in my shop in High-street, St. Giles'
, at nine o'clock on the evening before - at five o'clock that morning I missed them; the prisoner had worked for me about one year and three-quarters ago - the shop had been broken open.
Prisoner's Defence. I met two chaps - one of them said he was out of work, and had no money; I bought these tools of him for 3s.

GUILTY . Aged 21. -
Confined Three Months .

1505.
WILLIAM FAUCIT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of July , 1 bottle, value 2d., and 1 pint of anniseed, value 2s. , the goods of
John Phillips
.

JOHN PHILLIPS. I am a licenced victualler , and live in Orchard-street, Westminster
. On the first of July the prisoner came to my house, and called for a pot of ale - he and two others drank it at the bar, and he broke a glass; I said I would not give him another till he paid for that - he then ran out with the ale quart in his hand; I fetched him back, and said he had committed a felony- he then deliberately took a bottle of anniseed off a shelf, and gave it to another man; he went out - I followed, and brought him back.

RACHAEL HOLLYER
. I was at the prosecutor's, and saw the prisoner take the bottle of anniseed, and give it to another person. who ran away with it.
Prisoner's Defence. I was in a state of intoxication.

GUILTY . Aged 24. -
Confined Fourteen Days .

1506.
MARY HUTCHINSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 22nd June , 1 necklace, value 5s.; 2 ear-rings, value 4s., and 5lbs. of beef, value 2s. , the goods of
George Walby
, his master.

MARY WALBY. I am the wife of George Walby, a butcher - we live in High-street, Shadwell
. The prisoner had been five months in my service; I missed these articles from a drawer - I found a key which opened my drawer, attached to a pocket of mine, which laid on her bed, and which she had no right to have; I spoke to her about it - she said it belonged to a box of her own, which she had when she lived at Mr. Brown's.

FRANCES PEPPER
. I have known the prisoner ever since she was in that place. On the Thursday before she was taken up; she gave me this ear-ring to take care of for her - she said she had lost the fellow to it.

GEORGE BLAKE
. I received this ear-ring from the witness.
MRS. WALBY. This is my ear-ring - we lost a piece of beef on the Sunday, but that has not been found, nor the necklace; she had no friends.
GUILTY. Aged 18.
Recommended to Mercy by the Jury and Prosecutor.

Judgment Respited
.

1507.
WILLIAM JAMESON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of July , 6 books, value 18s. , the goods of
Thomas Bateman
.

THOMAS BATEMAN. I keep a book-shop in Goodge-street
. The officer brought the prisoner and the books to me on the 2nd of July - I did not see them taken.

WILLIAM PICKARD
. I am a Police-constable. I saw the prisoner carrying these books, wrapped in a cloth, not far from the prosecutor's; I asked how he came by them- he said he brought them from Goodge-street; he would not satisfy me from whom, and I took him with them.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 25. -
Confined One Month .

1508.
WILLIAM WHERRITT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of July , 1 saucepan, value 2s. , the goods of
James Lee
.

MARY LEE
. I am the wife of James Lee, of Joseph-street, New-road
. About two o'clock on the 1st of July, I was standing at the next door, and saw the prisoner come out of my passage with this saucepan - I pursued, and he threw it down; I secured him - it was taken from my kitchen.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner. I know nothing about it.

GUILTY . Aged 37. -
Confined Three Months .

1509.
ELIZA FELTON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of June , 2 half-crowns, and 1 sixpence, the monies of
John Hellings
, from the person of
Jane Hellings
.

JANE HELLINGS. I am the wife of John Hellings. On the 6th of June my goods were going to be seized - I went out, and had half a pint of beer; I was crying - the prisoner, who was a stranger, came and asked what was the matter; I told her - she said she would go home with me, and see me righted; I allowed her to stop all night we had some gin, and sat on the bed drinking; about ten o'clock at night, I felt my pockets going, and she walked away with them; this money was in them.

Q. Why not give an alarm? A. I felt something snap, but was not certain it was my pocket - I did not undress all night; I saw her about two o'clock the next afternoon, and asked for my money - she said, "Come with me, I will make it all right;" I went to two houses with her - she could not raise it, and about seven I gave her in charge.

GEORGE MARLOW
. I keep the house - the prosecutrix brought the prisoner in; the prisoner called me up stairs, and said she understood I wanted to seize her goods - I knew nothing about it, and never meant it.
NOT GUILTY .

1510.
ANN MALLETT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of June , 1 cream-jug, value 5s., and 1 decanter, value 5s. , the goods of
Mary Bull
.

MARY BULL. I am a widow , and keep the Grey Hound, Smithfield
. On the 29th of June the prisoner came to my house with a gentleman, and had something to drink - when she was gone these articles were missed from the bar; I did not miss them till next morning - they had been two or three hours in the house, and some other persons were with them part of the time - they left about one o'clock.

Cross-examined by MR. STURGEON. Q.What do you know the articles by? A. I have no mark, but they are like mine, and I believe them to be mine: the persons in the house seemed companions - I should think they staid two hours; they were not bad characters - there were two other females there; the prisoner and the gentleman came into the bar - the gentleman was intoxicated; I cannot say whether the prisoner was so- they had a good deal to drink, and there was a dispute about the reckoning.

HENRY KEMPSTER. I am a Policeman. I found the prisoner in a lodging-house in West-street, Saffron-hill - there were two men and a female there; I said she was accused of robbing a man of 6l. - I found a sovereign in her hand; this decanter and cream-jug were found on her person - it was at four o'clock in the morning.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. We were drinking there from ten to two o'clock; the man who was with me gave me these things - we went to West-street, and there the gentleman said I had robbed him; I would have the Policeman called in.

GUILTY . Aged 24. -
Transported for Seven Years .
OLD COURT. FRIDAY, JULY 8.
Second Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

1511.
ELIZABETH MARIA NORRIS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of June , 4 half-crowns, and 1 shilling, the monies of
Daniel Daly
, from his person .

DANIEL DALY
. I am a sailor , and belong to a King's ship - I was paid off at Portsmouth, came to town, and worked at the West India-docks; I came to Somerset-house, and drew my prize-money. I went to a friend's house, and between twelve and one o'clock at night, I was going home; I had four half-crowns and two shillings in my right-hand waistcoat pocket - I was quite sober, and dressed as a sailor; the prisoner came up to me in Spitalfields
, and asked me to go home with her - I said I had rather go home; she said I had better go with somebody that could protect me; I said I had rather go home - she put her hand suddenly into my pocket, and took out my money; I caught hold of her hand as it came out of my pocket - as I could not get her hand open, I threw her down on the pavement, and a shilling dropped out of her hand; I picked it up - she screamed Murder! a Policeman came up - I gave her in charge, and on the way to the station I heard money drop on the pavement - a Policeman picked up two half-crowns, and farther on she dropped another half-crown; the money was laid on the table at the station- she said, "* * * you, cannot hurt me, because nothing was found on me."

JOHN CAMPBELL
. I am a Policeman. The prosecutor, who was sober, called me; I found them both on the pavement - he charged her with robbing him of 11s.; I took her, and about one hundred yards further on I heard something drop - my brother officer took it up: it was two half-crowns; and further on she dropped another - she said"You have got it again - what can you do with me? it was not found on me."
MARK MEADOWS. I am a Policeman. Campbell's evidence is correct; one half-crown is entirely gone.
Prisoner's Defence. It was my own money - I had it in my hand; this man accosted me - he wanted me to take him home; I said it was not convenient, and he knocked me down.

GUILTY . Aged 29. -
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1512.
BENJAMIN NEWCOMB
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of June , 6 sheets, value 2l.; 3 table-cloths, value 2l.; 3 shirts, value 1l.; 7 neckerchiefs, value 1l.; 3 sets of bed-furniture, value 15s., and 12 yards of calico, value 3s. , the goods of
Richard Parkin
.

MARGARET HALL. I am servant to Richard Parkin, a grocer , of Bedford-street, Covent-garden
; Mrs. Cousins, of Kensington, washes for the family - the linen is sent and returned by Bosher, the carrier. On Monday, the 6th of June, about five o'clock in the evening, the prisoner, who was a stranger, came to my house - I was called to him, and he asked if the linen-box was ready to go to Kensington; I said it was, and thinking he came from Cousin's, I delivered him a box, containing the articles stated in the indictment - I have not seen any of them since; he was apprehended that day week - I am quite certain he is the man.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. I suppose he was a very short time with you? A.He was more than a minute; he corded the box up - I noticed his dress and his features, being a stranger I noticed him more; I have not a doubt of him.

HANNAH COUSINS
. I wash for Mr. Parkin. I did not receive the linen on the 6th of June - Monday is the usual time for it to come; I never saw the prisoner, nor authorised him or any person to go for the box.

JAMES BOSHER
. I am a carrier. I know the prisoner by sight; his friends live close to me - I never authorised him to go for the box, and never received it.
THOMAS MADDEN. I am a Police-constable. I apprehended the prisoner on the 13th - the property has not been found.

GUILTY . Aged 21. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1513.
MARY ANN MULLINS
,
WILLIAM RICHARDS
, and
EDWARD WILSON
, were indicted for
stealing, on the 23rd of June , 1 shirt, value 4s.; 1 pair of hose, value 1s.; 2 cravats, value 2s.; 3 handkerchiefs, value 4s.; 1 collar, value 9d., and 1 pocket, value 3d. , the goods of
John Howells
.

MARY HOWELLS
. I am the wife of John Howells - we live at Pimlico
. On Thursday, the 26th of June, I went out at six o'clock in the evening - I shut the door, but did not lock it; two females lodge in the house - I returned at half-past nine, and missed this property, before I went to bed - the prisoners are strangers to me.

JOSEPH WILKINS
. I am an officer. I heard of this transaction, and went to No. 12, Perkins'-rents, Westminster, on Saturday morning, the 25th, about half-past ten o'clock; the prisoners all occupy one room there, and live together - Mullins was at home; I searched a box there, and turned out a handkerchief - she said that was hers; I said, "Well, if it is, you shall have it;" I gave it her, and she put it in her bosom - I went on searching the place, and then took her to the watch-house; I found a cravat, a lace collar, and a shirt in the room, and a pair of stockings and a pocket in a box; I fetched Howells, who claimedthe handkerchief, which I afterwards took from her bosom; I found Wilson in St. Giles', brought him to the watch-house, and one cravat was round his neck.

ROBERT GOOSE
. I am a Policeman. I apprehended Richards, and on his neck found a silk handkerchief, which the prosecutrix claimed.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Wilson's Defence. On the 25th of June I left my father's house - I called on a young man to go to bathe; I saw the handkerchief laying on his chair - I asked him to lend me something to wipe myself with, and when I came out of the water he lent me this handkerchief; I was going to return it when the Policeman took me - as soon as the young man heard I was in custody he absconded, and the woman who lived with him.

Mullins' Defence. The room did not belong to me; I went up when the Policeman was there, and seeing him taking the young man's things, I said, "Don't take my property away;" I did not know but it was the young man's till I got to the watch-house - I do not live with him.

Richards' Defence. I was in Tothill-fields, and met a man, who asked me to lend him 2d. - I pulled out a sixpence to get change; he said he would sell me the cravat for 6d., as he wanted 6d. to get his breakfast.

MULLINS -
GUILTY . Aged 17.

RICHARDS -
GUILTY . Aged 17.

WILSON -
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Transported for Seven Years .

1511.
JANE JACKSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of May , 1 diamond pin, value 8l., the goods of
John Maccallum
, from his person .
MR. CLARKSON conducted the prosecution.

JOHN MACCALLUM
. I am an insurance-broker , of Bucklersbury, and reside in Grafton-street, Fitzroy-square. On the 26th of May, having dined with a friend, I was on my road home - about one o'clock in the morning, as I proceeded up Rathbone-place, I saw the prisoner before me and a man walking along with her; I overtook and passed them - they stopped at the corner of Rathboneplace, by the Percy hotel; as I passed the prisoner she looked very hard at me - I crossed the road, and she followed me; I requested her not to go with me, for she could get no advantage at all by my company, and requested her to return to her friend - she said he was no friend of hers, that she had never seen him before, and did not like him for he was putting a great many curious questions to her, and she did not wish to have any thing to say to him - she continued this sort of conversation till I got to the other side of the street; that was in crossing Charlotte-street - she wished me to go to a house with her, which I declined; she then asked me for money to carry her home in a coach - I asked where she lived; she said in Burton-crescent - I said the distance was very short, it was a fine clear night, and she had no occasion for a coach - she then became rather abusive in her language, and said I had deprived her of a friend; I reminded her that I had wished her to keep by that friend - I could not get rid of her; I cannot repeat all the conversation - she was very importunate, and to get rid of her I turned away from her, and at the moment of turning away, another female, who is here, happened to be passing; I joined her on purpose to ged rid of the prisoner, and walked a few paces with her - when the prisoner saw me join that female she ran after me, laid hold of the skirts of my coat, apparently to stop me; I put my hand round to take care of my pockets or my coat, and at that moment (I was walking alongside the other female) the prisoner put her hand over my shoulder, towards my breast - I moved my right hand to keep her away, but she repeated these efforts so frequently that I did all I could to push her away from me - I had not used sufficient force to keep her away, and therefore I laid hold of both her hands, folded them on her bosom, and gently pushed her into the street; I did it so gently as I could; I left her standing in the street, and came back to the pavement on the left side, upon which she instantly rushed towards me, and made a grasp at my breast - I had a diamond pin in my shirt, which was conspicuous; the moment she made the grasp, she withdrew a step or two -I put my hand to my breast, and found the pin was gone; I immediately charged her with robbery, and called Police! Police! a Policeman came up; I laid hold of her left hand myself immediately, and told him to lay hold of the right, which he did, and she was taken to the station-house - I did not feel satisfied with the Policeman's conduct; at the station I made a general complaint that I was robbed; Pattisson went out; the prisoner was on the point of being searched when Pattisson came in with the pin - my shirt was torn with her taking it - I had taken no description of liberty with her whatever.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. You have stated very fairly that you took her by the wrist, I am sure you would not use unnecessary violence, but with as much force as you thought necessary, you removed her? A.
