Precisely so; she certainly appeared angry at my not acceding to her wishes - I was going home, and did not want to be troubled with any body; the last grasp she made was after I had pushed her away - I have never said I might be mistaken as to her intention; I said to Mr. Harmer that I did not wish to press hard upon her, for there was no anger in my feelings - she denied that she intended to steal the pin.
MR. CLARKSON. Q. Did you use more violence than to keep her from your person? A. I did not.

MR. PHILLIPS. Q.What did you say to the other girl? A. I believe I asked where she lived, and where she was going; that was not in the prisoner's hearing - she was ten or twelve paces off: it was a still night - my object was only to get rid of the prisoner.

FRANCES DUFFIELD
. I am unfortunate, but do not get my living by walking the streets. I was returning home, and heard the prosecutor and prisoner talking rather loud; I heard something about a coach, but cannot exactly recollect what - I saw the prisoner snatch at Mr. Maccallum's cravat; he pushed her away - she made a second snatch, and then he called the Policeman, who came up and took her; the Policeman told me I must go too - I heard something drop, but did not think any thing about the pin, and never saw it - they took me to the station; Pattisson afterwards called me out - I described the spot to him; he went away, and returned in about ten minutes with the pin.

Cross-examined. Q. How long before the prisoner waspushed away by Mr. Maccallum did you come up? A. I was passing; Mr. Maccallum said, "Are you going home?" I had not time to answer before the prisoner ran up to him- she had passed me with the prosecutor; I cannot say whether she could hear what he said to me, as she was behind me - he had left her and come up to me; she came up and gave the snatch - he took her by the hand and pushed her off the pavement; then she came and made a snatch at his cravat.
Q. Did she not appear irritated and angry at the push off the pavement? A. She appeared angry, and was making use of very angry words.
Q. Did she not, in strong terms, deny indignantly that she had any intention of robbing him? A. She certainly said she was no thief - she appeared angry; a piece of his shirt was torn off.
MR. CLARKSON. Q.Was that the part where his pin was? A.Exactly.

WILLIAM JONES
. I am a Policeman. I was not called up on this occasion - there was no call till I got to Mr. Maccallum - he then directly gave the prisoner into my charge for stealing a diamond pin.

Cross-examined. Q. Are you the Policeman the prosecutor was dissatisfied with? A. I am - I do not know that I gave him any reason to be dissatisfied; I think he acted with rather unnecessary violence - as I was going up Rathbone-place I saw the prosecutor and prisoner, and hearing an altercation between them, I stopped, and saw the prosecutor push her into the road - he directly came on the pavement; I passed them, and he gave her into my custody - it was a clear still morning; I came up directly after the push, and he exclaimed, "She has stolen a diamond pin;" and gave her in charge - I saw him push her, and was near enough for her to see me, if she had looked; I was in my dress, and on duty.

MATTHEW PATTISSON
. I am a Policeman. I was at the station - the prisoner, prosecutor, and Duffield came in; I called Duffield, and she described the spot to me - I immediately went there, found the pin, and brought it back to Mr. Maccallum - I have the shirt where it was torn from the breast.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. Mr. Maccallum followed me some distance, and asked my address, which I refused; he repeated the question - I asked why he put the question to me; he said he was very anxious to know, that he might call next day - I told him I was so situated I could not tell him; he then behaved very ill to me, indeed, turned away to another woman, and spoke to her - I turned round, took him by the coat or sleeve, and said, "You behave very unlike a gentleman," and believe I said, "You are a blackguard;" he then pushed me to the other side of the road - I thought he would have killed me, he threw me with such force into the road, and at the impulse of the moment I attempted to slap his face, or scratch it - if I could have got at it I would have done it; I declare I never saw his pin till I saw it at the station-house - he took hold of me, pulled me to the station-house, I did not know what for, but thought it was for the assault; when I got there I wept bitterly; he said, "I charge this woman with stealing a pin;" I was astonished - I was not at all anxious for his property, or any body else's; I want nothing but what is right.
NOT GUILTY .

1515.
THOMAS GREEN
and
JOHN GRANT
were indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of June , 1 handkerchief, value 4s., the goods of
George Joseph Ford
, from his person .

GEORGE JOSEPH FORD
. On the 12th of June, about eight o'clock in the evening, I was in Mitre-passage, Hatton-garden
, with my wife on my arm, and felt a tug at my outside coat pocket - I felt a shoving against the wall, and in a moment Grant and another man passed; I recollect seeing him behind me in Hatton-garden - I missed my handkerchief; I went to Grant, and said, "Give me my handkerchief;" he said, "I have not got your handkerchief," and swore - I then saw Green run away; he almost knocked my wife down in running; I followed, calling Stop thief! a gentleman came up - I asked him to hold him while I went after the other, and at the bottom of the court two lads said a fellow had run up there with a handkerchief; I went up - it is no thoroughfare, and Green came out; I called him, and said, "Give me my handkerchief;" he said, "I have not got it" - his coat came open, and it fell out; I got a Policeman, who took him - there was a third man, who got away.

EDWARD GONOUD
. I am a Policeman. I received them in charge.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Grant's Defence. I know nothing of this young man.
G. J. FORD re-examined. They were all three abreast in Hatton-garden, and when I felt them at me Green was exactly behind me - he turned round, and ran.

GREEN -
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

GRANT -
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Confined Three Months .

1516.
RICHARD FRITH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of June , 2 shirts, value 20s., and 1 pair of stockings, value 5s. , the goods of the Honourable
Augustus Barrington
.

WILLIAM HAWES
. I am servant to the Honourable Augustus Barrington, who was lodging in Half Moon-street, Piccadilly
- the prisoner was footman to Mr. Malon, the landlord. On Monday, the 27th of June, I missed from the drawers two shirts and a pair of white silk stockings - the prisoner had left on the Friday previous; I suspected him, met him in Shepherd's-market about six o'clock next day, and asked if he took them- I said it would be better to give me the tickets of the shirts, than have them taken from him; he then gave me some duplicates - I went to the pawnbroker's, and found the shirts.
Cross-examined by MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. You cannot tell whether Mr. Barrington might not have made him a present of them? A. I did not know them certainly.
COURT. Q. I suppose if Mr. Barrington gave his shirts away he would give them to you? A. Yes.

WILLIAM BEZANT
. I am a pawnbroker, in South Audley-street. I have a linen shirt - I do not know who pawned it; Hawes has the counterpart of the duplicate.
Cross-examined. Q. You gave that duplicate to theperson who pawned it? A.Yes - he said he pawned it for another person.

JOHN BUTTON
. I am a pawnbroker, in Jermyn-street. I have a shirt - I do not know who pawned it; the counterpart of the duplicate is here.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 24.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Confined Six Weeks .

1517.
HENRY VENDWORTH DUNOIR
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of June , 1 pair of boots, value 2s. , the goods of
Charles Bohag
.

SUSANNAH BOHAG
. I am the wife of Charles Bohag, a shoemaker - we live in Tothill-street
. On the 29th of June, about ten minutes to nine o'clock at night, I saw the prisoner put his foot into the shop, reach up, break the string, and take the shoes off a nail; I followed, took him about five yards from the house, and brought him back -I did not know him before.
Prisoner. Q. Did you not offer to set me at liberty if I paid 2s. for them? A. Yes, I thought it would save me the trouble of coming here.
DANIEL LYONS. I am a Policeman, and received the prisoner in charge.(Property produced and sworn to)
The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating that he was intoxicated.

GUILTY . Aged 34. -
Confined Fourteen Days .
Before Mr. Recorder.

1518.
ELIZABETH ROSE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3rd of June , 4 table-cloths, value 9s.; 1 candlestick, value 6d.; 1 pair of shoes, value 3s.; 1 shift, value 2s.; 1 holster, value 6d.; 1 sheet, value 2s., and 2 spoons, value 4s. , the goods of
James Partridge
, her master.

ANN ELIZABETH PARTRIDGE
. I am the wife of James Partridge; we keep a tavern in Paul-street, Finsbury
. The prisoner was three or four months in our service, during which time we lost the articles stated in the indictment - she was apprehended on the 3rd of June, at my house, on suspicion, and all the articles produced at Worship-street.

JOHN BATEMAN
. I am a journeyman to Mr. Johnson, of Providence-row, Finsbury, a pawnbroker. On the 4th of April I took a table-cloth in pledge for 3s., in the name of Mary Jones, from the prisoner - I am certain of her person; on the 20th of April, a table-cloth was pawned in the same name, but not in my presence; on the 3rd of May I took in another table-cloth from her, in the name of Eliza Jones, from 6d. - on the 5th of May she pawned a candlestick for 6d., and another table-cloth for 6d.; I have a holster-case, pawned by her on the 24th of May for 4d., a holster, on the 1st of June, for 2s. 6d., a child's shift, on the 2nd of June, for 6d., a pair of woman's shoes, on the 2nd of June, for 1s. 6d., and on the 3rd of June she offered a glass goblet to pawn, with Partridge's name on it - I asked how she came by it; she said it belonged to hereself - I sent for Mr. Partridge; she then made her escape from our shop.

WILLIAM PAWLEY
. I am a shopman to Mr. Attenborough, of Crown-street, I have a tea-spoon, pawned in the name of Ann Jones - I do not know who by; also another spoon and shirt, which I did not take in.

ELIZABETH PAYNE
. I came into Mr. Partridge's service immediately after the prisoner, and found some duplicates in a glove, in a cupboard up stairs - I delivered them to mistress.

THOMAS WHITNEY
. I am a constable. I apprehended the prisoner at Partridge's house, the Paul's Head; she had gone home hereself - Partridge gave me this goblet.

JOHN BATEMAN
. This is the goblet she offered me.

JAMES BROWN
. I am an officer. On the 16th of June the prosecutor brought me a glove, containing twenty-one duplicates, twelve of which relate to the articles produced; some are for wearing apparel, which are not claimed.(Property produced and sworn to.)
MR. PARTRIDGE. I have the duplicates - they are all in the name of Jones.
JOHN BATEMAN. They are the duplicates of these pledges.

GUILTY . -
Transported for Seven Years .

1519.
MARY ROBINSON
and
MARY CORBYN
were indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of June , 1 sovereign, 2 half-crowns, and 1 shilling, the monies of
Patrick Dunn
, from his person .

PATRICK DUNN. I work at the Trinity-house, as ballast-man . On Sunday, morning, the 26th of June, about nine o'clock, I went into the tap-room at the White Hart, Ratcliff-highway
, to look for some ballast-heavers; I had been in bed all night - I was alone; my money was in my trousers pocket; the prisoners were strangers - I laid my head on the table, and fell asleep; while I was asleep the money was taken out of my pocket - I did not see the prisoners there - I am sure it was safe when I fell asleep.
Corbyn. Q. Did you count your money? A. I counted it about two minutes before I laid my head down - there were a good many men and women in the house; I might have been seen to count it.

ELLEN SULLIVAN
. I went into the White Hart with a friend about nine o'clock, to have a pint of beer; Dunn sat in a box opposite me, reading a book - I saw the prisoners sitting in the next box to me; when Dunn fell asleep they went over to where he was sitting - I was not in the house above five minutes; nobody but Dunn and the prisoners were in that box - I saw Robinson sit down by his side, and put her band into his pocket, while Curbyn stood before her to conceal her: they did not stop five minutes - he was asleep when they left the house; I had not seen him count his money - I told a man who was in the box with me, that I would go over and tell him; he advised me to have nothing to do with it, and I did not tell - when Dunn missed his money, he came over and asked if I had seen any body pick his pocket; I pointed Robinson out, who stood at the tap-room door - he went over, and told her if she would give him part of it back, he would say nothing about it; she said, "Go and look for your money," and then he gave her in charge.
Robinson. Q. Did you not see me sitting in the same box as your friend? A. No: when Robinson was taken I went home - Corbyn was taken in about a quarter of an hour; I am a char-woman.

Corbyn. She is an unfortunate girl, and cohabits with Dunn. Witness. I never drank a farthing of his money,
HENRY LEE
. I am a Policeman. I apprehended Robinson - she said she was innocent; I found nothing on her - I took Corbyn in about half an hour, and found only 3d. on her.
Robinson's Defence. I never saw the man till I was taken up.
Corbyn's Defence. I never set eyes on him till I was taken.
PATRICK DUNN. I did not know Sullivan any more than a woman in the street.
NOT GUILTY .

1520.
WILLIAM SCRIVENER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of June , 1 pair of breeches, value 4s. , the goods of
Benjamin Hutchins
.

BENJAMIN HUTCHINS
. I am ostler at the White Hart, South Mimms
. I missed my breeches out of a stall in the stable, in May; I know the prisoner, but he was not in the same situation - I saw him wearing my breeches about four days after I missed them; I asked him for them - he made no answer, and on the 15th of June he was taken up; I had asked him for them - he said sooner than I should have them he would tear them up.

JAMES FARRELL
. I live with Hutchins. He lent me these breeches while I got my own mended, but I never put them on, because they were too large - they hung in the stable for about a month, and were missed; I was weeding the garden one day, and the prisoner came in - I said,"Have you not got Ben's breeches on?" he said, "Yes, I have put them on while my own are drying, as I have been fishing; I don't think he will say any thing to me."
NOT GUILTY .

1521.
HENRY SAUNDERS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of April , 1 coat, value 1l., and 1 pocket-book, value 1s. , the goods of
James Edward Tillman
.

JAMES EDWARD TILLMAN
. I keep a tailor's shop . On the 9th of April the prisoner came into the shop, and bought a body coat and pair of trousers, which came to 25s. - he gave me two sovereigns; my own coat was on the counter, with a pocket-book in the pocket - I went down into the kitchen to get change, which I came up and gave him; he then walked out with what he had bought under his arm, and my coat, with the pocket-book in it, on his back, leaving his old coat behind, which he had on when he came in; he had put mine on instead of his own while I was down stairs; I met him three weeks after, in the street, with my coat on - I turned round, and collared him; he said, "Oh, how do you do? I was going to bring your coat back;" I took charge of him - he had been frequently to my shop, offering half a crown for an old hat.

THOMAS TILLMAN. I am the prosecutor's brother. I was in the shop, and saw the prisoner put the coat on, and put his own down, but did not know at the moment which coat he had on - the one he left behind was worth nothing; he went away with a blue coat on - my brother went to put his coat on, and could not find it.
Prisoner's Defence. The boy says he was in the shop; he was in the parlour.

GUILTY . Aged 23. -
Confined One Month .

1522.
MATTHEW VARNEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of May , 1 shawl, value 5s., and 1 gown, value 2s. , the goods of
William Sharp
.
The prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .

1523.
ANN WALKER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of June , 1 china bowl, value 10s. , the goods of
Thomas Costalow
.

THOMAS COSTALOW
. I am a broker , and live in Windmill-street, Tottenham-court-road
. This bowl was in front of my shop - I did not see it taken, but an alarm was given - I saw the prisoner running away with it; I pursued, and took her with it - it is worth 10s.

THOMAS REEVE
. I am a Policeman. I received her in charge, with the bowl.(Property produced and sworn to.)

SARAH JONES
. I live in Windmill-street. I was at my window, and saw the prisoner come along the street, go to the private door, look round the corner, and take this bowl off a chest of drawers - I came down, gave information, and she was apprehended.
The prisoner pleaded poverty.

GUILTY . Aged 41. -
Fined 1s. and Discharged.

1524.
ROBERT RAYNSFORD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of July , 1 shirt, value 2s. 6d. , the goods of
William Smith
.

WILLIAM SMITH
. I live at Brompton
, and have been a gardener . On the 1st of July I missed a shirt, which I had seen ten minutes before hanging on a horse in my back room; the door was locked, but the key in it - a lodger had left the street door open; I saw the prisoner taken out of a ditch, about a quarter of a mile from the house, and saw the shirt under an archway; he was standing just by it - I charged him with stealing it; he went on his knees, and begged to be forgiven, saying he had done nothing of the kind before.

EDWARD FIELD
. I lived at Smith's house with my parents; I am eleven years old. About five minutes past eleven o'clock I went out for a drop of beer for my mother; I came back, and closed the door - a lodger came in and left the front door open; I went up and warmed the beer - I then heard the key of the back door turned; I came down, saw the prisoner snatch the shirt off the horse, and run off - I ran after him, calling Stop thief! he was found in a ditch, in Cromwell-lane - I saw the shirt found in the arch which goes over the ditch; the prisoner had just scrambled it there to hide it.

GEORGE MILTON
. I am a Policeman. I received him in charge with the shirt, and found 10d. on him, with some bread and cheese - I never saw him before.
The prisoner pleaded distress.
GUILTY . Aged 43.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Confined Fourteen Days .
NEW COURT. FRIDAY, JULY 8.
Fifth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1525.
PATRICK SULLIVAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of July , 1 handkerchief, value 4s., the goods of
Simon Jacques Rochard
, from his person .

SIMON JACQUES ROCHARD
. I am a miniature-painter , and live in Regent-street. On the evening of the 1st ofJuly I was walking in Argyle-place
, a little before eight o'clock - I heard a cry of Stop thief! and saw Hobbs running after the prisoner; I had felt my coat pocket moving, and missed my handkerchief, which I had safe the minure before - I afterwards received it from a gentleman who saw it on the ground, and ran after me with it.

THOMAS HOBBS
. I am a Police-constable. On the evening of the 1st of July, I saw the prisoner in Regent-street, in company with another person; I saw him follow different gentlemen, and attempt their pockets - I followed him on to Argyle-place, and saw him put his hand into the prosecutor's pocket; he drew it out without the handkerchief - he put it in a second time, and brought out the handkerchief; I instantly went towards him - I suppose he saw me, and threw the handkerchief on the pavement - he and his companion then separated; I pursued, and took him in Regent-street - I had not lost sight of him.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I was going along Argyle-street- a boy picked a gentleman's pocket, and ran by me; I crossed the road - the Policeman pursued the boy; he run too fast for him - he then turned and took me.
GUILTY . Aged 9.

Confined Three Months and
Whipped .

1526.
CAROLINE BOOTH
and
ELIZA HARRINGTON
were indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of June , 1 purse, value 2s.; 13 sovereigns, 2 half-sovereigns, and three 5l. Bank notes, the property of
Elias White
, from his person .
MR. CLARKSON conducted the prosecution.

ELIAS WHITE
. I live in Parker's-court, Drury-lane- I keep a bent-timber manufactory , and am a widower . On the morning of the 17th of June I fell in with the two prisoners in Drury-lane, near Long-acre, a little before four o'clock - we went into a house in Drury-lane, and had something to drink; I had 15l. in 5l. notes, thirteen sovereigns, and two half-sovereigns - I am confident I had all this money when I met them; I at length went with them to No. 4, Phoenix-alley Hart-street
- we all went into a room on the attic; Harrington then went away, and Booth only staid with me - I sat down on the side of the bed, and found myself rather heavy; I laid down with all my clothes on, except my coat and hat -Booth then asked me for a compliment; I said I had no change, but I would make her a compliment before I went away, that I would behave to her in the way I ought - my money and purse were safe then, and I buttoned up my pocket; I fell asleep, and awoke a little after seven o'clock - Booth was then gone, and all my money; I had not 1d. left - I inquired in the house, and heard that Booth was not there; I went to the Police-station, and gave information - I went with an officer to a house in Canterbury-place, Cornwall-road, where I found the two prisoners and a sister of theirs, all in bed together; I have since seen the purse which my money was in - it is a green silk purse; I have also seen a 5l. note at Booth's, the distillers, in Cow-cross - I know it by the names of Payne and Lee on it, in my own hand-writing; I positively swear that note was in my purse - I found my money safe after Harrington left.

Cross-examined by MR. BARRY. Q. Were you drunk? A. I had taken a little refreshment, but was perfectly sober; I only went to one public-house - a friend was with me; he went with Harrington to another room, and they kicked him down stairs - I paid money away, and received some in the course of the day; I know what I had when I went into the house.

THOMAS STILWELL
. I am a gas-lighter; it is my duty to go round early in a morning, to put the gas out. On the morning of the 17th of June, this day three weeks, I was out cleaning my lamps - I saw the two prisoners and another shorter person coming from Duke-street, Lincoln's-inn-fields, towards Gate-street, at a quarter-past five o'clock; I saw Booth take something, put it in her left hand, and with her right hand she threw it over the wall of a garden - I had seen the prisoners before; I told the Policeman, and by his permission I went over the wall, and found this green purse, which I have had ever since - the prosecutor claimed it.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you know both the women? A. Yes; I have seen them - I saw her put something in a bulk into her left hand, and then into her pocket.

ARCHIBALD McINTRE
. I am in the service of Messrs. Hall and Freeman, in St. John-street. I know both the prisoners as customers; on the 7th of June they both came, bought three shawls, and paid for them with a 5l. note.

PHILLIP FREEMAN
. On the morning of the 17th of June I received this note from Harrington's hand - Booth was with her; I marked it, and paid it to a man named Jennings.
- FAIRCLOUGH. I am clerk at Booth's distillery. I produce a 5l. note.

PHILLIP FREEMAN
. This is the note she paid me.

ELIAS WHITE
. This is one of the notes I lost that night - this and the purse is all I have found.
Cross-examined. Q.You had not paid the note away? A. No.
Booth's Defence. What the lamplighter says is false.

BOOTH -
GUILTY . Aged 25.
Transported for Seven Years .

HARRINGTON -
NOT GUILTY .

1527.
THOMAS LAHAY
and
THOMAS BRENAN
were indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of June , 3 gills of wine, value 1s. 6d. , the goods of the
London Dock Company
.

JAMES GILLESPIE
. I am a watchman at the east-cellar of the London-docks. On the afternoon of the 25th of June I came out of the cellar, and saw the prisoners near a pipe of wine on the quay; the pipes had been set up to be repaired - Labay had a spile in his hand, ready to put into a hole which had been bored in the cask; Brenan was holding a bottle to catch the wine which was running out; when the bottle was full Lahay put the spile in - Brenan passed between me and Lahay, and put the bottle down between two casks; it contains about three quarters of a pint of port wine - I went to the gate, and reported them.
Cross-examined by MR. STURGEON. Q.How long have you been a watchman there? A.Seven years - the prisoners had no business to taste wine.
Lahay's Defence. There were other coopers there - Iwas gathering up my tools, and was some distance from the cask; this man has had a prejudice against me ever since last summer.
Brenan's Defence. I know nothing of it.

JAMES GILLESPIE
. The prisoners were the only men near the cask.
The prisoners received an excellent character.

LAHAY -
GUILTY . Aged 36.

BRENAN -
GUILTY . Aged 35.
Confined Three Months .

1528.
WILLIAM PARKIN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of June , 1 cart-saddle, value 1l.; 1 bridle, value 10s.; 1 wanty, value 2s., and 1 sack, value 2s. , the goods of
Thomas Pretty
.

THOMAS PRETTY
. I live in Chapel-street, Somer'stown, and am a green-grocer . On the 20th of June, about four o'clock in the morning, the Policeman alarmed me - I found my stable, which is in Isaac's-place
, broken open, and this harness gone, which was safe at nine o'clock the night before.

JAMES POSFORD
. I am a Policeman. On the morning of the 21st of June, a little after one o'clock, I saw Holloway, (who has been tried,) in Phillips'-buildings, and watched him; he watched another constable who was on his beat in Isaac's-place, into the New-road - he stopped at the corner of Isaac's-place, and the prisoner came up and spoke to him; I followed him down Isaac's-place, and met Holloway with a sack, containing this harness - I collared him, and asked what he had; the prisoner then came up, and knocked me down; I was left insensible, and they both got away - when I came to myself I found the sack and harness by my side; I had known the prisoner for three months, and am positive he is the man - I apprehended him afterwards, and accused him of this; he said,"Stuff and nonsense, come and have a drop of gin, and let me go;" I knew him well - I have often been called into the Crown and Anchor to turn him out.

Cross-examined by MR. STURGEON. Q.Then you have had some scuffles with him? A. Yes: I never had a spite against him; I believe he and Holloway spoke to each other, but I was not near enough to hear - it was a nice star-light night, and there was a lamp just over; he resisted when I took him - I am quite positive of him.

CHARLES STEWART
. I am a Police-constable. I knew the prisoner, and, in consequence of what Posford said, I pointed him out.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I have friends to prove where I was from five o'clock in the evening till eleven the next day.

JAMES CUMMINGS
. I am a carver, and live in Salisbury-street, Lisson-grove, Portman-market. On Monday night, the 20th of June, I saw the prisoner at the Goat and Compasses, Fitzroy-street; he was not out of my company till three o'clock in the morning.

COURT. Q. How far is Salisbury-street from Chapel-street? A.Between one and two miles - my wife called at the public-house at half-past eight o'clock, and the prisoner carried my child home; I asked him and Lambert to go up and have some supper - we left the Goat about eleven; we made them a bed on the floor, and they were not out of my place till eleven o'clock next day - I have known the prisoner about twelve months - we had cold pickled pork for supper; we had had no fire for several hours; we had cold tea to drink, but no beer, for the houses were shut up - the prisoner and Lambert break fasted with us next morning; I lodge in the house; it was last Monday fortnight - I sat up till about three o'clock; I was never in custody, except for a noise in the street about four months ago - I was not detained.

GEORGE LAMBERT
. On the 20th of June I went to the Goat about six o'clock, and staid till about eleven; the prisoner and Cummings were there, and we went and helped Cummings and his wife home with their three children - he invited us to supper; we sat there till three o'clock in the morning, and had cold pork; we had beer to drink, and stopped all night - we had been at the public-house, but I had nothing but water at Cummings'; I do not know what the others had; they made up a bed in the front room, and Parkin and I slept there.
COURT. Q.Where do you live? A. In Milton-place. The prisoner is a carpenter.
MRS. CUMMINGS. On Monday, the 20th of June, Parkin and Lambert supped at our house, and slept there; they remained there till eleven o'clock in the morning.

COURT. Q. What time did you get home? A. Between eleven and twelve o'clock; some beer was fetched from the public-house at the corner of the street for supper- I do not know who fetched it, as I was putting the children to bed in another room; I found it there when I came in, and drank some - we had no fire; I made tea about three o'clock, and lighted the fire then - there was some cold tea drank before that; they were smoking, and drinking beer.

GUILTY . Aged 29. -
Confined One Year .

1529.
JAMES McNIFF
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of July
, 5 yards of lace, value 30s., and 4 skirt ornaments, value 17s. , the goods of
John Burgens
, his master; and
BENJAMIN SMART
was indicted for
feloniously receiving the same, well knowing them to have been stolen .
MR. ADOLPHUS conducted the prosecution.

JOHN BURGESS
. I am a tailor , and live in Woodstock-street - I have no partner. On the 29th of June McNiff was in my employ, as a journeyman ; I took him on the Wednesday morning; I advanced him 5s. the first day, and 2s. 6d. the next - he asked for money a third time; I refused to let him have any more till he had completed a full dress colonel's coat, which he was about - I had delivered him lace to put on that coat; I was called out, and when I returned he was gone - I looked where he had been at work, and missed the lace, the ornaments, and some little bits of kerseymere; I had three men then at work, and I sent out two of them to make inquiries.

EDWARD JONES
. I was in the prosecutor's employ. I went out in search of McNiff; I found him at a public-house, in the Seven-dials - he had a new pair of shoes on; there was some beer on the table, and he was singing a song - a person, who was with me, asked him about the silver lace; he said it was in the shop there - the other man then told him if he would tell him where the lace was he would get it out at his own expence, rather than thereshould be any more row about it; he did not state where it was.

MR. BURGESS re-examined. As I was coming to Bow-street, the next morning, I went by chance into the prisoner Smart's shop, in Princes-street - I showed him a pattern of some of the ornaments which I had lost, and asked if he had such goods, and if he had any lace according to the new regulation - he turned as if he was going to find the articles, then turned back, and said he had no such goods, for whatever he bought in that way he always melted it directly - he did not show me any thing then, and I went away; I went and saw McNiff, previous to the examination at Bow-street - I did not use any threat or make any promise to get him into conversation - I only said there was quite enough to convict him, as some kerseymere was found on him - in consequence of what he told me I went back to Mr. Smart's shop, with an officer, between ten and eleven o'clock the same morning - the officer went in first, and I waited about five minutes; I then went in, and Mr. Smart stated that what he had purchased he had melted down, and he gave us a bill of 1l. 17s. 6d., as a memorandum of what he had purchased that evening - he then produced this silver, which had been melted, and these other articles, which was what he stated he had purchased, and that he had not purchased any thing else that evening - this silver was then put into a bag, and taken to the office - he stated before the Magistrate that that was what he had purchased, and he had nothing else but what he had melted; the Magistrate immediately granted a search-warrant - I went with it with an officer; Mr. Smart remained at Bow-street - we then searched the premises, and in a back room behind the shop; we found a chest with a great quantity of silver in it - we pulled out a great deal of silver, and found the lace and these ornaments, which I had given to McNiff to work - I had marked them, and knew them again; McNiff had not exactly told me where these things were to be found, but he said it was in a shop near Wardour-street, going down towards the Hay-market; that answered the description of Mr. Smart's, and there I found these articles- when we found them, we produced them to Mr. Smart, and he acknowledged having purchased them of this man for 8s. - they cost me about 2s. 17s. 6d.; they were quite new- I am no judge of what would have been the worth of them to burn.

Cross-examined by MR. ALLEY. Q. Mr. Smart was not present at any conversation you had with the other prisoner? A. No; I had not been to Mr. Smart's before - he is a refiner; he says their business is to melt down silver lace - I showed him something like these ornaments, but I have not brought here what I showed to him; these which I found at his house correspond with what I showed him - these were sewn on a garment by mistake, but were never worn; they were taken off, and would be used again - I do not know what they would be worth to a refiner; I asked him whether he had any ornaments of this description, and like a star, which I made on a bit of paper- I asked if he had them to sell; I do not recollect a question being asked what they were wanted for - there was a person in the shop talking to him at the time; I do not know that these things are called lace in the trade - we call them ornaments; they are spangles, I believe - I do not know whether those he first produced are called ornaments; we do not use them - I think I went to the shop a second time about half an hour after the first - when we went back we still found him at home: the officer was in about five minutes before I went in - he was going to send his man with the things; the officer then said he would take them, and Mr. Smart said, "If you will take the things, I will come myself;" the officer said,"You must come yourself;" I think we were at Bow-street about a quarter of an hour before we went back a third time; we then left Mr. Smart at the office, but as we went back we met him in Covent-garden - I do not know whether he was on bail; I do not think he had an officer with him - I should imagine he was at large: he had an opportunity of going away - he said, when we were going back to his house, "You had better take my word, whatever was purchased was melted down:" he told us to desire his father to show us two tin boxes, and he showed us, very readily, over the place - I had not been to his house the day before; I went three times that morning - I think it might be an hour after my first calling that I went again, and he had that hour to have disposed of this property, but when the officer went it was there - I did not see his father there at first; his man was there, and he had an opportunity of telling him to get rid of the property; I have known the house for a long time - I know nothing of the parties; there had been an alteration in the military costume; we are acquainted with the costume, but I do not know that refiners know it - a man might not know whether what he bought was according to the present regulation or not.

MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. The second time you went you brought away these two ornaments, through which stitches had been passed, but they had not been worn? A. Yes; I only asked him then if he had such things to sell - I said nothing to induce him to think I had any suspicion; the second time I went with an officer, and then he produced these silver articles, and went to Bow-street; he said these were what he had purchased the evening before, and he gave me this bill of the amount - he wanted to send his man with them; the officer said, "If you send your man I shall take them;" he said, "You shan't take them from my man, I will go and take them myself;" he did not say any thing about any chests - he said we might take his word there was nothing but what was melted; these things were found at the bottom of the chest, in the back room.
COURT. Q. You went three times to Mr. Smart's? A. Yes; and it was the first time I asked if he had any lace according to the new regulation.

JOSEPH KENRICK
. I am a Police-constable. I went with Mr. Burgess to Mr. Smart's - I had not seen the other prisoner at that time; I went in before Mr. Burgess, and saw Mr. Smart there - I asked if he had bought any silver lace last night, and some ornaments belonging to a uniform coat; he called a man by the name of John, and asked him what sort of a man he bought the things of, and each of them described McNiff - I wished him to let the man come to Bow-street, to identify McNiff, and I said I wanted the property - he was weighing the ornaments, and Mr. Burgess came in; he did not state that these did not belong to him - Mr. Smart said these were the ornaments, and that the lace was melted down; he was going to give his man the ornaments, and as I wanted to take them he said he wouldgo, and I said, "Very well;" - we went to Bow-street, and when we were going to execute the search-warrant, Mr. Smart wished to go, but I said he must stop - he said his father was old and nervous, and would be alarmed; I told him every thing should be done in a gentle way - he told me to tell his father there were two tin boxes he might show us, but he said it was no use to go to search, as they were burnt - I went down and saw this property taken out of a box, I think it was a tin box, but I was not near enough to see; in coming to Bow-street again, we met Mr. Smart in New-street - he turned and went to Bow-street, and was held to bail.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did the prosecutor go back to Bow-street with Mr. Smart? A. Yes - I do not know whether he was present when he was held to bail: I was in the shop, and the tin boxes were in the back room - there was nothing to hide them from my view; in my opinion they were taken from a tin box - there was a great deal of lace taken out: the question I put to Mr. Smart was, whether he had bought any lace the night before with military ornaments - he said he had, and he produced these things, I believe, or some similar - I believe he then asked the young man to come forward, and state whether lace had been bought with these ornaments, and I understood the lace was burnt, but whether it was the lace bought with these ornaments or not I do not know; he showed me something similar to this, which he called burnt - he was asked what he gave for it, and I thought it said on the bill, 1l. 17s. 6d.; if he trusted his property with me there would have been no necessity for his going to Bow-street - his father appeared a nervous old gentleman; we were afforded every facility in searching - there seemed no opposition to it; this property could have been melted down in five minutes - there was a fire and every thing backwards.

MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. When Mr. Smart produced these articles, and showed the bill, did he tell you that he had bought other things? A. No, he did not - I understood the lace was destroyed; I did not go in to search the boxes - I did not see any deal box; there is a partition and a glass door between the shop and parlour - I had been in that room before the search, and saw the two tin boxes; I did not notice any deal box.

EDWARD HARRINGTON TURNER
. I am a wool-stapler and merchant. I was at Mr. Smart's at the time of the search - I had been at Bow-street, and Mr. Burgess asked me to accompany him down - I saw this lace and property found in a box in the room adjoining the shop; I believe it was a deal box - there were some small tin boxes in the shop, but I did not notice any in the room; these articles were found in the bottom of the box.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. You will not swear whether there were any tin boxes in the room? A. No, I did not notice any; I will not swear whether they were found in a tin box or a wooden one - it was filled with lace; the constable, who is not here, was present -Mr. Burgess took out the things; I am not in business just at present - I am waiting the result of an appeal in the House of Lords, and some actions in the King's Bench - Mr. Smedly is my attorney.

MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. Did you know Mr. Smart before this? A. No, I did not; I had no quarrel with him, nor any interest to serve Mr. Burgess - I happened to hear Mr. Burgess was at Bow-street, and went in there; there were some tin boxes in the shop, which the officer took from a drawer - Mr. Smart's father was there.

COURT. Q. Was the box from which these things were taken larger than the tin boxes? A.Much larger - I do not know that any one pointed out the tin boxes; I should think the box from which this property was taken was about a foot square - the tin boxes were about four or six inches.

McNiff's Defence. I was very much inebriated, and in consequence of that I committed this act; Mr. Smart said, "Is this your property?" I said Yes; he said, "If it is not, I will not purchase it" - I still persisted it was, and he laid me down 8s.; he is as innocent of buying it, knowing it to be stolen, as I am guilty of the theft - I should not have done it had I not been drunk.

Smart read the following Defence. I am utterly incapable of what is laid to my charge, and hosts of witnesses will tell you the same; the circumstances which have brought me into this, I would have detailed before the Magistrate, but was not allowed- we buy lace and ornaments to burn, that is, to get the silver they contain; we are not in the habit of selling them, and if any one asked if I had lace of any particular pattern, I should have answered No - on the day I bought these, several ornaments and pieces of lace had been offered, which had been refused, but about six o'clock I bought the silver ornaments of an officer's coat, and with them a piece of lace which I have since discovered had belonged to -; the late army regulations having dispensed with much of the lace formerly worn, it is very common for such articles to be offered for sale, though they had not been worn - when the prosecutor called at my house, what passed will be detailed to you; in about ten minutes after the Police-officer called, and asked if I had bought any military ornaments of a man, I showed him what I had bought at six o'clock, and gave him the weight, and the amount from the day-book - he asked me to take them to Bow-street, and I did; he asked if I should know the man - I said I did not, but he might ask my man; I went to Bow-street, and saw the man now beside me, but that was not the man I had bought these ornaments of - the lace brought with these ornaments had been burnt, as I stated; when the prosecutor and the officer asked where it was, I said burnt - you will at once perceive what lace I meant, but they who asked the question did not perceive my meaning; a search-warrant was then granted, and these things were found in an open tin box, with other pieces of lace which had been purchased, and which I had abundant time to have removed, had I been the person capable of the felony laid to my charge; all this I would have explained to Mr. Halls, but he would not allow me.

WILLIAM FISH
. I am foreman to Mr. Smart. I recollect these military ornaments and some silver lace being brought at the same time, by a person who is not here - I burnt it to ascertain the value and weight of it; this is the produce of it - I cannot exactly tell what it weights; my master gave 5s. 8d. an ounce for it - I do not remember how much was paid for it; I did not see McNiff come afterwards, but this lace was not brought by him - we buy to refine, not to sell in the same state we buy it; we melt it into bars.

MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. You were present when these ornaments, and some lace which has been burnt, were brought to your shop? A. Yes; that was about five o'clock; I did not see these other things and this lace brought - we ask questions of persons who are strangers,of whom we have any suspicion; I do not know whether my master asks other persons - Mr. Smart keeps these things in a tin box in the shop till they are melted; we sometimes burn new lace and ornaments - the person we bought these ornaments and the lace which was burnt of, was a respectable tall man; I never saw him before nor since - he did not tell me where he came from; I was in the back shop - he brought an officer's belt, and I destroyed it myself.
COURT. Q. Are you the only person employed at burning silver lace? A. Yes - there was a fire in the place when they came to Mr. Smart.
Thirty-two witnesses gave Smart an undeniable character, several of whom being silver-refiners, valued the property at about 8s. to burn.
The prisoner Smart pointed out to the Jury the following entry in his book, "3 oz. 4 drachms, 8s."

McNIFF -
GUILTY .
Confined One Year in the House of Correction .

SMART -
GUILTY .
Recommended to Mercy by the Jury and Prosecutor.
Confined One Year in Newgate .
